item.title: Drawing Git Graphs in the Browser
item.description: A talk I gave at FullStack NYC 2019 to present GitGraph.js.
item.content:encoded:
In this talk I presented a side-project that I‚Äôve been developing with my friend Fabien Bernard since 2013: GitGraph.js üéâ

It‚Äôs a JS library that allows you to draw git graphs in the browser. Very handy to prepare presentations or write blog posts. Creating and updating those git illustrations becomes easy!

I already wrote about GitGraph.js in the past.

If there is one thing you should retain from my talk, it‚Äôs that you can hack your own problems. You certainly have this crazy idea in mind, that problem you want to solve for yourself‚Ä¶ Stop waiting the perfect moment, just start doing it. Good things will happen!

Click on the following image to access the slides:

The project is available on GitHub: https://github.com/nicoespeon/gitgraph.js/

Different libraries are available:

  • @gitgraph/js for the vanilla JS version
  • @gitgraph/react for the React version
  • There is a browser bundle you can use directly in the browser üí™

If you want to play with the GitGraph.js, have a look at the online playground:

item.title: The Secrets of Hexagonal Architecture
item.description: A talk I gave at ConFoo Montr√©al 2019 about Hexagonal Architecture.
item.content:encoded:
If there is one thing you should retain from my talk, it‚Äôs that you should separate the Domain from the Infrastructure if you want to write maintainable software.

The Domain is the business part. Today, I work at Busbud. We sell intercity bus tickets, worldwide. We talk about things like Seat, Departure, Leg, Stop, Roundtrip‚Ä¶ These are specific to our business, and we understand this vocabulary in a given context. We also have Taxes, Fees, Discount Code that you probably have to. This is a more generic Domain for us, but it‚Äôs still business.

The Infrastructure part is how is our current solution made. Fastly, Postgres databases, Redis instances, Express server, React‚Ä¶ All of these technologies we use to provide busbud.com to travellers across the planet. But we could change the infrastructure, still we do the same business.

The Hexagonal Architecture is the simplest way to do this separation. Put your Domain at the heart of your software. Make your Infra depends on your Domain, and your Domain not depending on your Infra. Use business vocabulary inside the Domain part, to define intention-revealing interfaces (aka Ports). Build concrete implementations of these interfaces in your Infra (aka Adapters). That gives you the flexibility to plug any adapter to your domain.

It makes testing easy. It allows you to start with something simple, and evolve the infrastructure when actually needed. Finally, It‚Äôs a good first step towards Clean Architecture.

Here are the slides of the talk:

The Secrets of Hexagonal Architecture de Nicolas Carlo

item.title: TIL: Tools can limit the potential of agile ceremonies
item.description: Today, I realized how not using an online tool could improve team engagement in a ceremony.
item.content:encoded:
Today is Friday. And not any Friday, but the end of our 2-weeks Sprint. End of the Sprint means demos, but also a ceremony that I really like: Sprint Retrospective.

Whatever is your process, the core thing of Agile is to reduce the feedback loop. Having a recurring ceremony when people pause and reflect on how things went during the last few days is really valuable. It gives time to all of us to share our thoughts and feelings. We give feedback to others about how we operate as a team, and how we could do better. As the team grows in maturity, this feedback will be part of daily work. Still, having a recurring ceremony is really valuable as it helps us to step back and reflect.

At Busbud, we usually do retrospective using an online board. It‚Äôs a typical ‚ÄúStart, Stop, Continue‚Äù (SSC) board, with a column for ‚ÄúNext Actions‚Äù. I think the best part of it is that people can participate, even when they are not at the office‚Äîit‚Äôs really common for us to work from home when we need to.

But today was different!

Today, the meeting room was taken for unexpected, important reasons. So we didn‚Äôt have a place to regroup. That‚Äôs when I suggested to do the retrospective offline‚Äînobody was remote anyway.

So we went to our big whiteboard. We bring the post-its, the markers and we stood up in half-circle around the whiteboard. We did a SSC and even a Mood Meter roundtable.

I remember retrospective meetings where we usually meet around a table. We‚Äôll bring our laptops because, you know, we need to put our items in the online board. And I always get this feeling at some point that it‚Äôs more about the process than the content. We usually get some discussions, but it‚Äôs always the same people talking‚Äîme, definitely included.

Being all here, standing up and writing on post-its was much more engaging! Everybody was clearly involved in the retrospective. Everybody was here and present. We had really insightful exchanges, and we took very interesting ‚ÄúNext Actions‚Äù. I asked for feedback at the end of the session, and the team quite liked the offline format.

Sometimes, convenient tools can play against the meaning of the ceremony. Dropping the tool turned to unleash the potential of our retrospective. I have this feeling we may have found a better way of working, as a team. I‚Äôm looking forward in 2 weeks, to see how it goes.

And you, are you using an online tool for your retrospectives?

item.title: TIL: Easy file sharing from the command line
item.description: Today, I learned how to easily retrieve a file from a distant server.
item.content:encoded:
Today, I was working on Busbud ‚ÄúPreview‚Äù environment. I was connected to the distant Heroku machine, through ssh (with the Heroku CLI command heroku run bash). I ran a task that generates a CSV report and I wanted to get it on my local machine so I can read it more conveniently.

In such a scenario, I usually use scp from my machine to download the file from the distant server. But I didn‚Äôt know the address of the machine I was connected to since I used the convenient Heroku CLI. I could have searched for it, but instead, a Google search gave me a nice solution: transfer.sh.

The idea is to send data to this service from CLI, then retrieve it from an URL. Data could also be encrypted, and upload is made through https üîê

Usage is very simple. Say I want to get my task-report.csv:

curl --upload-file ./task-report.csv https://transfer.sh/my-report.csv

After the upload is complete, I get the URL where I can retrieve it (e.g. https://transfer.sh/66nb8/my-report.csv).

Data are stored 14 days by default. But this can be configured on upload, with other different options like:

curl -H "Max-Downloads: 1" -H "Max-Days: 5" --upload-file ./hello.txt https://transfer.sh/hello.txt

I can also configure an alias for convenience, but I didn‚Äôt feel I need to‚ÄîI‚Äôd usually use that from a distant server which I don‚Äôt have the address on hand.

So yeah. I did that and got my CSV file in no time. Thank you transfer.sh!

And you, do you have tips & tricks for retrieving distant files?

item.title: TIL: A parchment paper trick
item.description: Today, I learned how to easily make parchment paper fits a recipient.
item.content:encoded:
Today aha moment is cooking related üë®‚Äçüç≥

I usually use parchment paper to protect baking sheets and the like‚Äîessentially when I bake cakes, cookies, and other niceties üç™

Sometimes, I also struggle to make it fit the recipient. Especially when it goes 3D. I used to measure and cut to adapt. But overall, it‚Äôs not really convenient.

Today, I learned that you can actually wet the parchment paper and crumple it to make this easy! Parchment paper is strong, even when it‚Äôs wet. Crumple it, put it under water, press it to eliminate the excess of water then unfold it. It will be easier to make it fit the recipient you want to protect.

Also, I learned that you can use it almost any time a recipe tells you to put some butter on your cake mold. Wet parchment paper will do the trick faster and leave the mold in a cleaner state‚Äîso you can reuse more quickly if you need to.

And voil√†!

And you, do you have tips & tricks for cooking?

item.title: TIL: How to start a talk
item.description: Today, I learned how to do a great introduction for a conference talk.
item.content:encoded:
2019 is a challenging year for me. I‚Äôll give my first talk, in English, in front of a larger audience than the 40-folks standard of local meetups I‚Äôm used to.

Actually, I‚Äôll give two talks:

  • In March, I‚Äôll present ‚ÄúThe secrets of Hexagonal Architecture‚Äù at Confoo Montreal
  • In May, I‚Äôll talk about ‚ÄúDrawing Git Graphs in the browser‚Äù at FullStack NYC

I did quite a few talks in the past, but they usually were in French ‚Äì my native language ‚Äì and in front of the local tech community, in meetups. As you might imagine, I‚Äôm both thrilled and scared. Thus, I‚Äôm preparing these talks ‚Äì the last thing I want would be to screw up in front of hundreds of people I¬†don‚Äôt know üòÖ

I already have plenty of good resources about giving such talks and preparing great slides. In fact, I used to provide such advice when I was coaching colleagues to speak at meetups, back in Paris.

But today, I came across a short video titled ‚ÄúHow to Start a Speech‚Äù. The fact it‚Äôs a 9min video is great: it goes to the point. I watched it after lunchtime, and it was both catchy and insightful. Here‚Äôs what I learned.

There are 2 common mistakes speakers usually do when they start their talk:

  1. A very formal talk introduction: ‚ÄúMy name is Nicolas Carlo, I work at Busbud, today I‚Äôm gonna talk about ‚ÄòThe secrets of Hexagonal Architecture‚Äô‚Äù. All of this, people already know ‚Äì they do have a program. As I‚Äôm spending time repeating this information, it gives the audience time to disconnect from me and look at their phone while I‚Äôm going through usual stuff.

  2. A very hesitating introduction: ‚ÄúAaaaaah eeeeeeeeeh‚Ä¶ Is the mic working?‚Ä¶ Yes‚Ä¶ Ok‚Ä¶ Right‚Ä¶ hmmmm‚Ä¶‚Äù. Which is obviously not very engaging. It could happen though because of stress. My personal advice here is to practice the talk before ‚Äì in front of colleagues at work, or/and in a local meetup. Practicing out loud at home and recording the video is also really helpful to self-improve our talk delivery.

The second one is obvious, but I didn‚Äôt think too much about the first one. It‚Äôs obviously the classical way of doing it, and most of the speakers I know do it like that ‚Äì including myself.

Then, here are 3 better ways to start a talk:

  1. ü§î Ask a question that matters to the audience. The idea is to make people relate to the problem. If I raise a question that you also have at work, it‚Äôs likely you‚Äôll be interested in knowing the answer. The talk is here to answer that question.

  2. üôÄ Start with a fact that shocks. It‚Äôs really easy today to access facts, studies, and different resources. A fact can illustrate the whole point of the talk, or be somehow related. Having a powerful fact that will force the audience into rethinking what they know is really catchy.

  3. üìñ Tell a story. Actually, it‚Äôs not something new. Still, it holds true. Even more for conferences talks. ‚ÄúOnce upon a time‚Äù makes children lean forward. And the grown-up way of saying ‚ÄúOnce upon a time‚Äù is to tell a story, usually one from your own life. A story that connects you to the subject of the talk. A story that explains why it is important to you. For example, ‚Äúthe first time‚Äù you discover the benefits of the thing you‚Äôre presenting.

That‚Äôs it. I‚Äôll personally try to rework the introduction of my Confoo talk to start with a story ‚Äì which is not that hard, I do have a story and fun facts to tell about it!

Here‚Äôs the full video if you have some more time to watch it. In my opinion, it worth it:

And you, do you have tips & tricks for public speaking?

item.title: "I need to change this code, but it has no test"
item.description: An introduction to "Approval Testing" in JavaScript with Jest.
item.content:encoded:
Here‚Äôs the deal: you need to change the code to make this awesome new feature work, but that code is not covered by an automated test. How do you know you didn‚Äôt break anything when you‚Äôre done?

That‚Äôs a typical scenario I frequently face.

I see different approaches in such a situation:

  1. ü§û Cross fingers, do the change and hope nothing breaks. Manually test different use cases you know. After all, you‚Äôre just adding a feature. You know the codebase, more or less. What could go wrong?

  2. ü§î Spend time to understand, test and refactor the code before changing it. ‚ÄúMake the change easy, then make the easy change‚Äù. Sure, it will take some time. You didn‚Äôt estimate that task to take that much time actually. That‚Äôs unexpected complexity. But, in the end, you will leave codebase in a better state and you‚Äôll be able to go faster.

  3. üì∏ Take a snapshot of existing code behavior. Consider it a black box and capture enough of its behavior to feel confident touching it.

I clearly think the first approach is shooting yourself in the foot ‚àí except if you know you won‚Äôt need to maintain that code. Heck, it seems you‚Äôre maintaining this code already, otherwise, you wouldn‚Äôt have this question in the first place! If you want to keep moving fast without breaking everything, there is a better, more professional way.

The second approach would be ideal. Working effectively with legacy code requires putting the existing code into a test harness, first. Then, you can refactor. But, it takes skills to write good tests. You should practice these skills though, they will help you with these ‚Äì so common ‚Äì scenarios. Now, I hear you: client demo is next week and you need to ship that cool feature before. You need a pragmatic solution to the problem. You‚Äôre gonna take this shortcut consciously so you can deliver, then you‚Äôll pay the technical debt back. Now, are you stuck with approach #1 then?

Nope. Approach #3 is more‚Ä¶ pragmatic. You have to put your code under test before you touch it anyway. But, who said you need to completely understand current code to do so? What you want is to know if you break existing behavior when you touch the code. This, you can do with Approval Testing.

The main idea is:

  • take a snapshot of existing code behavior, in all possible variations
  • use test coverage to discover parts of the code not covered with the variations
  • use mutations to ensure you detect any broken behavior

You don‚Äôt need to understand existing code to do so. That‚Äôs the good news.

There is a pre-requisite though: you need to take a snapshot of your code behavior, meaning that you should be able to stringify the output of your code, including side-effects. If your codebase was not designed with tests in mind, you probably need to rely on Michael Feather‚Äôs book to help you get started.

Now, let see how you can do that in JavaScript.

Approval Testing in JavaScript

My personal go-to for JavaScript testing nowadays is Jest.

It is simple to set up ‚Äì almost no configuration needed. It has a wonderful test runner baked in, with a powerful watch mode. Finally, and that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre looking for, it can take snapshots.

Snapshots are powerful. But they are a test-after technique. I usually recommend to practice Test-Driven Developement, so you should barely need snapshots. Actually, snapshots have very few valid use-cases. Putting tests on existing code, before refactoring it, is one of these.

Now, I need an example. I‚Äôll use the Gilded Rose kata to illustrate that. It‚Äôs an exercise to practice refactoring techniques, which is really convenient here. I made a JS starter of the kata that you can use.

So you have 2 classes:¬†Shop and Item. Item is pretty simple:

export class Item {
  constructor(name, sellIn, quality) {
    this.name = name
    this.sellIn = sellIn
    this.quality = quality
  }
}

Then you have Shop which takes a list of items and have a method updateQuality() that will update the quality and sellIn attributes of every item. There is a bunch of logic that‚Äôs currently supposed to work. It is not pretty though, so I won‚Äôt put it here but give you a link to the beast instead.

Your goal: change updateQuality() so it deals with "Conjured" items too (they degrade in quality twice as fast as normal items).

There is no test. A good idea is to refactor this code first ‚Äì make the change easy, remember?

Let me show you how to apply the Approval Testing technique in such a scenario.

1. Generate an output you can snapshot

The first step is to generate a snapshot from updateQuality(). It doesn‚Äôt return a string, but it changes items. Thus, my first move is to write a function returning something which captures the changes so Jest can take a snapshot of it:

// I put that code in my test file, since it's test-related.

function doUpdateQuality(name, sellIn, quality) {
  const gildedRose = new Shop([new Item(name, sellIn, quality)])
  const items = gildedRose.updateQuality()
  return items[0]
}

I could have returned items, but I‚Äôm simplifying things a bit here: I‚Äôm only testing a shop with one item. That‚Äôs because I already know the behavior is the same regardless the number of items. It might not be your case. You should adapt to your situation, this is the tricky part.

Now I have a doUpdateQuality(name, sellIn, quality) I can call from my tests. It will instantiate the shop, call the method I‚Äôm testing and return me the updated item.

My next move is to write the first test, taking a snapshot from the output:

it('should update quality', () => {
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 0)).toMatchSnapshot()
})

function doUpdateQuality(name, sellIn, quality) {
  // ‚Ä¶
}

If you‚Äôre not familiar with Jest snapshot testing, I suggest you take a few minutes to have a look at their documentation. I will wait üòâ

2. Using test coverage to find all input combinations

At this point, I generated a first snapshot, given a set of parameters. Jest will tell me if any regression happens to that scenario. Can I go refactor updateQuality() now? Nope. Because I‚Äôm not covering all the code with this snapshot. This, I can know thanks to the test coverage!

To generate test coverage, I run Jest with the --coverage option.

I find the html report to be the best in this scenario. To do so, I need to configure Jest options. This can be done in a config file, or quickly in package.json:

{
  "name": "gilded-rose-kata",
  // ‚Ä¶
  "scripts": {
    "test": "jest"
  },
  "jest": {
    "coverageReporters": [
      "html"
      // I could add "text" or "text-summary" to see output in the console
    ]
  }
}

Then, I run yarn test --coverage (or npm run test -- --coverage), which generates a coverage/ folder.

I open the coverage/index.html file:

All the red lines, I don‚Äôt test.

Let‚Äôs figure out another combination that would cover more lines‚Ä¶ An item with a positive quality should do:

it('should update quality', () => {
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 0)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
})

I run the test again. A new snapshot is generated.

Coverage report is updated:

Yay, less red lines!

So you get the idea: during this phase, I need to find all the possible combinations that would cover all the code. No more red lines.

Let‚Äôs fast-forward a bit. Here‚Äôs what I‚Äôve got:

it('should update quality', () => {
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 0)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 2)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Aged Brie', 0, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(
    doUpdateQuality('Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert', 0, 1)
  ).toMatchSnapshot()
})

No more red lines, but I still have these E symbols. These symbols mean that I‚Äôm covering the if case, but I‚Äôm missing the else clause ‚Äì that‚Äôs why only 68.57% of branches are covered. I need to cover them too:

it('should update quality', () => {
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 0)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 2)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Aged Brie', 0, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Aged Brie', 0, 50)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Sulfuras, Hand of Ragnaros', 0, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Sulfuras, Hand of Ragnaros', -1, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(
    doUpdateQuality('Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert', 0, 1)
  ).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(
    doUpdateQuality('Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert', 11, 1)
  ).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(
    doUpdateQuality('Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert', 0, 49)
  ).toMatchSnapshot()
})

So far, so good. I‚Äôm covering every line and branch. Can I go refactor updateQuality() now?

Well‚Ä¶ not yet. Remember when I said test coverage can only tell you ‚Äúwhat code is not tested‚Äù? That means it doesn‚Äôt tell you if the covered code is properly tested.

This is why setting a test coverage objective to ensure test quality doesn‚Äôt work. Test coverage tells you parts that are not tested ‚Äì and that might be fine not to test these parts. Other than that, it says nothing.

To me, good test coverage comes as a side-effect of a good testing strategy (TDD). It‚Äôs not a target.

3. Use mutations to verify snapshots

To ensure the covered code is actually tested, I‚Äôm gonna introduce little mutations in the code.

The goal here is to see the test fail. If I change the existing code and a test fail, I‚Äôll feel safe refactoring this code! When the test has failed, I revert the mutation and move to another line.

What mutations should you introduce? Again, it depends on what you‚Äôre testing ‚Äì sorry. Usually, mutate the side-effects that you‚Äôre capturing in your snapshot. In my case, that means I don‚Äôt have to change ifs, but only the updates to item. There are 8 of them.

Let‚Äôs start with the first assignment, line 22:

if (this.items[i].name != 'Sulfuras, Hand of Ragnaros') {
  this.items[i].quality = this.items[i].quality - 1
}

I‚Äôll introduce a little mutation, just to check:

if (this.items[i].name != 'Sulfuras, Hand of Ragnaros') {
  this.items[i].quality = this.items[i].quality - 2
}

I run my tests again:

Great! I know my test will catch any regression here. I can revert my mutation.

Let‚Äôs move on the other ones. I introduce a similar mutation line 33:

if (this.items[i].quality < 50) {
  this.items[i].quality = this.items[i].quality + 2
}

Run tests again and‚Ä¶

That‚Äôs not good.

Before going further, I revert the mutation in the code. Don‚Äôt let mutations live long.

Then, at that point, I need to think a bit about the code ‚Äì yeah, I lied, but you don‚Äôt have to understand all the code. How could this happen? I suspect that a further update makes me take another path in the following logic, resulting in a similar result with my given combinations. Looking at the lines of code I want to mutate, I find this one to be interesting:

if (this.items[i].name != 'Sulfuras, Hand of Ragnaros') {
  this.items[i].sellIn = this.items[i].sellIn - 1
}
if (this.items[i].sellIn < 0) {
  // ‚Ä¶
}

That means if sellIn is 0, then it doesn‚Äôt execute the rest of the code. I try to add another combination:

it('should update quality', () => {
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 0)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 2)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Aged Brie', 0, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Aged Brie', 0, 50)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Sulfuras, Hand of Ragnaros', 0, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Sulfuras, Hand of Ragnaros', -1, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(
    doUpdateQuality('Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert', 0, 1)
  ).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(
    doUpdateQuality('Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert', 11, 1)
  ).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(
    doUpdateQuality('Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert', 0, 49)
  ).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(
    doUpdateQuality('Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert', 1, 0)
  ).toMatchSnapshot()
})

I generate the new snapshot, then retry the mutation:

It worked!

I revert my mutation and continue to the next assignment. I do that until I know all of them are actually covered with tests.

Hopefully, I didn‚Äôt found other false positive for coverage. Here‚Äôs the final list of tests:

it('should update quality', () => {
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 0)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('foo', 0, 2)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Aged Brie', 0, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Aged Brie', 0, 50)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Sulfuras, Hand of Ragnaros', 0, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(doUpdateQuality('Sulfuras, Hand of Ragnaros', -1, 1)).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(
    doUpdateQuality('Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert', 0, 1)
  ).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(
    doUpdateQuality('Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert', 11, 1)
  ).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(
    doUpdateQuality('Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert', 0, 49)
  ).toMatchSnapshot()
  expect(
    doUpdateQuality('Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert', 1, 0)
  ).toMatchSnapshot()
})

Can I go refactor updateQuality() now?

Yes! All the code is now covered by snapshots. A wrong move and I‚Äôll automatically know that. I can now refactor the code without introducing bugs. Then I‚Äôll add the feature ü§ò

4. These tests are technical debt

If you apply this recipe, remember this:¬†you accepted to take technical debt here. You traded well-written tests against snapshots of existing behavior to get a test harness faster so you can refactor.

Snapshots are powerful, but they don‚Äôt help you understand what the code is supposed to do. Once the code is refactored, you should pay the debt back: write proper, comprehensive tests on your clean code to replace your snapshots. If you do so, this part of the codebase will be easier to maintain in the future, and you‚Äôll add new features faster.

Introducing jest-extended-snapshot

Looking at the resulting test code, I thought that was a lot of boilerplate code in a single it!

So I refactored it with a custom Jest matcher: toVerifyAllCombinations().

With it, the previous code could be written the following:

it('should update quality', () => {
  expect(doUpdateQuality).toVerifyAllCombinations(
    [
      'foo',
      'Aged Brie',
      'Backstage passes to a TAFKAL80ETC concert',
      'Sulfuras, Hand of Ragnaros',
    ],
    [-1, 0, 1, 11],
    [0, 1, 2, 49, 50]
  )
})

It will generate all possible combinations of the following arguments, call doUpdateQuality() with each and take a snapshot of all results.

I like it because it expresses the intention better: ‚Äúcurrent behavior should be preserved for all these scenarios‚Äù.

I extracted that into a library so you can use it too: jest-extended-snapshot üëπ

Inspiration

I discovered Approval Testing thanks to Emily Bache. She made a very nice 20-min screencast where she runs a demo of this very example, in Java:

You can read more about Approval Testing on http://approvaltests.com/.

They have a library to do that in JS, with Mocha: https://github.com/approvals/Approvals.NodeJS

item.title: Hexagonal Architecture & Elixir
item.description: A talk I gave at the Montreal Elixir meetup of November 2018.
item.content:encoded:
This is a talk I gave at the Montr√©al Elixir meetup of November 2018.

Let‚Äôs start from scratch and go beyond the buzzwords.

We‚Äôll go together through these ideas to understand how you can improve the maintainability of your projects, either greenfield or legacy.

We‚Äôll see how it can be achieved in Elixir to check if it goes along the philosophy of the language.

item.title: I built a tool to work with complicated Sass codebases
item.description: Introducing sass-graph-viz, a tool to draw a visual graph of Sass dependencies.
item.content:encoded:
I currently work as a web developer at Busbud.

Part of our stack is the public website that you can see at https://www.busbud.com. The first commit of its source code was made on January 2011. Today is December 12th, 2018. It has been almost 8 years!

For 8 years, the codebase has been growing. Today, code is still constantly updated to add new features, adopt or remove experiments, fix bugs‚Ä¶ As we work, we need to deal with existing, working, legacy code and ensure nothing breaks when we change it.

Today, I‚Äôd like to tell you about the styles part.

A lot of Sass files‚Ä¶

A choice has been made, long time ago, to use Sass as a pre-processor for our stylesheets.

This is great. It simplifies maintenance of styles thanks to variables, mixins and other niceties Sass brings to us.

Among the niceties, we do use @import a lot. It allows us to import partial files into others and compile them into a single CSS stylesheet. Again: this is great. It allows us to split styles into smaller chunks (convenient for development) and get a single stylesheet in the end (convenient for production).

But @import creates dependency relationships between Sass files. Today, we face issues of dependency graph management in a growing codebase. Now, I‚Äôm not talking about critical problems like circular dependencies ‚àí Sass does a great job dealing with that. I‚Äôm talking about understanding the dependency graph as a whole. It usually boils down to these questions:

  • In which final CSS will this style be compiled to?
  • Will this style be compiled into a CSS file where it‚Äôs not needed?
  • Is there any file not imported anymore?
  • Is there any (useless) duplicated import of the same partial?

These are tricky questions to answer when you have a lot of files.

The dependency graph of our codebase is not trivial. It started with a bunch of Sass files along Jade templates ; now we miss a clear architecture to maintain our styles with ease. Hopefully, we‚Äôve identified this technical debt, and we‚Äôre taking actions to pay it back.

But, until then, we have to work with this complicated Sass codebase.

Now, to visualise what we‚Äôre working with, I realised we need a tool to turn on the light.

Turn on the light, please

I first went to sass-graph. It‚Äôs a library which computes the dependency graph of a Sass codebase. Unfortunately, it was only able to output some sort of graph in my terminal, or a JSON structure. But to answer rapidly previous questions, I needed something visual.

Thus, I decided to plug sass-graph with a rendering library:

The difference is that sass-graph-viz generates a visual graph of dependencies in the browser.

You can use it as a CLI tool, as illustrated in this gif (a demo of v1):

You can quickly try it out with npx: npx sass-graph-viz path/to/your/scss

Or, you can install it with npm: npm i -g sass-graph-viz

Then use it in your terminal:

$ sassgraphviz --help
  Usage: sassgraphviz [options] <target>

  Options:
    -e, --exclude-externals  Omit files that are not under given target
    -s, --simple             Generate a simpler visualization (not recommended for complex graphs)
    -p, --port <port>        Port to use [3000]
    -h, --help               Output usage information

  Examples:
    sassgraphviz assets/scss
    sassgraphviz .
    sassgraphviz main.scss
    sassgraphviz main.scss -s -e -p 3001

Alternatively, you can use the alias sgv if sassgraphviz is too cumbersome to type.

How is this built?

It‚Äôs merely a plug of something that generates the dependency graph (sass-graph) and a graph rendering library. It exposes a CLI for convenient usage, and uses the browser to render the graph.

For graph rendering, I first went for viz.js because the API was simple and the result looked great.

The core idea of sass-graph-viz is:

  1. Expose a CLI command to get the path to the directory I want to parse
  2. Delegates to sass-graph the generation of dependencies graph
  3. Translate sass-graph‚Äôs Graph into my own Graph model
  4. Delegates to viz.js the rendering of the Graph in the browser

Now you might wonder: what‚Äôs the point in parsing sass-graph outputs into another Graph model?

I‚Äôd say this is the heart of the lib. This is my domain. Now, it‚Äôs probably really thin and might feel useless, but I have a few arguments in favor of this choice:

  1. The rendering lib doesn‚Äôt need all of the details sass-graph generates in its ‚ÄúGraph‚Äù modelling.
  2. The ‚ÄúGraph‚Äù from sass-graph doesn‚Äôt quite fit the rendering lib expected format anyway. A parsing is necessary at some point.
  3. Maybe I‚Äôll swap sass-graph for another tool, if I found a better one. If so, I‚Äôd better not tie the rendering lib to sass-graph implementation.
  4. I don‚Äôt know yet all the features I‚Äôll need to implement with the rendered graph. I don‚Äôt want to be limited by sass-graph capacity.

I quickly got it working for simple structures with viz.js. It helped me set up the architecture of the solution, exposing a CLI command to generate the graph.

For example, running sass-graph-viz assets/scss/ would produce following result:

But my graphs are more complex than that!

Otherwise, I wouldn‚Äôt have needed this tool anyway.

I moved to more realistic examples, running the tool against the codebase I was working on. There I confirmed I needed a better rendering lib to handle complex graphs.

I found vis.js ‚àí yeah, the one-letter difference is subtle. The lib showcases very cool, interactive graphs and the API looked nice. It was the solution I was looking for!

As the graph generation, the domain and the rendering were independent, is was really just about plugging another rendering adapter. One that would do the rendering with vis.js.

I enhanced the CLI a bit so vis.js became the default rendering lib and viz.js would be opt-in (with the -s, --simple option). I also provided a shorthand alias, so I wouldn‚Äôt need to type sassgraphviz every time.

At that point, running sgv assets/scss/ on previous example would produce following graph:

Few things to say here:

  • Unlike previous graph, this one is interactive. You can zoom, select and move nodes, as showcased in demo gif.
  • We visually distinct regular Sass files (e.g. main.scss) from partials (e.g. _header.scss). Partials are meant to be imported. I thought the distinction would be interesting.

And here‚Äôs where the separation of the domain started to pay off: I realised that I could add features to my graph, so it would be more useful. Identifying partial files is not the role of sass-graph, nor the one of the rendering lib. This belongs to the domain I created here. That also means it can be unit tested really easily: no need to manipulate actual Sass files, nor to spy on the browser.

Features, I want moar!

From usage, I noticed few quirks that I fixed. I also identified (and implemented) useful features.

The first one is the ability to exclude ‚Äúexternal files‚Äù from the rendered graph. By ‚Äúexternal files‚Äù I mean files that are outside the scope of the target folder. For example, we do import some source files from Bootstrap package which lives in node_modules/ ‚àí which is probably not the best idea, but these things happen. As I certainly can‚Äôt change all of these Bootstrap Sass files, I‚Äôd prefer they don‚Äôt show up and clutter my graph. I want to think about what I can change.

So here it is: sgv -e assets/scss/ will omit these external nodes from the generated graph.

Another feature from sass-graph-viz is the ability to focus on a file only. It‚Äôs very handy to only see a subset of the Sass files, the ones that are linked to a specific file. Intuitively, sgv assets/scss/core.scss does the trick and focus on core.scss dependencies (parents and children) only.

The last feature I wanted to highlight is the guidance the tool can provide. After all, since it computes the dependency graph of my Sass files, it could certainly detect suspicious patterns. One I identified was ‚Äúthe orphan partial‚Äù pattern. An ‚Äúorphan partial‚Äù is a partial file that doesn‚Äôt have a parent. Which is weird, as partials are meant to be imported. These are likely dead code we can remove. And it paid off: I was able to detect some of them in our codebase, and get rid of these unused files!

Typically, the tool would render suspicious nodes in red, like so:

This was fun

I had a great time building this little tool. So far, it was useful to understand the relationship between all of these Sass files. It might become useless when we‚Äôll solve the root cause of this mess, but it‚Äôs a handy tool to work with a complicated Sass codebase.

I hope it might be useful to you, if you face such situation. If you do, let me know about it!

If you have any comment, I‚Äôll be happy to reply here or directly on GitHub issues.

PS: If you‚Äôre into Hexagonal Architecture, what I described may sounds like ports & adapters. It is. Just, I didn‚Äôt made interfaces & the hexagon explicit yet (functions and types were simple enough to do so).

item.title: Git rebase onto
item.description: A story about this useful command.
item.content:encoded:
Thursday.

Sprint M started this Monday, just after the usual round of applause that ends every daily standup. When you looked at the backlog, you found it a bit ambitious, too optimistic, greedy. A new mountain the team started to tear apart methodically, piece by piece, progressively stacking these pieces under the ‚ÄúDone‚Äù column. The mountain was now bleeding through each column of the flow. Each story shows the head of the person ‚àí usually a developer ‚àí currently working on it. The whole thing is a chain, stories flowing from left to right, carried by the members of the team‚Ä¶

Just like ants carry food to the anthill.

You‚Äôd like to think about the metaphor a bit longer, but Ahmed brings you back to reality: ‚ÄúAbout the code review you asked me: is it OK if I do it at 3? I don‚Äôt really have time before‚Ä¶‚Äù

You frown:

‚ÄúWell, why not but it‚Äôs inconvenient for me. The new feature I need to work on depends on these changes so‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm blocked now.‚Äù

‚ÄúI get that, but I really can‚Äôt do that sooner. And I wouldn‚Äôt like to scamp it neither.‚Äù

‚ÄúOK, go for 3pm!‚Äù

‚ÄúAnyway, you are not blocked. Just start from the current branch. You‚Äôll rebase later.‚Äù

‚ÄúHow‚Äôs that?‚Äù

‚ÄúWell, just start from the current branch. You create a new branch from this one and you work on it.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks but‚Ä¶ no. Look, if I do that, the PR diff will contain changes from both branches. It‚Äôll be a mess!‚Äù

‚ÄúTrust me. Create a new branch, work on it and we‚Äôll figure this out later together.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you say so‚Ä¶ Thanks.‚Äù

You turn back to your screen while Ahmed heads rapidly toward the meeting room with his laptop. You still hesitate.

Damn it. Let‚Äôs do that.

15:30. You get the notification telling your PR has been approved. Satisfaction makes you smile. In the same time, Ahmed rolls his chair to your desk.

‚ÄúLegit to me. Nice job on this feature, nothing I could think of. Neat!‚Äù

‚ÄúIt was a small PR. It helps.‚Äù

‚ÄúSure. Anyway, you can merge it now.‚Äù

‚ÄúYup. I was just doing it aaaaaaaand‚Ä¶ Done!‚Äù

‚ÄúGreat!‚Äù

As he‚Äôs about to roll in the opposite direction, you add:

‚ÄúWait a minute. I created a branch like you told me. I did a few commits on it. But now it‚Äôs starting from the other branch, the one I merged.‚Äù

‚ÄúNot a problem. You need to rebase it on master.‚Äù

‚ÄúAnd how am I supposed to do that?‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not a big deal. Let‚Äôs see. First, show me you git log.‚Äù

‚ÄúThere you go!‚Äù

‚ÄúSee the last commit on master? This is the branch you merged. We use the ‚Äúsquash and merge‚Äù strategy, so your feature became a single commit on master.‚Äù

‚ÄúI never get that part. Like, why are we doing that anyway?‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is another debate. In short, some prefers the fact that ‚Äú1 commit = 1 feature‚Äù. Technically, because our branches are quite short-lived, it works. Thus, master is always stable.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah‚Ä¶ But I‚Äôve read that it‚Äôs better to keep the actual history.‚Äù

‚ÄúMaybe. Anyway, this is our convention for now. If you want to change it, go ahead and propose the subject during tomorrow‚Äôs tech meeting.‚Äù

‚ÄúOK.‚Äù

‚ÄúBack to what you want to do. You want to take the green branch feat/dynamic-campaigns and move it so it starts from master.‚Äù

‚ÄúHmmmm‚Ä¶ yeah, that‚Äôs it.‚Äù

‚ÄúTo do that, you need to use git rebase. There is an option called ‚Äúonto‚Äù which does exactly that.‚Äù

‚ÄúLike rebase onto master?‚Äù

‚ÄúKind of. Look.‚Äù

Still a bit puzzled, you‚Äôre trying to figure out what just happen:

‚ÄúWait a minute. Can you explain?‚Äù

‚ÄúSure. You see, git rebase can have a parameter called ‚Äúonto‚Äù which is useful in such scenarios. It takes 3 arguments.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo the first one is master. That‚Äôs the new branch, right?‚Äù

‚ÄúRight! It‚Äôs the reference of the new parent for the what you‚Äôre rebasing. Then comes the reference of the old parent: feat/create-campaigns in this case.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut‚Ä¶ Didn‚Äôt we merge this one before?‚Äù

‚ÄúOn origin yes. Locally on your computer, no. Remember your git history? You still have that branch on your machine.‚Äù

‚ÄúOK, got it. So new parent, then old parent‚Ä¶‚Äù

‚ÄúThen the reference of the branch you want to rebase. Technically, any commit reference will do. But usually, you work with branches.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs more convenient.‚Äù

‚ÄúYeah. The last argument is optional. If you don‚Äôt provide it, it‚Äôll use HEAD as a reference. But, you know me, I like when things are explicit. Less surprises.‚Äù

You nod while displaying the new git history to visualize what you‚Äôve done:

‚ÄúHey, it worked! It‚Äôs just like the branch started from master!‚Äù

‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what you asked for.‚Äù

‚ÄúThanks a lot! I‚Äôm gonna write this done somewhere.‚Äù

‚ÄúMy pleasure.‚Äù

On this final line, Ahmed pushes on his feet to roll back to his desk in a single attempt. Failed. As he tramples to finish rolling, you clean the local branch that has no more reason to be.

Bye.

You smile and give another look at the git history.

Clean.

You look at your watch. 15:45. You open your editor thinking that you still have time to work a bit more on this.

Another story processed. Just like ants‚Ä¶

item.title: So I went to Montreal Elixir meetup
item.description: Here is my feedback about how this meetup was, and what you could expect from it.
item.content:encoded:
Few days ago, I went to Montr√©al Elixir meetup of March.

I‚Äôm French. I moved to Montr√©al in February. Thus, this is the beginning of a new life for me ; a Canadian-dream as a Developer at Busbud. I used to attend / talk at / organize a lot of meetups, back in Paris. I‚Äôm now looking to meet the tech community of Montr√©al.

So here is my feedback about how this meetup was, and what you could expect from it.

By the way, if you don‚Äôt know it yet: Elixir is a dynamic, functional language.

It is built upon Erlang shoulders, which is really fault-tolerant and built for scalability (think telecoms). To put them in a nutshell, I‚Äôd say Elixir main goals are: productivity, maintainability and reliability.

Montr√©al Elixir is a monthly meetup. The community is not big ‚àí we were around 20 persons at the event.

They do have a website: http://www.montrealelixir.ca

The typical agenda of the meetup is:

  • Networking & food first, which is a nice ice-breaker.
  • Announcements from Elixir community, about books, news from the meetup organizers‚Ä¶
  • Talks, usually 20 minutes ones. But we‚Äôll try some lightning talks (5min) in the future.
  • Sponsor talks & open mic to anyone who‚Äôd have something to share to the group

It starts at 18:30, ends at 20:00, which is great if you want to go back home early. People generally speak english there, so it‚Äôs more inclusive.

This meetup talk was from Pedro Medeiros on ‚ÄúElixir formatter internals‚Äù.

In case you wonder, a formatter is a tool that aims to maintain a consistent style for your project. Thus, you don‚Äôt loose time discussing whether there must be a space before your parenthesis, nor you waste time with the linter telling you that you forgot a trailing space somewhere.

If you are familiar with JavaScript rather than Elixir, this is Prettier goal. Handles the syntax for you so you don‚Äôt have to bother. If you do Elm, this is elm-format job.

So it really helps productivity.

Elixir formatter is built-in. You can run it with mix format.

The talk focused on how the formatter works to format your code ‚àí building an AST, then logically applying the standard rules to re-write your code with proper indentation/spaces‚Ä¶

The meetup was nice and I enjoyed the community. I met and discussed with Henry Olders, who is both a psychiatrist and engineer. We discussed machine learning, Elixir and scalability.

üòÉüëç I really enjoyed that time and will come back to next sessions. Join us!

To conclude, here are some books recommendation I get from the meetup:

  • üìï Functional Web Development with Elixir, OTP, and Phoenix
  • üìò Learn Functional Programming with Elixir (good for beginners and newcomers to Functional Programming)
  • üìÑ To spawn or not to spawn to understand how to think in terms of processes, from the author of Elixir in action

item.title: Pair-programming makes people share
item.description: Few thoughts on pair-programming.
item.content:encoded:
Pair-programming is two persons, coding on the same screen.

There are different ways to practice pair-programming and mistakes to avoid.

Why do we pair-program? I think the main reason is to communicatebetween developers of the same team.

Communication is a central part of our job: building software. To build a software that satisfies people‚Äôs needs, we must talk together to understand these needs. We must share this knowledge among the team to align everyone with a common goal. Thus, communication is key to ensure we are all sailing to the same objective. At the end, everyone‚Äôs code is going to be merged into the same codebase. Pair-programming helps us meet before our code does.

There are orher practices with the same benefits: technical retrospectives, code reviews or mob-programming for example. You can combine them.

‚ÄúBut we don‚Äôt need pair-programming, we do code reviews.‚Äù

Let‚Äôs talk about the specificities of pair-programming then.

First, we get real-time feedback during pair-programming. We do have feedback during code reviews too, but it happens later ‚àí often when the feature is considered ‚Äúdone‚Äù. When we pair with a co-worker, we get instant review of the code we write. Actually, we are thinking together.

Then, as we think together, pair-programming is a better filter against bad ideas or laziness. This can be true for code reviews done correctly ‚àí which will hardly happen if the pull-request is big. This is even more true during mob programming.

When we code alone, we put both our best and worst decisions into the codebase.

When we code together, only the best decisions of the team make it through the filter of our combined point of views.

Finally, I think there is something that only happens during pair-programming: people share how they work, tips and tricks, in real-time.

We teach each other our own productivity tips ‚àí keyboard shortcuts, techniques‚Ä¶ We help each other grow in our day-to-day work. That‚Äôs how I learned some features of the tools I use and I didn‚Äôt know existed. That‚Äôs how I teach my teammates some habits worth trying to waste less time on daunting tasks.

Sharing is why we do pair-programming.

If you do pair-programming, don‚Äôt forget to keep it dynamic, switching roles frequently. And do take breaks: pair-programming requires a lot of attention and can be exhausting.

Now tell us, did you have had an ‚Äúaha‚Äù moment doing pair-programming?

item.title: Using observables in real life
item.description: In this post, I‚Äôll talk about a concrete use case in which Observables turn to be remarkably relevant to make our code cleaner and more maintainable.
item.content:encoded:
In this post, I‚Äôll talk about a concrete use case in which Observables turn to be remarkably relevant to make our code cleaner and more maintainable.

How to spot a barcode scanner?!

Yup! This is kind of a specific example. But it perfectly illustrates issues that would beg you for using Observables.

A barcode scanner simply emulates the keyboard. It reproduces the scanned code, emitting keypress signals, ending with the ‚ÄúEnter‚Äù key ‚àí which key code is 13.

Let‚Äôs say we‚Äôre developing an app that allows users to search products from their 16-chars code reference. Rather than typing them by hand, users should be able to use a barcode scanner to trigger the search.

‚ÄúJust let the user focus the search input, scan and you‚Äôre done!‚Äù

Sure, it‚Äôs native behavior.

But the search feature is contained inside a popup that can be open with a button. And we‚Äôve been told the app should be super-ergonomic! Whenever the user scans a barcode, we should open the popup and fill the input with the scanned code.

Now, the problem is: how do we differentiate a scanned code from other keypress events? Let‚Äôs say the user hit a key before scanning the code: we don‚Äôt want that key to be part of the scanned code!

Solving this, the imperative way

We surely need to listen to keypress events‚Ä¶ Then we must‚Ä¶ remember the key codes, probably using a buffer! If the key pressed is the ‚ÄúEnter‚Äù key, fill the input and clean the buffer. Otherwise, add the key to the buffer!

Let‚Äôs try this first shot:

const ENTER_KEY_CODE = 13
let keyCodesBuffer = []

document.addEventListener('keypress', event => {
  const keyCode = event.keyCode

  if (keyCode === ENTER_KEY_CODE) {
    fillInputWithKeyCodesBuffer()
    cleanBuffer()
  } else {
    addToBuffer(keyCode)
  }
})

function fillInputWithKeyCodesBuffer() {
  // ‚Ä¶
}

function cleanBuffer() {
  keyCodesBuffer = []
}

function addToBuffer(keyCode) {
  keyCodesBuffer.push(keyCode)
}

Good.

But this is not enough: it doesn‚Äôt differentiate scanned codes from regular keypresses!

We know that, if no new keypress is emitted after ~50ms, it‚Äôs not a scanned code for sure and we can clean the buffer.

const ENTER_KEY_CODE = 13
const MAX_INTERVAL_BETWEEN_EVENTS_IN_MS = 50
let keyCodesBuffer = []

document.addEventListener('keypress', event => {
  const keyCode = event.keyCode

  if (keyCode === ENTER_KEY_CODE) {
    fillInputWithKeyCodesBuffer()
    cleanBuffer()
  } else {
    addToBuffer(keyCode)
    cleanBufferAfter(MAX_INTERVAL_BETWEEN_EVENTS_IN_MS)
  }
})

function fillInputWithKeyCodesBuffer() {
  // ‚Ä¶
}

function cleanBuffer() {
  keyCodesBuffer = []
}

function addToBuffer(keyCode) {
  keyCodesBuffer.push(keyCode)
}

function cleanBufferAfter(timeout) {
  setTimeout(cleanBuffer, timeout)
}

Hmmm‚Ä¶ not bad. But there is a subtle bug here: if the code takes more than 50ms to be scanned, it will drop the beginning‚Ä¶

In fact, if a new keypress occurs within 50ms, we should clear the timeout.

const ENTER_KEY_CODE = 13
const MAX_INTERVAL_BETWEEN_EVENTS_IN_MS = 50
let keyCodesBuffer = []
let cleanBufferTimeout

document.addEventListener('keypress', event => {
  const keyCode = event.keyCode

  stopCleanBufferTimeout()
  if (keyCode === ENTER_KEY_CODE) {
    fillInputWithKeyCodesBuffer()
    cleanBuffer()
  } else {
    addToBuffer(keyCode)
    cleanBufferAfter(MAX_INTERVAL_BETWEEN_EVENTS_IN_MS)
  }
})

function fillInputWithKeyCodesBuffer() {
  // ‚Ä¶
}

function cleanBuffer() {
  keyCodesBuffer = []
}

function addToBuffer(keyCode) {
  keyCodesBuffer.push(keyCode)
}

function cleanBufferAfter(timeout) {
  cleanBufferTimeout = setTimeout(cleanBuffer, timeout)
}

function stopCleanBufferTimeout() {
  clearTimeout(cleanBufferTimeout)
}

Now we‚Äôve got something working.

Let‚Äôs take a step back and think: what if we‚Äôve had the full history of keypress events we could manipulate to filter out scanned codes sequences? Would the code be simpler? Let‚Äôs figure this out‚Ä¶

Solving this, with Observables

For this kind of use cases, I find Observables to be a powerful abstraction to represent our data.

Observables are immutable collections of asynchronous events you can manipulate through operators.

If we use things like map and filter over arrays, then we‚Äôre already familiar with that way of thinking.

If Observables are still cryptic for you so far, I‚Äôd suggest you to read this excellent introduction to Reactive Programming from Andr√© Staltz.

So, instead of responding to each event individually, let‚Äôs collect all events into a single stream that we can transform.

const keyCode$ = Rx.Observable.fromEvent(document, 'keypress')
  // ---(ev)--(ev)--------(ev)--->
  .pluck('keyCode')
// ---(43)--(51)--------(13)--->

The $ sign at the end of the variable name means ‚ÄúStream‚Äù. It‚Äôs a convention I use to know the variable I manipulate is an Observable in non-typed languages, just like I‚Äôd call elements an array of element, or $header the jQuery representation of the header.

Now we have a stream of key codes. Any time a keypress event occurs, a new event, which value is the corresponding key code, is emitted.

At the end of the process, we‚Äôd like to have a stream we can subscribe to. Each event of the stream should represent the scanned code. So we need to make batches of key codes in a way that isolates scanned codes from parasitic keypresses.

To do so, we can buffer our stream using a debounce strategy: when an event occurs, wait 50ms for another one. If another event is emitted within this time frame, wait another 50ms. If no other event occurs within this time frame, make a batch of the passed events.

This is what we want to achieve with the buffer operator

const MAX_INTERVAL_BETWEEN_EVENTS_IN_MS = 50

const keyCode$ = Rx.Observable.fromEvent(document, 'keypress').pluck('keyCode')

const keyCodesBuffer$ = keyCode$
  // --(43)-(64)----(32)-----(65)-(77)-(13)--->
  .buffer(keyCode$.debounce(MAX_INTERVAL_BETWEEN_EVENTS_IN_MS))
// --([43,64])----([32])-----([65,77,13])--->

So far, so good!

Now, all we have to do is to filter out batches that don‚Äôt look like scanned codes. And we know that a scanned code is a sequence that ends with the ‚ÄúEnter‚Äù key.

const ENTER_KEY_CODE = 13
const MAX_INTERVAL_BETWEEN_EVENTS_IN_MS = 50

const keyCode$ = Rx.Observable.fromEvent(document, 'keypress').pluck('keyCode')

const keyCodesBuffer$ = keyCode$
  .buffer(keyCode$.debounce(MAX_INTERVAL_BETWEEN_EVENTS_IN_MS))
  .filter(isFromScan)

function isFromScan(keyCodes) {
  return keyCodes.length > 1 && keyCodes[keyCodes.length - 1] === ENTER_KEY_CODE
}

Finally, let‚Äôs subscribe to this stream we have created and execute our callback each time a new event is emitted.

Nothing will happen until we subscribe to the Observable, since they are lazy.

const ENTER_KEY_CODE = 13
const MAX_INTERVAL_BETWEEN_EVENTS_IN_MS = 50

const keyCode$ = Rx.Observable.fromEvent(document, 'keypress').pluck('keyCode')

const keyCodesBuffer$ = keyCode$
  .buffer(keyCode$.debounce(MAX_INTERVAL_BETWEEN_EVENTS_IN_MS))
  .filter(isFromScan)

function isFromScan(keyCodes) {
  return keyCodes.length > 1 && keyCodes[keyCodes.length - 1] === ENTER_KEY_CODE
}

function fillInputWith(keyCodes) {
  // ‚Ä¶
}

keyCodesBuffer$.subscribe(fillInputWith)

What we did here

This is a visual illustration of what we did to go from keyCode$ ‚àí which was created from keypress events ‚àí to keyCodesBuffer$ we subscribed to:

There are a few things to notice with our final code:

  • we don‚Äôt have to manage things like timeout and buffer manually
  • hence, code is shorter, focused on the actual work
  • fillInputWith() doesn‚Äôt rely on a global buffer, which is more testable and reusable ‚àí actually, we are few small steps from making the whole logic purely functional
  • we just manipulate consts, nothing is reassigned, which is simpler to reason about
  • created Streams can be reused to do other things ; we can add features without fear of breaking this one
  • we could easily fix issues in this code, injecting operators into streams creation pipes, if necessary ‚àí e.g. we‚Äôd probably filter out non-interesting key codes from keyCode$ as simply as .filter(isValidKeyCode)

In my opinion, the one difficult thing is to reason with streams and understand how to solve our use case with given operators.

But, I believe this is something that just takes practice üòâ

item.title: Implementing a download button with Cycle.js
item.description: A concrete example of programming with Cycle.js & Rx.js.
item.content:encoded:
Programming with Cycle.js / Rx.js needs you to take another approach to the code. We have to switch your brain to think with a different paradigm ‚àí functional and reactive, instead of imperative and passive.

Unfortunately, there is a lack of concrete example, from concrete features, from real-life application.

Since I‚Äôm building a tool to analyse Kanban metrics from a Trello board with Cycle.js, I do have concrete examples.

Here‚Äôs one use case I want to share with you to illustrate how you deal with the user clicking a button to perform an action when everything is a stream.

The feature

Cumulative Flow Diagram (CFD) is a cool metric to help you understand what‚Äôs going on with our Kanban flow. In TKAT, data are taken from the Trello API, consolidated then parsed to produce it.

However, this metric is contained in the entrails of the web app. This is not convenient if we want to re-use or share these information in any way (e.g., to build a global report for external stakeholders).

What if the data was parsed and we can download a .csv? That would be awesome.

Building awesomeness, one stream at a time

From a user point of view, we would like to have a ‚ÄúDownload‚Äù button somewhere close to the graph‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääprobably just below. Clicking on this button will download the .csv of the current graph.

If we change the period/selected lists range and then click on the download button, it should keep matching the displayed graph. We should be able to draw that graph again after we import our data into Excel/GSheet.

In other words: each time a click on the button happens, download in CSV format the latest data.

Let‚Äôs interpret this in Cycle.js terms:

  • ‚Äúeach time ‚Ä¶‚Äù: subscribe to the following stream
  • ‚Äú‚Ä¶ a click on the button happens, ‚Ä¶‚Äù: downloadClicks$, a stream representing button clicks
  • ‚Äú‚Ä¶ download in CSV format ‚Ä¶‚Äù: a side-effect, performed by a dedicated ExportToCSV driver
  • ‚Äú‚Ä¶ the latest data.‚Äù: csvData$, a stream representing data

There is already a stream containing CFD data since we display them already. We simply need to map them to produce a csvData$ that matches the input format of ExportToCSV driver.

Then, we need to combine our streams to get the latest value from csvData$whenever‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand only when‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääan item is emitted in downloadClicks$.

Brace yourself, there is a Rx.js operator for that: withLatestFrom().

This is what we want to achieve:

downloadClicks$:  -------x------x----------------x---------->
       csvData$:  ---A---------------B----C--D-------E------>

                     withLatestFrom((clicks, data) => data)

  downloadData$:  -------A------A----------------D---------->

Combining our streams will produce another one (downloadData$) that will emit an item containing CSV-formatted data whenever a click happens on the button.

What about the download?

Downloading a CSV file from formatted data, this looks like a job for a driver!

Indeed, this kind of operations implies side-effects since the program needs to output something that is visible to the user. This is the part where our application unleash its added value. This is also the part where nasty bugs might lie, regarding the environment, the global state of the machine, etc.

That‚Äôs why we prefer to move this part into a dedicated driver, away from our application logic.

Our app is pure dataflow while downloading a CSV file is part of side effects stuff.

Note: I didn‚Äôt find an open-sourced ‚ÄúdownloadToCsv‚Äù driver at the time of implementing the feature, so I build my own for this project. With a very little refactoring, it can easily be open-sourced though.

import R from 'ramda'

// Export a driver to be used in our Cycle.js app.
// It takes an `input$` stream that contains `data` to be download.
function exportToCSVDriver(input$) {
  // `data` should be formatted as an Array of Arrays (= lines of CSV).
  // -> `[["name1", "city1", "other info"], ["name2", "city2", "more info"]]`
  input$.subscribe(data => {
    // Parse data to create a CSV file.
    // See: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14964035/how-to-export-javascript-array-info-to-csv-on-client-side
    let csvContent = 'data:text/csv;charset=utf-8,'
    data.forEach((infoArray, index) => {
      const dataString = infoArray.join(',')
      csvContent += index < data.length ? `${dataString}\n` : dataString
    })

    // Create a link in the page to trigger the download.
    const link = document.createElement('a')
    link.setAttribute('href', encodeURI(csvContent))

    // Name the CSV file based on data attributes.
    // Implementation is based on TKAT specificities (https://github.com/nicoespeon/trello-kanban-analysis-tool).
    // This part can be refactor to open-source the driver.
    const head = R.head(data)
    link.setAttribute('download', `cfd-from-${head[1]}-to-${R.last(head)}.csv`)

    // Required for Firefox.
    document.body.appendChild(link)

    // Download the data file.
    link.click()
  })
}

export { exportToCSVDriver }

The driver subscribe to an observable (= stream) input.

Anytime it emits an event containing formatted data, it will perform the side-effect: download the CSV file from these data. Thus, we would simply pass our downloadData$ stream and we‚Äôre done!

And here it is, our ‚ÄúDownload .csv‚Äù button, waiting for users to click it!

Here is the PR that implemented the feature, in case you want to read the concrete diff.

What are your feelings about this approach? Would you have done it differently? I‚Äôd love to discuss about it!
