      },
    ],
  })
}

Prompts

The prompts part is delegated to Inquirer.js.

You can just refer to their documentation to learn whatever you can do ‚Äî questions types, output filter, input validation‚Ä¶

You can imagine doing some not trivial stuff:

import { trimRight, isEmpty } from 'lodash'

const ensurePlural = text => trimRight(text, 's') + 's'

const isNotEmptyFor = name => {
  return value => {
    if (isEmpty(value)) return name + ' is required'
    return true
  }
}

module.exports = plop => {
  plop.setGenerator('module', {
    // ‚Ä¶

    prompts: [
      {
        type: 'input',
        name: 'name',
        message: 'What is your module name?',
        validate: isNotEmptyFor('name'),
        filter: ensurePlural,
      },
    ],

    // ‚Ä¶
  })
}

validate will ensure the given module name is not empty.

filter allow you to standardize the output: here module names should end with an s by convention. Even if I do it wrong and give calendar as the module name, I can be sure the name variable will be calendars.

Actions

Now it knows everything it needs, plop will run every actions you configured. It can use every variables that inquirer did transmit.

Actions, just like templates, are parsed with Handlebars. If you understand how it works, you know how to use plop.

Therefore {{name}} is the answer given to the prompt, validated and filtered previously. You can drop it wherever needed, in the created file path and/or its template.

There are 2 types of actions that are supported yet:

  • "add" that will create a new file into the given path ‚Äî which is relative to plopfile.js
  • "modify" that will modify the file located at given path. It will replace the RegExp you provided in pattern with the template you provide

Both actions can either use an inlined template via template, or retrieve it from the path you set via templateFile.

A concrete example

Let‚Äôs imagine that kind of implementation:

const modulePath = 'app/modules/{{camelCase name}}.js'

module.exports = plop => {
  plop.setGenerator('model', {
    // ‚Ä¶

    actions: [
      // Add a new model + tests boilerplate.
      {
        type: 'add',
        path: 'app/modules/{{camelCase name}}.model.js',
        templateFile: 'plop-templates/model.js',
      },
      {
        type: 'add',
        path: 'app/tests/{{camelCase name}}.model.tests.js',
        templateFile: 'plop-templates/model.tests.js',
      },

      // Modify the module file to inject created model.
      // This is basically RegExp replacement.
      {
        type: 'modify',
        path: modulePath,
        pattern: /(\/\/ IMPORT MODULE FILES)/g,
        template: '$1\nimport Model from "./{{camelCase name}}.model";',
      },
      {
        type: 'modify',
        path: modulePath,
        pattern: /(const namespace = "\w+";)/g,
        template: '$1\n\nModel = Model.extend( { namespace: namespace } );',
      },
    ],
  })
}

Then, let‚Äôs say you have the plop-templates/model.js template:

/**
 * TODO - Describe what your model does.
 *
 * @class {{pascalCase name}}.Model
 * @module {{pascalCase name}}
 * @constructor
 */
import { Model } from 'backbone'

export default Model.extend({
  initialize() {
    // Executed on model initialization
  },
})

Considering {{name}} is calendars, then plop will create the following app/modules/calendars.model.js file:

/**
 * TODO - Describe what your model does.
 *
 * @class Calendars.Model
 * @module Calendars
 * @constructor
 */
import { Model } from 'backbone'

export default Model.extend({
  initialize() {
    // Executed on model initialization
  },
})

And will also transform your current app/modules/calendars.js module file:

import Module from 'core/module'
import _ from 'lodash'

// IMPORT MODULE FILES

const namespace = 'calendars'

export default Module.extend({
  initialize() {
    _.defaults(this.options, { isDisplayed: true })
  },

  onStart() {
    this.ready()
  },

  onReady() {
    // Do something when module is considered as ready
  },
})

To insert the reference to the created model:

import Module from 'core/module'
import _ from 'lodash'

// IMPORT MODULE FILES
import Model from './calendars.model'

const namespace = 'calendars'

Model = Model.extend({ namespace: namespace })

export default Module.extend({
  initialize() {
    _.defaults(this.options, { isDisplayed: true })
  },

  onStart() {
    this.ready()
  },

  onReady() {
    // Do something when module is considered as ready
  },
})

With "add" and "modify" you can ease a lot of small repetitive things.

Adapt actions to given answers

You can pass a function to actions. This function will take user‚Äôs answers as a parameter and should return the array of actions to take.

This way you can adapt actions to given answers.

Let‚Äôs consider this example of new module creation:

module.exports = plop => {
  plop.setGenerator('module', {
    prompts: [
      {
        type: 'input',
        name: 'name',
        message: 'What is the name of your module?',
        validate: isNotEmptyFor('name'),
        filter: ensurePlural,
      },
      {
        type: 'list',
        name: 'dataConfig',
        message: 'Tell me about the data, what do you need?',
        default: 'none',
        choices: [
          { name: 'Nothing', value: 'none' },
          { name: 'A Model', value: 'model' },
        ],
      },
    ],

    actions: data => {
      // Add a new module, whatever happens.
      let actions = [
        {
          type: 'add',
          path: 'app/modules/{{camelCase name}}/{{camelCase name}}.js',
          templateFile: 'plop-templates/module.js',
        },
        {
          type: 'add',
          path:
            'app/modules/{{camelCase name}}/tests/{{camelCase name}}.tests.js',
          templateFile: 'plop-templates/module.tests.js',
        },
      ]

      // If you wish a Model, then we add a Model.
      if (data.dataConfig === 'model') {
        actions = actions.concat([
          {
            type: 'add',
            path: 'app/modules/{{camelCase name}}.model.js',
            templateFile: 'plop-templates/model.js',
          },
          {
            type: 'add',
            path: 'app/tests/{{camelCase name}}.model.tests.js',
            templateFile: 'plop-templates/model.tests.js',
          },
        ])
      }

      // Return the array of actions to take.
      return actions
    },
  })
}

Your generator can adapt to many different scenarios (e.g: a module with a Model, a Collection + Model, with a CollectionView or a CompositeView‚Ä¶).

Helpers

A little note about templating helpers of plop: these are those from Handlebars.

You starts with a bunch of helpers plop gives you. camelCase, for instance, just works this way: {{camelCase name}} with name = "my awesome module" gives "myAwesomeModule".

You can define your own helpers within plopfile.js with addHelper :

module.exports = plop => {
  plop.addHelper('upperCase', text => text.toUpperCase())

  // ‚Ä¶
}

We just created an upperCase helper we could use later in the actions and templates: {{upperCase name}}.

Just use it

There you go, just type npm run plop ‚Äî or simply plop, if you made it global ‚Äî then follow the guide.

You can also directly call a specific generator with npm run plop [generatorName].

Plop is fast and efficient to use, just like Yeoman. However, it‚Äôs far more lightweight and easier to maintain.

My experience feedback in production

As of the time of writing, I use plop with my team on the Vinoga project. Its features perfectly match our use cases.

I did wrote a Yeoman generator for the project before. It was concretely unused by the team.

Definitely, plop is the kind of tool that saves you 10 minutes here and there, every single day. And running plop module in your console, how cool is that \o/

item.title: Testing Marionette.js Behaviors
item.description: How to unit test your Marionette.js Behaviors with ease.
item.content:encoded:
Context

This is a talk I gave on November 10th, 2015 at meetup Backbone.js Paris S02E01.

Video (FR)

Slides

Concretely

Problems

When you want to test your Behavior, the first problem that generally comes up is:

Damn, how to I instantiate my Behavior so I can test its API?

In fact, the Behavior API are not that much public methods you declared inside. These never are directly called:

const Alert = Marionette.Behavior.extend({
  defaults: {
    title: 'Alert!',
    message: 'Not really urgent',
  },

  events: {
    click: 'emitAlert',
  },

  emitAlert() {
    alert(this.options.message)
  },
})
it('should emit an alert', () => {
  // => This won't work
  expect(Behavior.emitAlert()).toEmitAnAlert()
})

A Behavior reacts to events ‚Äî DOM interactions, trigger from the view, etc.

If you want to test a Behavior you then have to trigger these events then observe the Behavior‚Äôs impacts on the system to check if it reacted appropriately. Behaviors work with side effects, this is what you need to test.

A Behavior is declared and instantiated within the context of a view:

const ShareView = Marionette.ItemView.extend({
  template: '#card',

  behaviors: {
    AlertOnShare: {
      behaviorClass: AlertBehavior,
      title: 'Shared',
      message: 'Your message has been shared!',
    },
  },
})

To test a Behavior, you then need to instantiate a view in which the Behavior is declared.

OK! Then I‚Äôll mock a view with my Behavior declared so I can test it.

describe('Alert Behavior', () => {
  let view

  beforeEach(() => {
    view = Marionette.ItemView.extend({
      template: _.template(''),

      behaviors: {
        Alert: {
          behaviorClass: AlertBehavior,
          title: 'Title',
          message: 'My message.',
        },
      },
    })
  })

  // ‚Ä¶
})

This is an option.

However, you won‚Äôt have the Behavior actually behave within the context of your application‚Äôs views. This is not necessarily wrong since we‚Äôre talking about unit tests here. But that requires a lot of ceremony to mock whatever should be:

  • mock a view with default parameters
  • mock a view with configured parameters
  • mock whatever should be tested ‚Äî template, events, triggers‚Ä¶

Another solution would be to test the instantiated Behavior within each view of our applicaation, directly in these views tests actually.

OK! So I‚Äôll test the Behavior within each of my views‚Ä¶ But well‚Ä¶ what about duplication?!

Yep, if you go testing how your Behaviors behave for every view‚Äôs context, you will duplicate tests. That would be a pitty for something which is supposed to isolate views behaviors so you don‚Äôt duplicate code.

What can we do then?

GitHub repo to illustrate the proposed solution

The idea is to refactor Behavior‚Äôs tests into a function that will take context as a param.

function addOnClickTests(context) {
  let model, view

  beforeEach(() => {
    model = new context.ModelClass()
    view = new context.ViewClass({ model: model })
  })

  it('should increase the model size by 1 when we click on the view', () => {
    model.set('size', 1)

    view.$el.trigger('click')

    expect(model.get('size')).toBe(2)
  })
}

This factory embeds tests of your Behavior and run them within a specific context.

This allows you to instantiate tests with the context of your view, providing correct parameters:

describe('Like View', () => {
  const View = LikeView.extend({ template: _.template('') })

  describe('AddOnClick Behavior', () => {
    addOnClickTests({ ViewClass: View, ModelClass: LikeModel })
  })
})

Sure, but what you‚Äôre doing here is testing default parameters of the Behavior: ¬´‚ÄØincrease the model size by 1‚ÄØ¬ª. How to test specific parameters? Should we pass them through the context? If so, that‚Äôs just duplication again. We‚Äôd better completely mock the view at the end.

That‚Äôs exactly why Marionette is publicly exposing the array of instantiated Behaviors of a view in its _behaviors attribute since v2.2.0.

The trick is to be able to retrieve your Behavior instance in the view context so you can adapt tests regarding parameters that it actually uses.

I specify an id to my Behaviors for that, so I can retrieve them easily:

const OnClick = Marionette.Behavior.extend({
  id: 'addOnClick',

  defaults: {
    propertyToIncrease: 'size',
    increaseStep: 1,
  },

  events: {
    click: 'add',
  },

  add() {
    // increase `propertyToIncrease` by `increaseStep`
  },
})
function addOnClickTests(context) {
  let model, view, behavior, options

  beforeEach(() => {
    model = new context.ModelClass()
    view = new context.ViewClass({ model: model })

    // Retrieve instantiated behavior and its actual options under this context.
    behavior = _.findWhere(view._behaviors, { id: 'addOnClick' })
    options = behavior.options

    model.set(options.propertyToIncrease, 1)
  })

  it('should be instantiated', () => {
    expect(behavior).not.toBeUndefined()
  })

  it('should increase the model value when we click on the view', () => {
    var expectedValue =
      model.get(options.propertyToIncrease) + options.increaseStep

    view.$el.trigger('click')

    expect(model.get(options.propertyToIncrease)).toBe(expectedValue)
  })
}

To sum it up

  • test the API of your Behavior = its impact on the system, reacting to some events
  • describe your Behavior tests in a factory that takes a context as a parameter
  • embed your tests in each of your views tests, using the according context
  • use this.view._behaviors to retrieve your Behavior ‚Äî you can use an id for that ‚Äî and its actual paremeters within the context of the view

item.title: Tester ses Behaviors Marionette.js
item.description: Comment tester unitairement, et simplement, ses Behaviors Marionette.js.
item.content:encoded:
Contexte

Ceci est un talk que j‚Äôai pr√©sent√© le 10 novembre 2015 au meetup Backbone.js Paris S02E01.

Vid√©o

Slides

Concr√®tement

Les probl√©matiques

Lorsqu‚Äôon se dit qu‚Äôon va tester notre Behavior, la premi√®re probl√©matique que l‚Äôon rencontre est g√©n√©ralement la suivante¬†:

Mince, comment je fais pour instancier ma Behavior pour pouvoir tester son API¬†?

En fait, l‚ÄôAPI d‚Äôune Behavior ce ne sont pas particuli√®rement les m√©thodes publiques qu‚Äôon y d√©clare. Celles-ci ne seront jamais appell√©es directement¬†:

const Alert = Marionette.Behavior.extend({
  defaults: {
    title: 'Alert!',
    message: 'Not really urgent',
  },

  events: {
    click: 'emitAlert',
  },

  emitAlert() {
    alert(this.options.message)
  },
})
it('should emit an alert', () => {
  // => This won't work
  expect(Behavior.emitAlert()).toEmitAnAlert()
})

Une Behavior r√©agit √† des √©v√©nements (interactions DOM, trigger de la vue, etc.).

Pour tester une Behavior, il faut donc d√©clencher ces √©v√©nements puis observer l‚Äôimpact de la Behavior sur le syst√®me pour voir si celle-ci a r√©agit correctement. Les Behaviors fonctionnant par effets de bord, c‚Äôest bel et bien ce qu‚Äôil faut tester.

Une Behavior est d√©clar√©e et instanci√©e dans le contexte d‚Äôune vue¬†:

const ShareView = Marionette.ItemView.extend({
  template: '#card',

  behaviors: {
    AlertOnShare: {
      behaviorClass: AlertBehavior,
      title: 'Shared',
      message: 'Your message has been shared!',
    },
  },
})

Pour tester une Behavior, il faut donc commencer par instancier une vue dans laquelle celle-ci est d√©clar√©e.

OK¬†! Donc je vais mock une vue en y d√©clarant ma Behavior pour pouvoir la tester.

describe('Alert Behavior', () => {
  let view

  beforeEach(() => {
    view = Marionette.ItemView.extend({
      template: _.template(''),

      behaviors: {
        Alert: {
          behaviorClass: AlertBehavior,
          title: 'Title',
          message: 'My message.',
        },
      },
    })
  })

  // ‚Ä¶
})

C‚Äôest une possibilit√©.

Cependant, je n‚Äôai pas vraiment le comportement de la Behavior dans le contexte des vues de mon application. Ce n‚Äôest pas n√©cessairement grave puisque nous parlons de tests unitaires. Simplement, cela demande beaucoup de c√©r√©monie pour mock tout ce qu‚Äôil faut¬†:

  • mock une vue avec les param√®tres par d√©faut
  • mock une vue avec des param√®tres configur√©s
  • mock tout ce qui doit √™tre test√© (template, events, triggers‚Ä¶)

Une autre solution consiste √† tester la Behavior instanci√©e dans chacunes des vues de notre application, directement dans les tests de celles-ci en fait.

OK¬†! Je vais tester la Behavior dans chacune de mes vues‚Ä¶ Mais, mais‚Ä¶ Et la duplication¬†?!

Effectivement, si on commence par tester le comportement de nos Behaviors dans le contexte de chacune de nos vues, on se retrouve √† dupliquer les tests. Sachant que le principe de la Behavior c‚Äôest d‚Äôisoler un ensemble de comportements de vue pour ne pas avoir √† le dupliquer, c‚Äôest un peu dommage de perdre √ßa c√¥t√© tests.

Comment on s‚Äôen sort¬†?

D√©p√¥t GitHub pour illustrer la solution propos√©e

L‚Äôid√©e consiste √† refactor les tests d‚Äôune Behavior dans une fonction qui prend un context en param√®tre.

function addOnClickTests(context) {
  let model, view

  beforeEach(() => {
    model = new context.ModelClass()
    view = new context.ViewClass({ model: model })
  })

  it('should increase the model size by 1 when we click on the view', () => {
    model.set('size', 1)

    view.$el.trigger('click')

    expect(model.get('size')).toBe(2)
  })
}

Cette factory embarque les tests de la Behavior et les d√©roule dans un contexte particulier.

Ceci nous permet de l‚Äôinstancier dans le contexte de notre vue, avec les param√®tres qui vont bien¬†:

describe('Like View', () => {
  const View = LikeView.extend({ template: _.template('') })

  describe('AddOnClick Behavior', () => {
    addOnClickTests({ ViewClass: View, ModelClass: LikeModel })
  })
})

Oui, mais ici tu testes les param√®tres par d√©faut de la Behavior¬†: ¬´‚ÄØincrease the model size by 1‚ÄØ¬ª. Comment tester des param√®tres en particulier¬†? On les passe dans le contexte¬†? Du coup, on fait √† nouveau de la duplication, autant mock la vue compl√®tement.

C‚Äôest effectivement la raison pour laquelle Marionette expose publiquement un tableau des Behaviors instanci√©es d‚Äôune vue dans son attribut _behaviors depuis la v2.2.0.

L‚Äôastuce consiste donc √† retrouver l‚Äôinstance de la Behavior dans le contexte de la vue afin de pouvoir variabiliser les tests en fonction des param√®tres avec lesquels la Behavior a √©t√© instanci√©e.

Pour cela, je d√©clare un id √† mes Behaviors afin de pouvoir les retrouver facilement¬†:

const OnClick = Marionette.Behavior.extend({
  id: 'addOnClick',

  defaults: {
    propertyToIncrease: 'size',
    increaseStep: 1,
  },

  events: {
    click: 'add',
  },

  add() {
    // increase `propertyToIncrease` by `increaseStep`
  },
})
function addOnClickTests(context) {
  let model, view, behavior, options

  beforeEach(() => {
    model = new context.ModelClass()
    view = new context.ViewClass({ model: model })

    // Retrieve instantiated behavior and its actual options under this context.
    behavior = _.findWhere(view._behaviors, { id: 'addOnClick' })
    options = behavior.options

    model.set(options.propertyToIncrease, 1)
  })

  it('should be instantiated', () => {
    expect(behavior).not.toBeUndefined()
  })

  it('should increase the model value when we click on the view', () => {
    var expectedValue =
      model.get(options.propertyToIncrease) + options.increaseStep

    view.$el.trigger('click')

    expect(model.get(options.propertyToIncrease)).toBe(expectedValue)
  })
}

Pour r√©sumer

  • on teste l‚ÄôAPI de la Behavior = son impact sur le syst√®me en r√©action √† des √©v√©nements
  • on d√©crit nos tests de Behavior dans une factory qui prend un contexte en param√®tre
  • on embarque nos tests dans chacune de nos vues en y passant le bon contexte
  • on utilise this.view._behaviors pour retrouver la Behavior (avec un id par exemple) et ses param√®tres d‚Äôinstanciation dans le contexte de la vue

item.title: Functions chaining and composition with lodash¬†/¬†underscore
item.description: Function chaining and composition techniques to build efficient pipelines, why and how-to.
item.content:encoded:
Context

This is a talk I gave last June 23rd, 2015 at meetup Backbone.js Paris S01E07.

Slides

item.title: Chaining et composition de fonctions avec lodash¬†/¬†underscore
item.description: Techniques de chaining et composition de fonctions pour cr√©er des pipelines efficaces, le pourquoi du comment.
item.content:encoded:
Contexte

Ceci est un talk que j‚Äôai pr√©sent√© le 23 juin 2015 au meetup Backbone.js Paris S01E07.

Slides

item.title: Inheritance, composition and Backbone.js
item.description: Why objects composition is preferable to inheritance in JavaScript? Most of all, how do you apply this technique with Backbone.js?
item.content:encoded:
‚ÄúFavor objects composition over inheritance‚Äù

When you‚Äôre doing Object Oriented Programmation (OOP), you create a bunch of objects with their data structure and methods that compose their interface. You decide how to split your objects based on the Single Responsibility Principle (SRP): each object should have one and only one reason to change.

To make interesting stuff happen, you need to combine those objects.

Roughly, there are 2 types of relationships in an object model: inheritance and composition.

You can do the analogy with a family tree:

  • inheritance is like a birth: when it happens, this is for life.
  • composition is like a marriage: it happens during the participating objects‚Äô lifetimes, and it can change. Objects can discard partners and get new partners to collaborate with. Please note that objects are surely not monogams.

Source: Object Design - Roles, Responsibilities and Collaborations

‚ÄúInheritance‚Äù all the things!

The very first thing JavaScript developers do is trying to mimic rules of pseudo-classical inheritance.

They usually quickly come up with a lot of new everywhere and inheritance chains awfully long. That generally produce something very hard to maintain.

That‚Äôs true you‚Äôve got everything you need to do inheritance with classes, interfaces, ‚Ä¶ in Java.

This is not JavaScript.

Keep It Simple, Seriously

The base rule in JavaScript is prototypal inheritance.

Forget about the technical jargon, just remember you have objects that can link to other objects (OLOO).

Thus, it‚Äôs way simpler to encapsulate methods from a same logic into an object, then simply return this object. If you need to, you can also create a function that will return an object ‚Äî which is what we call a factory.

Then you‚Äôll take this object, eventually compose it with others, to build the prototype which you‚Äôll use to instantiate your class. That simple.

To sum it up: instead of creating huge, poorly built, inheritance chains from constructors, simply create your objects and compose them to create a prototype you will instantiate your class with.

¬†Concatenative inheritance

Someone notified me that what I‚Äôm talking about here is called multiple inheritance, not actual object composition.

When you do object composition, you make attributes point to instances of other classes.

There is no multiple inheritance in JavaScript. Still, composing different prototypes to produce a totally new one is a very close notion, which can be confusing. Here we are talking about ‚Äúcomposing prototypes‚Äù, but not in the terms of objects composition‚Ä¶

There you‚Äôll find a more concrete explanation: Composition, Inheritance, and Aggregation in JavaScript

So, let‚Äôs call that concatenative inheritance, as detailed by Eric Eliott.

With a concrete example

Context

For quite some time I‚Äôve been working full-time on Vinoga, a social-farming game about wine, developed in HTML5.

Among few libraries, we use Backbone.js to decouple our views from our data with ease.

Let‚Äôs take a concrete use case: elements on the map.

If we take a few time to think about it, there are actually 2 types of elements:

  1. Props that are decorations elements ‚Äî trees, rocks, paths‚Ä¶
  2. Buildings that are buildings of the game ‚Äî winery, castle‚Ä¶

There is, among others, one difference we can notice from now: Buildings can be constructed ‚Äî from the build menu ‚Äî, not Props since they already are on the map.

Whatever, all these elements share a common behavior: they are on the map. Hence, Props and Buildings both inherit from Objects, which describes the behavior of an ‚Äúobject‚Äù on the map.

But there also are different types of Buildings, such as:

  • Markets that are buildings that will reflect the state of the player‚Äôs store
  • Productions buildings, that will transform resources ‚Äî grape, juice ‚Äî into another product ‚Äî juice, bottle.

About constructability

After we discussed with the Game Designer, we realized that Markets are not constructable: they already are on the map.

Constructability is a behavior that were part of the Buildings one until now. But yep, let‚Äôs handle that with a little modification of the inheritance chain:

Here comes the drama

As time goes, specs evolve and features too: brace yourself, Decorations are coming!

Decorations are decorations elements ‚Äî actually, Props ‚Äî except that they are constructables too!

Well, now we‚Äôre a bit stucked since ConstructableBuildings inherits from Buildings. We‚Äôd like not to duplicate ConstructableBuildings to recode roughly the same thing into Props.

Looks like we‚Äôll end up with classes that inherit of useless properties at the very best.

Why so pseudo-classical?

Well, how did we get there? How to get out of here?

Actually, we were a bit in the hurry when the constructability question appears. Without any more reflexion we came with the logic that ‚ÄùProductions IS a ConstructableBuildings that IS a Buildings that IS an Objects‚Äù. Kaboom, inheritance!

In fact, if we look closer, we could infer that constructability is a behavior. You can not say that there is no Constructable element without Building. This is a subtle error that is so frequent in JavaScript because of pseudo-classical inheritance since this is the only thing you remember: this is the very first ‚Äî bad ‚Äî instinct.

In our case, the only legitimate inheritance chain may be the one that bounds Decorations to Props. Anyway, I still think that you can get rid of it too.

What you actually put into Objects is a bunch of behaviors that are shared between Props and Buildings. But technically, Objects doesn‚Äôt represent anything concrete: this would be an abstract class if we were coding in Java. Just like Buildings by the way.

Embrace composition

In JavaScript, may I suggest another way: let‚Äôs describe each behavior into its own object. Let‚Äôs get rid of constructors and inheritance chains.

Then, combine these objects to make the prototype of objects we want to build. No class around, simply objects that are composed from other objects. Eventually factories to construct the correct object regarding your needs.

Here we just augment our prototype with other objects that describe behaviors. That‚Äôs what mixin is about.

If your object inherits from another, then prefer to use prototypal inheritance.

What about Backbone?

Backbone.extend

When you use Backbone, you use .extend() to override Backbone.[Model|Collection|View|‚Ä¶]. Then you instantiate it with new.

Thus, it‚Äôs very frequent to follow the pseudo-classical inheritance reflex and to end up with:

var ObjectsModel = Backbone.Model.extend( ‚Ä¶ );
var BuildingsModel = ObjectsModel.extend( ‚Ä¶ );
var MarketsModel = BuildingsModel.extend( ‚Ä¶ );

Which, by the way, would be the same than:

var MarketsModel = Backbone.Model.extend(‚Ä¶).extend(‚Ä¶).extend(‚Ä¶);

// Then you instantiate when needed
var marketsModel = new MarketsModel();

Backbone is built like that. .extend() easily lead us to that slippery slope where Models depend on the others in many not-that-subtle ways.

Compose your prototype THEN extend

Even though you need to inherit from Backbone, you can at least limit the damages. Even though .extend() exists, you don‚Äôt have to use it for every single object you create. The only object we really need to .extend() here is Backbone.Model.

The main idea is to compose objects to make to prototype you will then use into the .extend() of your Model / Collection / View‚Ä¶

var objectsModelProto = {
  /* ‚Ä¶ */
}
var buildingsModelProto = {
  /* ‚Ä¶ */
}
var constructablesModelProto = {
  /* ‚Ä¶ */
}

// We compose to make a new prototype.
var marketsModelProto = _.assign(
  {
    /* ‚Ä¶ */
  }, // -> specific interface for markets
  objectsModelProto, //
  buildingsModelProto, // => our mixins
  constructablesModelProto, //
  {
    /* ‚Ä¶ */
  } // -> to override mixins, if needed
)

// Once prototype is created, inherit from Backbone.
var MarketsModel = Backbone.Model.extend(marketsModelProto)

// Then you instantiate.
var marketsModel = new MarketsModel()

You can see how objectsModelProto, buildingsModelProto and constructablesModelProto override the base prototype of marketsModelProto to add specific behaviors.

Merge or assign

Please note that might be useful to use _.merge instead of _.assign if you need to merge attributes deeply. This may be handy with Backbone when you need to merge things like events:

var objectsViewProto = {
  events: {
    'click .store': 'store',
    'click .turn': 'turn',
  },

  store: function store() {
    /* ‚Ä¶ */
  },
  turn: function turn() {
    /* ‚Ä¶ */
  },
}

_.assign(
  {
    displayModal: function displayModal() {
      /* ‚Ä¶ */
    },
    select: function select() {
      /* ‚Ä¶ */
    },
  },
  objectsViewProto,
  {
    events: {
      click: 'select',
      'click .turn': 'displayModal',
    },
  }
)
// ->
// {
//   events: {
//     "click": "select",
//     "click .turn": "displayModal"
//   },
//
//   displayModal: function displayModal () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ },
//   select: function select () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ },
//   store: function store () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ },
//   turn: function turn () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ }
// }

_.merge(
  {
    displayModal: function displayModal() {
      /* ‚Ä¶ */
    },
    select: function select() {
      /* ‚Ä¶ */
    },
  },
  objectsViewProto,
  {
    events: {
      click: 'select',
      'click .turn': 'displayModal',
    },
  }
)
// ->
// {
//   events: {
//     "click": "select",
//     "click .store": "store",
//     "click .turn": "displayModal"
//   },
//
//   displayModal: function displayModal () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ },
//   select: function select () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ },
//   store: function store () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ },
//   turn: function turn () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ }
// }

In conclusion

Favor objects composition over inheritance. Don‚Äôt use inheritance if it doesn‚Äôt really make sense, or is required. Beware overlong inheritance chains: that‚Äôs damn fragile.

What is preferable to avoid:

// markets.model.js
var MarketsModel = ConstructablesModel.extend({
  /* ‚Ä¶ */
})

// main.js
var marketsModel = new MarketsModel()

Far more flexible, simpler:

// markets.model.js
var marketsModelProto = _.assign(
  {
    /* ‚Ä¶ */
  }, // -> specific interface of markets
  objectsModelProto,
  buildingsModelProto,
  constructablesModelProto
)

// main.js
var MarketsModel = Backbone.Model.extend(marketsModelProto)
var marketsModel = new MarketsModel()

Let‚Äôs end up this post with few post I recommend you to read if you need to know more about composition and inheritance with JavaScript:

  • Understanding Prototypes, Delegation & Composition > an explanation from A to Z which is simple, clear and illustrated
  • Common Misconceptions about Inheritance in Javascript > detailed FAQ that goes deep on this subject

item.title: H√©ritage, composition et Backbone.js
item.description: Pourquoi la composition d'objets est pr√©f√©rable √† l'h√©ritage en JavaScript¬†? Et surtout, comment applique-t-on cette id√©e avec Backbone¬†?
item.content:encoded:
‚ÄúFavor objects composition over inheritance‚Äù

Dans la Programmation Orient√©e Objet (POO), on cr√©e un certain nombre d‚Äôobjets avec leur structure de donn√©es et les m√©thodes qui composent leur interface. Pour d√©cider de comment d√©couper nos objets, on suit le Single Responsibility Principle (SRP)¬†: chaque objet doit avoir une seule et unique raison de changer.

Pour faire des choses int√©ressantes, il faut combiner ces objets.

Or, en gros, il existe 2 types de relations dans le mod√®le objets¬†: l‚Äôh√©ritage et la composition.

On peut faire l‚Äôanalogie avec un arbre g√©n√©alogique¬†:

  • l‚Äôh√©ritage, c‚Äôest comme une naissance¬†: quand √ßa arrive, c‚Äôest pour la vie.
  • la composition c‚Äôest comme un mariage¬†: √ßa arrive au cours de l‚Äôexistence des objets et √ßa peut changer. Les objets peuvent se s√©parer et trouver de nouveaux partenaires avec qui s‚Äôassocier. On notera n√©anmoins que les objets ne sont pas monogames.

Source: Object Design - Roles, Responsibilities and Collaborations

‚ÄúHeritage‚Äù all the things!

Le premier r√©flexe des d√©veloppeurs JavaScript consiste souvent √† tenter de reproduire les r√®gles d‚Äôh√©ritage pseudo-classique.

On se retrouve alors vite avec des new un peu partout et des cha√Ænes d‚Äôh√©ritage longues comme le bras. √áa produit souvent quelque chose tr√®s difficile √† maintenir.

Il est vrai qu‚Äôen Java on dispose de tout ce qu‚Äôil faut pour faire de l‚Äôh√©ritage avec des classes, des interfaces, etc.

Ce n‚Äôest pas le cas en JavaScript.

Keep It Simple, Seriously

En JavaScript, la base, c‚Äôest l‚Äôh√©ritage de prototype.

Si on oublie le jargon technique, disons qu‚Äôon a tout simplement des objets qui peuvent se lier √† d‚Äôautres objets (OLOO).

Du coup, il est vachement plus simple d‚Äôencapsuler les m√©thodes d‚Äôune m√™me logique dans un objet, puis de simplement retourner cet objet. Au besoin, on peut aussi cr√©er une fonction qui va retourner un objet (ce qu‚Äôon appelle une factory).

Cet objet on va le prendre, √©ventuellement le composer avec d‚Äôautres, pour former le prototype avec lequel on va instancier notre classe. Tout simplement.

Pour r√©sumer¬†: plut√¥t que de cr√©er des cha√Ænes d‚Äôh√©ritage plus ou moins bancales √† grands coups de constructeurs, cr√©ez simplement vos objets et composez les pour former un prototype avec lequel vous allez instancier votre classe.

¬†Concatenative inheritance

Quelqu‚Äôun m‚Äôa fait tr√®s justement remarqu√© que ce dont je vous parle ici s‚Äôappelle l‚Äôh√©ritage multiple, plut√¥t que d‚Äôobject composition au sens propre du terme.

Object composition fait r√©f√©rence au fait de faire pointer les attributs de notre objet vers des instances d‚Äôautres classes.

Il n‚Äôy a pas d‚Äôh√©ritage multiple √† proprement parler en JavaScript. Mais le fait de composer diff√©rents prototypes pour en former un nouveau est la notion qui s‚Äôen rapproche, ce qui peut g√©n√©rer de la confusion. On parle de ‚Äúcomposer des prototypes‚Äù, ce qui est le cas, mais pas dans le sens de la composition d‚Äôobjets‚Ä¶

Voici pour une explication plus concr√®te¬†: Composition, Inheritance, and Aggregation in JavaScript

Du coup, nous appellerons √ßa la concatenative inheritance, √† la mani√®re d‚ÄôEric Eliott.

Sur un exemple concret

Contexte

Depuis quelques temps d√©j√†, je travaille √† temps plein sur Vinoga, un jeu de social farming sur le vin, d√©velopp√© en HTML5.

Entre autres biblioth√®ques, nous utilisons Backbone.js pour d√©coupler simplement nos vues de nos donn√©es.

Prenons donc un cas concret¬†: les √©l√©ments sur la carte.

En posant les choses, on se rend vite compte qu‚Äôil y a 2 types d‚Äô√©l√©ments¬†:

  1. les Props qui sont les √©l√©ments de d√©cor (arbres, rochers, chemins‚Ä¶)
  2. les Buildings qui sont les b√¢timents du jeu (cuverie, ch√¢teau‚Ä¶)

Une diff√©rence parmi d‚Äôautres, mais notable √† ce stade¬†: les Buildings sont constructibles (depuis le menu de construction), les Props ne le sont pas (ils sont d√©j√† sur la carte).

Quoiqu‚Äôil en soit, tous les √©l√©ments partagent un comportement commun¬†: ils sont sur la carte. Du coup, Props et Buildings d√©rivent tous deux de Objects, qui d√©crit le comportement d‚Äôun ‚Äúobjet‚Äù sur la carte.

Mais il y a aussi diff√©rents types de Buildings, notamment¬†:

  • les Markets qui sont les b√¢timents qui vont refl√©ter l‚Äô√©tat de la boutique du joueur
  • les Productions qui sont les b√¢timents qui vont permettre de transformer une ressource (raisin, jus) en produit (jus, bouteille)

√Ä propos de la constructibilit√©

Apr√®s avoir discut√© avec le Game Designer, on se rend finalement compte que les Markets ne sont pas constructibles¬†: il sont d√©j√† sur la carte de base.

La constructibilit√© est un comportement qui faisait partie int√©grante de Buildings √† ce stade. Mais soit, on peut se dire qu‚Äôon va s‚Äôen sortir facilement en changeant la cha√Æne d‚Äôh√©ritage ainsi¬†:

Et l√†, c‚Äôest le drame

Puis le temps passe, les specs √©voluent et les features avec¬†: brace yourself, Decorations are coming!

Les Decorations, ce sont des √©l√©ments de d√©cor (des Props), sauf qu‚Äôils sont constructibles eux aussi¬†!

Bon, √† ce stade on est un peu coinc√©s parce-que Constructables √ßa h√©rite de Buildings. On aimerait √©viter de dupliquer Constructables pour recoder quasiment la m√™me chose c√¥t√© Props.

Dans le meilleur des sc√©narios, on se retrouve donc avec des classes qui h√©ritent de propri√©t√©s inutiles.

Why so pseudo-classical?

Alors comment en sommes-nous arriv√©s l√†¬†? Comment s‚Äôen sortir¬†?

En fait, nous nous sommes un peu pr√©cipit√©s quand la probl√©matique de la constructibilit√© est apparue. Sans plus y r√©fl√©chir nous avons tenu la logique ‚ÄùProductions EST un Constructables qui EST un Buildings qui EST un Objects‚Äù. Et PAF l‚Äôh√©ritage¬†!

Si on y regarde mieux, la constructibilit√© c‚Äôest un comportement. On ne peut pas dire que sans Buildings il n‚Äôy a pas d‚Äô√©l√©ment Constructables. C‚Äôest une subtilit√© et une erreur assez fr√©quente en JavaScript parce-que l‚Äôh√©ritage pseudo-classique c‚Äôest la seule chose que l‚Äôon retient¬†: c‚Äôest le premier (mauvais) r√©flexe.

Dans notre cas, la seule cha√Æne d‚Äôh√©ritage vraiment l√©gitime est peut-√™tre celle qui lie Decorations √† Props. Et encore, je dis que l‚Äôon peut s‚Äôen passer.

En r√©alit√©, ce que l‚Äôon fourre dans Objects, c‚Äôest un ensemble de comportements qui sont communs √† Props et Buildings. Mais en pratique, Objects ne repr√©sente rien de concret¬†: ce serait une classe abstraite si nous faisions du Java. Idem pour Buildings ici d‚Äôailleurs.

Embrace composition

En JavaScript, je vous sugg√®re de le prendre autrement¬†: d√©crivons chaque comportement dans un objet qui lui est propre. Laissons tomber les constructeurs et la cha√Æne d‚Äôh√©ritage.

Puis, combinons ces objets pour former le prototype des objets qui nous int√©resse. Pas de classe √† l‚Äôhorizon, simplement des objets qui se composent d‚Äôautres objets. √âventuellement des factories pour construire le bon objet au besoin.

Dans le cas de o√π l‚Äôon vient augmenter notre prototype avec d‚Äôautres objets, qui d√©crivent des comportements, on parle alors de mixin.

Si notre objet h√©rite d‚Äôun autre objet, on pr√©f√®rera utiliser l‚Äôh√©ritage de prototype.

Et avec Backbone¬†?

Backbone.extend

Quand on utilise Backbone, on se sert de .extend() pour surcharger Backbone.[Model|Collection|View|‚Ä¶]. Puis on l‚Äôinstancie avec new.

Du coup, il est assez fr√©quent de suivre le r√©flexe de l‚Äôh√©ritage pseudo-classique et de se retrouver avec¬†:

var ObjectsModel = Backbone.Model.extend( ‚Ä¶ );
var BuildingsModel = ObjectsModel.extend( ‚Ä¶ );
var MarketsModel = BuildingsModel.extend( ‚Ä¶ );

Ce qui revient d‚Äôailleurs √† √©crire¬†:

var MarketsModel = Backbone.Model.extend(‚Ä¶).extend(‚Ä¶).extend(‚Ä¶);

// Et on instancie au besoin
var marketsModel = new MarketsModel();

Backbone est ainsi fait et .extend() nous emm√®ne tr√®s facilement sur cette pente glissante o√π les Models d√©pendent les uns des autres de mani√®re plus ou moins subtile.

Composer son prototype PUIS √©tendre

Quitte √† devoir h√©riter de Backbone, autant limiter les d√©g√¢ts. Ce n‚Äôest pas parce-que .extend() existe que nous sommes contraints de l‚Äôutiliser pour chaque objet que nous cr√©ons. Le seul objet que nous ayons √† .extend() v√©ritablement ici, c‚Äôest Backbone.Model.

L‚Äôid√©e, c‚Äôest de composer des objets pour former le prototype que nous allons ensuite utiliser dans le .extend() de notre Model / Collection / Vue‚Ä¶

var objectsModelProto = {
  /* ‚Ä¶ */
}
var buildingsModelProto = {
  /* ‚Ä¶ */
}
var constructablesModelProto = {
  /* ‚Ä¶ */
}

// On compose pour former un nouveau prototype.
var marketsModelProto = _.assign(
  {
    /* ‚Ä¶ */
  }, // -> interface sp√©cifique √† markets
  objectsModelProto, //
  buildingsModelProto, // => nos mixins
  constructablesModelProto, //
  {
    /* ‚Ä¶ */
  } // -> pour surcharger nos mixins, si besoin
)

// Une fois le prototype cr√©√©, on h√©rite de Backbone.
var MarketsModel = Backbone.Model.extend(marketsModelProto)

// Puis on instancie.
var marketsModel = new MarketsModel()

Ici objectsModelProto, buildingsModelProto et constructablesModelProto viennent surcharger le prototype de base de marketsModelProto pour rajouter des comportements sp√©cifiques.

¬†Merge ou assign

√Ä noter qu‚Äôil peut √™tre int√©ressant d‚Äôutiliser _.merge plut√¥t que _.assign si l‚Äôon souhaite pouvoir fusionner les attributs. √áa peut √™tre pratique avec Backbone pour fusionner certains attributs tels que events¬†:

var objectsViewProto = {
  events: {
    'click .store': 'store',
    'click .turn': 'turn',
  },

  store: function store() {
    /* ‚Ä¶ */
  },
  turn: function turn() {
    /* ‚Ä¶ */
  },
}

_.assign(
  {
    displayModal: function displayModal() {
      /* ‚Ä¶ */
    },
    select: function select() {
      /* ‚Ä¶ */
    },
  },
  objectsViewProto,
  {
    events: {
      click: 'select',
      'click .turn': 'displayModal',
    },
  }
)
// ->
// {
//   events: {
//     "click": "select",
//     "click .turn": "displayModal"
//   },
//
//   displayModal: function displayModal () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ },
//   select: function select () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ },
//   store: function store () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ },
//   turn: function turn () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ }
// }

_.merge(
  {
    displayModal: function displayModal() {
      /* ‚Ä¶ */
    },
    select: function select() {
      /* ‚Ä¶ */
    },
  },
  objectsViewProto,
  {
    events: {
      click: 'select',
      'click .turn': 'displayModal',
    },
  }
)
// ->
// {
//   events: {
//     "click": "select",
//     "click .store": "store",
//     "click .turn": "displayModal"
//   },
//
//   displayModal: function displayModal () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ },
//   select: function select () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ },
//   store: function store () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ },
//   turn: function turn () { /* ‚Ä¶ */ }
// }

Pour conclure

Pr√©f√©rez la composition d‚Äôobjets plut√¥t que l‚Äôh√©ritage. N‚Äôutilisez l‚Äôh√©ritage que si cela fait vraiment sens, ou si c‚Äôest n√©cessaire. Gare aux longues cha√Ænes d‚Äôh√©ritage¬†: c‚Äôest fragile.

Ce qu‚Äôil est pr√©f√©rable d‚Äô√©viter¬†:

// markets.model.js
var MarketsModel = ConstructablesModel.extend({
  /* ‚Ä¶ */
})

// main.js
var marketsModel = new MarketsModel()

Plus flexible, plus simple¬†:

// markets.model.js
var marketsModelProto = _.assign(
  {
    /* ‚Ä¶ */
  }, // -> interface sp√©cifique √† markets
  objectsModelProto,
  buildingsModelProto,
  constructablesModelProto
)

// main.js
var MarketsModel = Backbone.Model.extend(marketsModelProto)
var marketsModel = new MarketsModel()

Pour finir, voici quelques articles que je vous recommande pour aller plus loin sur le sujet de la composition et de l‚Äôh√©ritage en JavaScript¬†:

  • Understanding Prototypes, Delegation & Composition > une explication de A √† Z simple, claire et illustr√©e
  • Common Misconceptions about Inheritance in Javascript > FAQ d√©taill√©e qui va au fond de la question

item.title: Pure functions in JavaScript
item.description: What is a pure function and why should you consider it in JavaScript?
item.content:encoded:
What‚Äôs that a ‚Äúpure‚Äù function?

A pure function doesn‚Äôt depend on and doesn‚Äôt modify the states of variables out of its scope.

Concretely, that means a pure function always returns the same result given same parameters. Its execution doesn‚Äôt depend on the state of the system.

Pure functions are a pillar of functional programming.

Give me examples

var values = { a: 1 }

function impureFunction(items) {
  var b = 1

  items.a = items.a * b + 2

  return items.a
}

var c = impureFunction(values)
// Now `values.a` is 3, the impure function modifies it.

Here we modify the attributes of the given object. Hence we modify the object which lies outside of the scope of our function: the function is impure.

var values = { a: 1 }

function pureFunction(a) {
  var b = 1

  a = a * b + 2

  return a
}

var c = pureFunction(values.a)
// `values.a` has not been modified, it's still 1

Now we simply modify the parameter which is in the scope of the function, nothing is modified outside!

var values = { a: 1 }
var b = 1

function impureFunction(a) {
  a = a * b + 2

  return a
}

var c = impureFunction(values.a)
// Actually, the value of `c` will depend on the value of `b`.
// In a bigger codebase, you may forget about that, which may
// surprise you because the result can vary implicitly.

Here, b is not in the scope of the function. The result will depend on the context: surprises expected!

var values = { a: 1 }
var b = 1

function pureFunction(a, c) {
  a = a * c + 2

  return a
}

var c = pureFunction(values.a, b)
// Here it's made clear that the value of `c` will depend on
// the value of `b`. No sneaky surprise behind your back.

What does it look like, concretely?

Considering this code exists:

var getMinQuantity = function getMinQuantity(name) {
  // A pure fonction which returns a number, regarding
  // the given name.
}

Let‚Äôs take the following code example that may exist in a lambda project:

var popover = {
  // A bunch of code‚Ä¶

  addQuantityText: function(quantity) {
    var quantityTextOptions = {
      namespace: 'quantity',
      initialChildIndex: 2,
      quantity: quantity,
    }

    try {
      this.formatQuantityText(quantityTextOptions)
    } catch (err) {
      console.log("Couldn't add quantity text!")
    }
  },

  formatQuantityText: function(options) {
    if (!this.$$boxContainer) {
      throw new Error('$$boxContainer is not configured')
    }

    var namespace = options.namespace || 'quantity'
    var quantity = options.quantity || 0
    var initialChildIndex = options.initialChildIndex || 0

    var $$quantity = new Canvas() // implementation details hidden
    $$quantity.name = namespace
    $$quantity.value = quantity
    this.setQuantityTextColor($$quantity)

    this.$$boxContainer.addChild($$quantity, initialChildIndex)

    return $$quantity
  },

  setQuantityTextColor: function($$quantity) {
    if (!$$quantity) return

    var minQuantity = getMinQuantity($$quantity.name)
    var quantity = $$quantity.value || minQuantity
    var hasEnoughQuantity = quantity >= minQuantity

    $$quantity.color = hasEnoughQuantity ? 'green' : 'red'
  },

  // A bunch of code‚Ä¶
}

We‚Äôve got addQuantityText(), formatQuantityText() and setQuantityTextColor() which are all impure.

In our context, addQuantityText() is the method actually used when you want to ‚Äúdisplay the quantity‚Äù in our $$boxContainer. This is the entry point, dealing with implementation details. You‚Äôll look at this method when something goes wrong with $$quantity. Which is likely to be the start of a treasure hunt ‚Äî but not a funny one.

The way it was written could be error-prone on the long term.

When it gets complicated

In this example, the execution order of functions is critical.

Just swap 2 lines and you‚Äôll break everything. It may sound obvious, but it‚Äôs much more difficult to debug:

var popover = {
  // A bunch of code‚Ä¶

  addQuantityText: function(quantity) {
    var quantityTextOptions = {
      namespace: 'quantity',
      initialChildIndex: 2,
      quantity: quantity,
    }

    try {
      this.formatQuantityText(quantityTextOptions)
    } catch (err) {
      console.log("Couldn't add quantity text!")
    }
  },

  formatQuantityText: function(options) {
    if (!this.$$boxContainer) {
      throw new Error('$$boxContainer is not configured')
    }

    var namespace = options.namespace || 'quantity'
    var quantity = options.quantity || 0
    var initialChildIndex = options.initialChildIndex || 0

    var $$quantity = new Canvas() // implementation details hidden
    this.setQuantityTextColor($$quantity)
    $$quantity.name = namespace
    $$quantity.value = quantity

    return $$quantity
  },

  setQuantityTextColor: function($$quantity) {
    if (!$$quantity) return

    var minQuantity = getMinQuantity($$quantity.name)
    var quantity = $$quantity.value || minQuantity
    var hasEnoughQuantity = quantity >= minQuantity

    $$quantity.color = hasEnoughQuantity ? 'green' : 'red'
  },

  // A bunch of code‚Ä¶
}

Now there is an error in the code. Problem is: that‚Äôs hard stuff to detect!

Here, setQuantityTextColor() is responsible of the color of $$quantity. And so you need to navigate through methods to catch the one which is the last which modifies the object, then reconstitute the whole flow to understand what‚Äôs going wrong.

At this point you could even regret having decomposed formatQuantityText() into smaller methods to simplify implementation details.

Generally speaking, that‚Äôs a lot of code that needs to be considered when you are debugging. And if you get thinking that splitting a big method into smaller ones just make the debug difficult, then the concept of pure function is gaining interest.

Let‚Äôs do that with pure functions

We‚Äôll use a maximum of pure functions to rewrite our code:

var popover = {
  // A bunch of code‚Ä¶

  // All the modifications of system state are grouped here.
  // This only method is responsible for the insertion of
  // an element, which makes debug simpler and limit
  // side effects.
  addQuantityText: function(quantity) {
    if (!this.$$boxContainer) {
      throw new Error('$$boxContainer is not configured')
    }

    var quantityTextOptions = {
      namespace: 'quantity',
      quantity: quantity,
    }
    var $$quantity = this.formatQuantityText(quantityTextOptions)

    this.$$boxContainer.addChild($$quantity, 2)
  },

  // This method doesn't have side effects.
  // It just call other pure functions. It creates and return the
  // canvas object desired, correctly configured!
  formatQuantityText: function(options) {
    var namespace = options.namespace || 'quantity'
    var quantity = options.quantity || 0

    var $$quantity = new Canvas() // implementation details hidden
    $$quantity.name = namespace
    $$quantity.value = quantity
    $$quantity.color = this.getQuantityTextColor(quantity, namespace)

    return $$quantity
  },

  // This method doesn't have side effects neither.
  // It returns the correct color, regarding the given quantity.
  getQuantityTextColor: function(quantity, namespace) {
    var minQuantity = getMinQuantity(namespace)
    var hasEnoughQuantity = quantity && quantity >= minQuantity

    return hasEnoughQuantity ? 'green' : 'red'
  },

  // A bunch of code‚Ä¶
}

There is no fundamental change in this new version. However, there are non-negligible benefits.

What we did here:

  • getQuantityTextColor() instead of setQuantityTextColor()
  • the method returns a color regarding the quantity we give to it instead of modifying the object directly, as we did before
  • methods don‚Äôt consider variables out of their scope
  • methods only call pure methods
  • we isolated the creation / modification of the $$quantity object in formatQuantityText()
  • we isolated modifications of the system state in addQuantityText()

Doing so, we removed methods with side effects. We just simplified the code maintenance. If there is an issue with $$quantity to occur, there is only one method to look for.

Simplify the interface

We used here public methods. It‚Äôd be perfectly acceptable ‚Äî completely relevant¬†‚Äî to make them private.

Indeed, there don‚Äôt have much to do with our API since their role is to simplify the interface. Have a look to my post on private methods with Backbone.js if you get scratching your head with that.

As they are pures, to extract them is dead easy since they don‚Äôt rely on a specific context, just parameters!

function getQuantityTextColor(quantity, namespace) {
  var minQuantity = getMinQuantity(namespace)
  var hasEnoughQuantity = quantity && quantity >= minQuantity

  return hasEnoughQuantity ? 'green' : 'red'
}

function formatQuantityText(options) {
  var namespace = options.namespace || 'quantity'
  var quantity = options.quantity || 0

  var $$quantity = new Canvas() // implementation details hidden
  $$quantity.name = namespace
  $$quantity.value = quantity
  $$quantity.color = getQuantityTextColor(quantity, namespace)

  return $$quantity
}

And then, later in the code:

var popover = {
  // A bunch of code‚Ä¶

  addQuantityText: function(quantity) {
    if (!this.$$boxContainer) {
      throw new Error('$$boxContainer is not configured')
    }

    var quantityTextOptions = {
      namespace: 'quantity',
      quantity: quantity,
    }
    var $$quantity = formatQuantityText(quantityTextOptions)

    this.$$boxContainer.addChild($$quantity, 2)
  },

  // A bunch of code‚Ä¶
}

Advantages of pure functions

The main advantage of a pure function is that it doesn‚Äôt have any side effect. It doesn‚Äôt modify the state of the system outside of their scope. Then, they just simplify and clarify the code: when you call a pure function, you just need to focus on the return value as you know you didn‚Äôt broke anything elsewhere doing so.

A pure function is also robust. Its order of execution doesn‚Äôt have any impact on the system. Operations with pure functions could be parallelized.

Also, it‚Äôs very easy to unit test a pure function since there is no context to consider. Just focus on inputs / outputs.

Finally, maximizing the use of pure functions makes your code simpler, more flexible.

A matter of design

In practice, when you are doing object-oriented code you may think that functional programming concepts couldn‚Äôt fit in. This is simply wrong as OOP and FP are absolutely compatibles!

Indeed, the idea here is simple: simplify your code by limiting the number of functions that has an impact on the system.

If you force yourself to think twice to maximize the number of pure functions in your code, you‚Äôll probably make your maintenance / life / debug easier!

Well, you‚Äôve got the idea. Which is often, in practice, a matter of design, the choice between a get and a set for instance.

Further Reading

  • Introduction To Functions

item.title: Fonctions pures en JavaScript
item.description: Qu'est-ce-qu'une fonction pure et pourquoi s'y int√©resser en JavaScript¬†?
item.content:encoded:
C‚Äôest quoi √ßa une fonction ‚Äúpure‚Äù¬†?

Une fonction pure ne d√©pend pas et ne modifie pas l‚Äô√©tat de variables hors de sa port√©e.

En pratique, cela signifie qu‚Äôune fonction pure retourne toujours le m√™me r√©sultat avec des param√®tres identiques. Son ex√©cution ne d√©pend pas de l‚Äô√©tat du syst√®me.

Les fonctions pures sont d‚Äôailleurs un pilier de la programmation fonctionnelle.

Quelques exemples

var values = { a: 1 }

function impureFunction(items) {
  var b = 1

  items.a = items.a * b + 2
}

var c = impureFunction(values)
// D√©sormais `values.a` vaut 3 car la fonction impure l'a modifi√©.

Ici, on modifie les attributs de l‚Äôobjet pass√© en param√®tre, donc on modifie l‚Äôobjet en dehors de la port√©e de notre fonction √©galement¬†: elle est impure dans ce cas.

var values = { a: 1 }

function pureFunction(a) {
  var b = 1

  a = a * b + 2

  return a
}

var c = pureFunction(values.a)
// `values.a` n'a pas √©t√© modifi√©, c'est toujours 1

Ici, on modifie simplement le param√®tre dans la port√©e de la fonction, on ne touche √† rien d‚Äôautre en dehors¬†!

var values = { a: 1 }
var b = 1

function impureFunction(a) {
  a = a * b + 2

  return a
}

var c = impureFunction(values.a)
// En fait la valeur de `c` d√©pend de celle de `b`.
// Dans une base de code plus grande vous risquez d'oublier ce
// d√©tail et le r√©sultat peut vous surprendre car il peut varier
// de mani√®re implicite.

La variable b n‚Äôest pas dans la port√©e de la fonction. Le r√©sultat d√©pendra du contexte¬†: surprises garanties¬†!

var values = { a: 1 }
var b = 1

function pureFunction(a, c) {
  a = a * c + 2

  return a
}

var c = pureFunction(values.a, b)
// Ici il est clair que la valeur de `c` d√©pend de celle de `b`.
// Pas de surprise en douce.

Et en pratique √ßa donne quoi¬†?

Consid√©rons que ce code existe¬†:

var getMinQuantity = function getMinQuantity(name) {
  // Une fonction pure qui retourne une valeur num√©rique
  // en fonction du name.
}

Et prenons donc l‚Äôexemple du code suivant que l‚Äôon pourrait retrouver dans un projet lambda¬†:

var popover = {
  // Un tas de code‚Ä¶

  addQuantityText: function(quantity) {
    var quantityTextOptions = {
      namespace: 'quantity',
      initialChildIndex: 2,
      quantity: quantity,
    }

    try {
      this.formatQuantityText(quantityTextOptions)
    } catch (err) {
      console.log("Couldn't add quantity text!")
    }
  },

  formatQuantityText: function(options) {
    if (!this.$$boxContainer) {
      throw new Error('$$boxContainer is not configured')
    }

    var namespace = options.namespace || 'quantity'
    var quantity = options.quantity || 0
    var initialChildIndex = options.initialChildIndex || 0

    var $$quantity = new Canvas() // implementation details hidden
    $$quantity.name = namespace
    $$quantity.value = quantity
    this.setQuantityTextColor($$quantity)

    this.$$boxContainer.addChild($$quantity, initialChildIndex)

    return $$quantity
  },

  setQuantityTextColor: function($$quantity) {
    if (!$$quantity) return

    var minQuantity = getMinQuantity($$quantity.name)
    var quantity = $$quantity.value || minQuantity
    var hasEnoughQuantity = quantity >= minQuantity

    $$quantity.color = hasEnoughQuantity ? 'green' : 'red'
  },

  // Un tas de code‚Ä¶
}

Ici nous avons addQuantityText(), formatQuantityText() et setQuantityTextColor() qui sont toutes impures.

Dans notre contexte, c‚Äôest addQuantityText() qui est utilis√©e lorsque l‚Äôon souhaite ‚Äúafficher la quantit√©‚Äù dans notre $$boxContainer. C‚Äôest le point d‚Äôentr√©e qui se charge de tous les d√©tails. C‚Äôest dans cette fonction qu‚Äôon va aller jeter un ≈ìil si un soucis se pr√©sente avec notre $$quantity. √áa risque de devenir un vrai jeu de piste.

La mani√®re dont il a √©t√© √©crit peut √™tre propice √† certaines erreurs sur le long terme.

Quand √ßa devient compliqu√©

Dans l‚Äôexemple, l‚Äôordre d‚Äôex√©cution des fonctions est garant du bon fonctionnement du code.

Il suffit d‚Äô√©changer l‚Äôordre de 2 lignes pour tout casser. √áa peut para√Ætre √©vident, mais √ßa l‚Äôest beaucoup moins √† rep√©rer¬†:

var popover = {
  // Un tas de code‚Ä¶

  addQuantityText: function(quantity) {
    var quantityTextOptions = {
      namespace: 'quantity',
      initialChildIndex: 2,
      quantity: quantity,
    }

    try {
      this.formatQuantityText(quantityTextOptions)
    } catch (err) {
      console.log("Couldn't add quantity text!")
    }
  },

  formatQuantityText: function(options) {
    if (!this.$$boxContainer) {
      throw new Error('$$boxContainer is not configured')
    }

    var namespace = options.namespace || 'quantity'
    var quantity = options.quantity || 0
    var initialChildIndex = options.initialChildIndex || 0

    var $$quantity = new Canvas() // implementation details hidden
    this.setQuantityTextColor($$quantity)
    $$quantity.name = namespace
    $$quantity.value = quantity

    return $$quantity
  },

  setQuantityTextColor: function($$quantity) {
    if (!$$quantity) return

    var minQuantity = getMinQuantity($$quantity.name)
    var quantity = $$quantity.value || minQuantity
    var hasEnoughQuantity = quantity >= minQuantity

    $$quantity.color = hasEnoughQuantity ? 'green' : 'red'
  },

  // Un tas de code‚Ä¶
}

Il y a d√©sormais une erreur dans le code. Le probl√®me, c‚Äôest que √ßa ne saute pas aux yeux¬†!

Ici, setQuantityTextColor() est responsable de la couleur de $$quantity. Du coup, il faut naviguer de m√©thodes en m√©thodes pour trouver celle qui modifie l‚Äôobjet en dernier et reconstituer le flow pour comprendre ce qui pourrait mal se passer.

√Ä ce moment l√†, on pourrait presque s‚Äôen mordre les doigts d‚Äôavoir d√©coup√© formatQuantityText() en petites m√©thodes pour simplifier les d√©tails de son impl√©mentation.

D‚Äôune mani√®re g√©n√©rale d‚Äôailleurs, √ßa fait pas mal de code √† consid√©rer en cas de debug. Et si on commence √† estimer que d√©composer une grosse m√©thode en petites complique la t√¢che de debug, alors le concept de fonction pure prend de l‚Äôint√©r√™t.

Avec des fonctions pures

Reprenons notre code en utilisant cette fois un maximum de fonctions pures¬†:

var popover = {
  // Un tas de code‚Ä¶

  // L'ensemble des modifications de l'√©tat du syst√®me sont
  // concentr√©es ici.
  // Seule cette m√©thode est responsable de l'insertion
  // d'un √©l√©ment, ce qui simplifie le debug et limite les
  // effets de bord.
  addQuantityText: function(quantity) {
    if (!this.$$boxContainer) {
      throw new Error('$$boxContainer is not configured')
    }

    var quantityTextOptions = {
      namespace: 'quantity',
      quantity: quantity,
    }
    var $$quantity = this.formatQuantityText(quantityTextOptions)

    this.$$boxContainer.addChild($$quantity, 2)
  },

  // Cette fonction n'a pas d'effet de bord.
  // Elle n'appelle que des fonctions pures. Elle cr√©e et
  // retourne l'objet canvas d√©sir√©, correctement configur√© !
  formatQuantityText: function(options) {
    var namespace = options.namespace || 'quantity'
    var quantity = options.quantity || 0

    var $$quantity = new Canvas() // implementation details hidden
    $$quantity.name = namespace
    $$quantity.value = quantity
    $$quantity.color = this.getQuantityTextColor(quantity, namespace)

    return $$quantity
  },

  // Cette m√©thode n'a plus d'effet de bord non plus,
  // elle se charge de renvoyer la bonne couleur en fonction
  // de la quantit√© en param√®tre.
  getQuantityTextColor: function(quantity, namespace) {
    var minQuantity = getMinQuantity(namespace)
    var hasEnoughQuantity = quantity && quantity >= minQuantity

    return hasEnoughQuantity ? 'green' : 'red'
  },

  // Un tas de code‚Ä¶
}

Il n‚Äôy a pas de changement fondamental dans cette nouvelle version du code. Et pourtant, les b√©n√©fices ne sont pas n√©gligeables.

Ce qu‚Äôon a fait¬†:

  • getQuantityTextColor() plut√¥t que setQuantityTextColor()
  • la m√©thode nous retourne une couleur en fonction de la quantit√© pass√©e en param√®tre au lieu de modifier l‚Äôobjet qu‚Äôon lui passait en param√®tre auparavant
  • les m√©thodes ne d√©pendent plus de variables en dehors de leur port√©e
  • les m√©thodes appellent uniquement des m√©thodes pures
  • on isole la cr√©ation / modification de l‚Äôobjet $$quantity dans formatQuantityText()
  • on isole les modifications de l‚Äô√©tat du syst√®me dans la seule m√©thode addQuantityText()

Ainsi, nous avons supprim√© les m√©thodes qui avaient des effets de bords. Nous avons donc simplifi√© la maintenance du code. Si jamais il y a un soucis avec $$quantity, il n‚Äôy a qu‚Äôune m√©thode √† regarder.

Simplification de l‚Äôinterface

Nous utilisons ici des m√©thodes publiques. Il serait tout √† fait envisageable, voire carr√©ment pertinent, de les rendre priv√©es.

En effet, elles n‚Äôont pas grand chose √† faire dans notre API car leur r√¥le est de simplifier l‚Äôinterface. Allez jeter un ≈ìil √† mon article sur les fonctions priv√©es avec Backbone.js si √ßa vous laisse perplexe.

Comme elles sont pures, les extraire est un jeu d‚Äôenfant puisqu‚Äôelles ne d√©pendent d‚Äôaucun contexte mais simplement des param√®tres¬†!

function getQuantityTextColor(quantity, namespace) {
  var minQuantity = getMinQuantity(namespace)
  var hasEnoughQuantity = quantity && quantity >= minQuantity

  return hasEnoughQuantity ? 'green' : 'red'
}

function formatQuantityText(options) {
  var namespace = options.namespace || 'quantity'
  var quantity = options.quantity || 0

  var $$quantity = new Canvas() // implementation details hidden
  $$quantity.name = namespace
  $$quantity.value = quantity
  $$quantity.color = getQuantityTextColor(quantity, namespace)

  return $$quantity
}

Et du coup, plus loin dans le code¬†:

var popover = {
  // Un tas de code‚Ä¶

  addQuantityText: function(quantity) {
    if (!this.$$boxContainer) {
      throw new Error('$$boxContainer is not configured')
    }

    var quantityTextOptions = {
      namespace: 'quantity',
      quantity: quantity,
    }
    var $$quantity = formatQuantityText(quantityTextOptions)

    this.$$boxContainer.addChild($$quantity, 2)
  },

  // Un tas de code‚Ä¶
}

L‚Äôint√©r√™t des fonctions pures

L‚Äôavantage d‚Äôune fonction pure, c‚Äôest qu‚Äôelle n‚Äôa pas d‚Äôeffets de bord. Elles ne modifient pas l‚Äô√©tat du syst√®me en dehors de leur port√©e. Ainsi, elles simplifient et clarifient le code¬†: quand on appelle une fonction pure, on peut se concentrer sur la valeur qu‚Äôelle retourne puisqu‚Äôon sait qu‚Äôelle ne va pas impacter le syst√®me en passant.

Une fonction pure est √©galement robuste. Son ordre d‚Äôex√©cution n‚Äôa pas d‚Äôimpact sur le syst√®me. Les op√©rations sur des fonctions pures sont donc parall√©lisables.

De m√™me, il est tr√®s simple de tester une fonction pure puisqu‚Äôil n‚Äôy a pas de contexte consid√©rer. Il suffit de se concentrer sur les entr√©es / sorties.

Enfin, maximiser le nombre de fonctions pures rend le code plus simple, plus flexible.

Une question de design

En pratique quand on fait de l‚Äôorient√©-objet, on se dit que les concepts de la programmation fonctionnelle paraissent inadapt√©s. C‚Äôest une erreur car POO et FP sont parfaitement compatibles¬†!

En effet, l‚Äôid√©e ici est toute simple¬†: simplifier le code en limitant le nombre de fonctions qui ont un impact sur l‚Äô√©tat du syst√®me.

En s‚Äôeffor√ßant √† √©crire un maximum de fonctions pures, en limitant le nombre de fonctions qui ne le sont pas, on se simplifie la vie¬†!

En tout cas, c‚Äôest l‚Äôid√©e. Et souvent, en pratique, c‚Äôest surtout une question de design, de choix entre un get et un set par exemple.

item.title: OOP - switch revisited in JavaScript
item.description: With JavaScript you get a more object-oriented, less procedural and error-prone alternative to the good 'ol switch ‚Ä¶ case.
item.content:encoded:
Suppose following methods for the rest of the post:

function sayHello() {
  console.log('Hello, how are you?')
}

function giveSomeNews() {
  console.log('Roses are red. Did you know that?')
}

function sayBye() {
  console.log('Ok bye!')
}

Few reminders about switch

if / else allow us to add some branching logic in our code: regarding a condition we‚Äôll do this or that operation. But there are sometimes more than 2 possibles branches.

As a beginner developer, you might be starting using else if:

if (name === 'patrick') {
  sayHello()
} else if (name === 'jane') {
  giveSomeNews()
} else {
  sayBye() // don't talk to strangers!
}

Well, that‚Äôs a bit verbose, difficult to read and not that pretty. Here comes switch:

switch (name) {
  case 'patrick':
    sayHello()
    break

  case 'jane':
    giveSomeNews()
    break

  default:
    sayBye() // don't talk to strangers!
    break
}

switch is the classical alternative to a long chain of else if.

Excepted for very short operations ‚Äî few lines with clear intent ‚Äî I prefer to encapsulate them in explicitly named functions to decompose the logic from the implementation details. The logic lies in the switch. I use the same technique for if / else.

Syntax is clearer, but you‚Äôre introducing few subtleties.

Most of all, you should be aware of the break concept here: it allows you to get out of the switch and prevent falling through the next case.

Remember errors to avoid!

When you deal with a switch, you‚Äôre not likely to expect falling through 2 different cases.

Just like else if, you probably expect to execute one and only one case. That‚Äôs why you must take care not to forget the break!

Have a look at this code, is it intentional? Is it a mistake? Whatever, that‚Äôs a source of bugs and confusion!

switch (name) {
  case 'patrick':
    sayHello()
    break

  case 'jane':
    giveSomeNews()

  default:
    sayBye() // don't talk to strangers!
    break
}

There might exists a use case however, where the intent is clear and which is acceptable ‚Äî and used.

That‚Äôs when you want to regroup multiple inputs into the same case:

switch (name) {
  case 'patrick':
    sayHello()
    break

  case 'jane':
  case 'john':
    giveSomeNews()
    break

  default:
    sayBye() // don't talk to strangers!
    break
}

To keep it short: to omit a break for each case is error-prone because you‚Äôre introducing obscure subtleties in your code. And your code is likely to get future developers into troubles.

That‚Äôs why the wise advice is: avoid doing that, do remember the break.

An object-oriented alternative: method lookup

Let‚Äôs go back to our example with a less procedural spirit. Let‚Äôs get object-oriented:

var greetings = {
  patrick: sayHello,
  john: giveSomeNews,
  jane: giveSomeNews,
}

typeof greetings[name] === 'function' ? greetings[name]() : sayBye()

You can call that the method lookup, which reflect the idea behind the Command Pattern.

We use the natural object syntax of JavaScript and the power of its first-class functions. No break to deal with. We already get all the advantages of the object, as the capability to extend it with ease, allowing context-relative options.

The method lookup is much more relevant than the switch if you‚Äôre in one of the following cases:

  • will you need to add more cases later? Dealing with plugins for instance.
  • is it useful to change cases during run-time? Like changing options regarding the context.
  • is it useful to log executed cases? To set up an undo / redo stack, a log system, etc.
  • are you using incremental numbers to list your cases iteratively? If you use case 1:, case 2:, etc.
  • are you trying to fall through different cases by intentionally omitting some break? Fall through = danger, method lookup is a much better alternative.

Few remarks on an ‚Äúadvanced‚Äù version of switch

Using switch, you can directly test a condition in your case.

Doing so, and considering this code exist:

function isPatrick(name) {
  return name === 'patrick'
}

function isJane(name) {
  return /^jane-/.test(name)
}

Then, the following code will perfectly work:

switch (true) {
  case isPatrick(name):
    sayHello()
    break

  case isJane(name):
    giveSomeNews()
    break

  default:
    sayBye() // don't talk to strangers!
    break
}

Again, for more readability I exported conditions into functions that make the intent clear and produce a better code.

You‚Äôll agree that the logic is now a bit more complex. In such a context, it might be relevant to polish your work to make your code clear.

This works and could be very useful. Plus, it doesn‚Äôt have any equivalent with the method lookup as far as I know.

However, beware overlogic abuse in your code. The fact you can do it doesn‚Äôt imply that you should. Keep a critical mind over what you‚Äôre doing: is it really necessary or is there another simpler way? Can I work on a clearer design to express the logic intent?

Sometimes you might go crazy into ‚Äúsexy‚Äù stuff, but nothing values most than KISS!

Release the (object-oriented) Kraken!

The method lookup / command pattern is a switch equivalent, with an object-oriented spirit. It tends to encourage you to write a flexible, well-organized, object-oriented code ‚Äî which is good.

switch ‚Ä¶ case is not a bad thing in itself. But it can be lead to spaghetti code and be error-prone. Because its procedural, you may end up with a complex branching logic which finally traduce a bad code design which is difficult to maintain.

Finally, there is no reason to actually use switch instead of its alternative if you want to benefit what JavaScript has to offer. But must of all, the most important is you to write a code the future-you and others won‚Äôt hate!

item.title: POO - le switch revisit√© en JavaScript
item.description: En JavaScript, nous disposons d'une alternative plus orient√©e-objet, moins proc√©durale et propice aux erreurs que le bon vieux switch ‚Ä¶ case.
item.content:encoded:
Supposons que les m√©thodes suivantes existent¬†:

function sayHello() {
  console.log('Hello, how are you?')
}

function giveSomeNews() {
  console.log('Roses are red. Did you know that?')
}

function sayBye() {
  console.log('Ok bye!')
}

Quelques rappels sur le switch

if / else permet d‚Äôintroduire de la logique dans notre code en cr√©ant des branches¬†: en fonction d‚Äôune condition, nous ex√©cuterons telle ou telle op√©ration. Mais parfois, il y a plus de 2 branches possibles.

Le r√©flexe initial consiste donc √† ajouter des branches avec else if¬†:

if (name === 'patrick') {
  sayHello()
} else if (name === 'jane') {
  giveSomeNews()
} else {
  sayBye() // don't talk to strangers!
}

Comme c‚Äôest un petit peu verbeux, peu lisible et encore moins √©l√©gant, on utilise alors le switch¬†:

switch (name) {
  case 'patrick':
    sayHello()
    break

  case 'jane':
    giveSomeNews()
    break

  default:
    sayBye() // don't talk to strangers!
    break
}

switch est une alternative classique √† un encha√Ænement de else if.

√Ä moins qu‚Äôil s‚Äôagisse d‚Äôop√©rations tr√®s petites (quelques lignes, claires et explicites), je pr√©f√®re les encapsuler dans des fonctions explicitement nomm√©es pour d√©composer la logique de l‚Äôimpl√©mentation. Le switch, c‚Äôest la logique. J‚Äôutilise la m√™me technique pour les if / else.

La syntaxe est plus claire, mais on introduit certaines subtilit√©s.

Notamment, il faut prendre garde au concept du break introduit ici¬†: il permet de sortir du switch et √©viter de passer au case suivant.

Rappel des erreurs √† √©viter¬†!

Lorsque l‚Äôon arrive sur un switch, on s‚Äôattend rarement (jamais¬†?) √† passer √† travers 2 cas diff√©rents.

√Ä l‚Äôinstar du else if, on s‚Äôattend √† ex√©cuter un cas et un seul. Pour cette raison, on veille √† ne pas oublier le break¬†!

Par exemple, ce code est-il intentionnel¬†? Est-ce un oubli¬†? En tout cas, c‚Äôest une source de confusion et de bugs¬†!

switch (name) {
  case 'patrick':
    sayHello()
    break

  case 'jane':
    giveSomeNews()

  default:
    sayBye() // don't talk to strangers!
    break
}

Il existe un cas de figure o√π, √† la limite, l‚Äôintention reste claire et qui est acceptable (et utilis√©e).

Il s‚Äôagit de regrouper diff√©rents inputs dans un m√™me case¬†:

switch (name) {
  case 'patrick':
    sayHello()
    break

  case 'jane':
  case 'john':
    giveSomeNews()
    break

  default:
    sayBye() // don't talk to strangers!
    break
}

Bref, ne pas mettre un break √† chaque case est tr√®s souvent propice aux erreurs car le code √©crit comporte ‚Äúune subtilit√©‚Äù, il a donc des chances d‚Äô√™tre mal lu / interpr√©t√©.

Le jeu n‚Äôen vaut pas la chandelle, aussi je vous conseille plut√¥t de ne pas le faire. Apr√®s, c‚Äôest vous qui voyez mais y‚Äôen a qu‚Äôon essay√©‚Ä¶

Une alternative orient√©e objet¬†: method lookup

Reprenons √† pr√©sent notre exemple avec un esprit moins proc√©dural, plus orient√©-objet¬†:

var greetings = {
  patrick: sayHello,
  john: giveSomeNews,
  jane: giveSomeNews,
}

typeof greetings[name] === 'function' ? greetings[name]() : sayBye()

On peut appeler cela le method lookup qui traduit finalement l‚Äôid√©e du Command Pattern.

On utilise ici la syntaxe objet naturelle de JavaScript et la puissance de ses fonctions. Pas de break dont on doit se pr√©occuper. On dispose √©galement de tous les avantages de l‚Äôobjet, notamment le fait de pouvoir le surcharger facilement et ainsi d√©pendre d‚Äôun contexte particulier.

En pratique, le method lookup est pertinent par rapport au switch si vous vous trouvez dans l‚Äôun des cas suivants¬†:

  • aurez-vous besoin d‚Äôajouter plus de cas¬†? Par exemple dans le cas de plugins
  • est-il utile de pouvoir modifier les cas en cours d‚Äôex√©cution¬†? Par exemple pour changer d‚Äôoptions en fonction du contexte.
  • est-il utile de log les cas qui ont √©t√© ex√©cut√©s¬†? Par exemple pour mettre en place un stack de undo / redo, ou un syst√®me de log.
  • √™tes-vous en train d‚Äôutiliser des nombres pour lister vos cas, de mani√®re it√©rative¬†? Par exemple case 1:, case 2:, etc.
  • √™tes-vous en train d‚Äôessayer de regrouper des cas ensembles en omettant de mani√®re intentionnelle des break¬†? Fall through = danger, le method lookup est bien plus clair.

Remarques sur une version du switch ‚Äúavanc√©‚Äù

Avec switch il est possible de tester directement une condition dans le case.

Ainsi, en consid√©rant que ceci existe¬†:

function isPatrick(name) {
  return name === 'patrick'
}

function isJane(name) {
  return /^jane-/.test(name)
}

Le code suivant fonctionne parfaitement¬†:

switch (true) {
  case isPatrick(name):
    sayHello()
    break

  case isJane(name):
    giveSomeNews()
    break

  default:
    sayBye() // don't talk to strangers!
    break
}

Pour plus de lisibilit√©, j‚Äôai effectivement export√© les case dans des fonctions qui expriment clairement l‚Äôintention afin de produire un code clair avec cette syntaxe.

Vous conviendrez que la logique est √† pr√©sent un poil plus complexe. Dans ce cas, il est donc judicieux de travailler √† rendre le code plus clair.

Ceci fonctionne, peut se r√©v√©ler utile et n‚Äôa pas d‚Äô√©quivalent avec la method lookup (que je sache).

Cela √©tant, prenez garde aux abus de logique. Ce n‚Äôest pas parce-qu‚Äôon peut le faire, qu‚Äôon doit le faire. Veillez √† garder un esprit critique sur ce que vous fa√Ætes¬†: est-ce vraiment n√©cessaire ou existe-t-il un moyen plus simple¬†? Peut-on trouver design plus clair pour exprimer cette logique¬†?

Parfois on s‚Äôemporte dans des trucs ‚Äúsexy‚Äù, mais un bon KISS ne fait jamais de mal¬†!

Release the (object-oriented) Kraken!

Le method lookup / command pattern est l‚Äô√©quivalent du switch dans un esprit objet. Il tend √† encourager l‚Äô√©criture d‚Äôun code flexible, bien organis√©, orient√©-objet (et √ßa, c‚Äôest bien¬†!).

Si switch ‚Ä¶ case n‚Äôest pas mauvais en soi, il peut s‚Äôav√©rer propice aux erreurs et encourage en soi le spaghetti code. Par sa nature proc√©durale, il peut conduire √† une logique de branche complexe qui r√©sulte souvent dans un mauvais design et donc un code peu difficile √† maintenir.

En fait, il n‚Äôy a pas vraiment de raison d‚Äôutiliser switch plut√¥t que son alternative quand on veut profiter de ce que JavaScript offre. Le principal, c‚Äôest de produire un code clair pour votre future-vous et les autres¬†!

item.title: Private methods with Backbone.js
item.description: Why and how to create private methods. How to concretely implement that while using Backbone.js.
item.content:encoded:
Private method, what is that?
