To keep it short: a private method is a method which is not exposed and can‚Äôt be called ‚Äúfrom the outside‚Äù.

It‚Äôs just a matter of scope after all.

function yolo() {
  var privateMethod = function() {
    console.log("can't be accessed outside of `yolo()`")
  }
  var privateVar = true

  // here, you can call `privateMethod` if you wish to.
  // here, `privateVar` returns `true`.

  return "that's all you've got from me!"
}

// here, `privateMethod` doesn't even exist.
// here, `privateVar` is undefined.

yolo() // returns "that's all you've got from me!"

This notion makes sense with the module pattern.

To learn more on that subject, I‚Äôd strongly recommend this post among others: Mastering the module pattern, simple and efficient.

Well, concretely, here‚Äôs what you‚Äôve got:

var MyModule = (function() {
  // a bunch of encapsulated stuff -> private if not exposed
  var _cantTouchThis = function() {
    console.log('I just met you!')
  }

  var _nbOfCats = 3

  // what you return when the method is executed
  // -> what you expose (= public).
  return {
    nbOfRainbows: 10,
    sayHi: function() {
      console.log('Hi!')
    },
    logNumberOfRainbows: function() {
      console.log(this.nbOfRainbows)
    },
    logNumberOfCats: function() {
      console.log(_nbOfCats)
    },
    touchThis: function() {
      console.log('Hey!')
      _cantTouchThis()
    },
  }
})()

This allow you to manipulate the public part ‚Äî the interface ‚Äî without having access to the private part:

MyModule.nbOfRainbows = 42
MyModule.logNumberOfRainbows() // returns "42"
MyModule.logNumberOfCats() // returns "3"
MyModule.touchThis() // returns "Hey!" "I just met you!"

Private methods‚Ä¶ for what?

That‚Äôs a legitimate question. I personally found 2 advantages of a private method:

  • it simplifies the public interface hiding technical details of the implementation
  • it doesn‚Äôt have to be unit tested

The first point is generally obvious. The second one arises from the first point, but may turn you suspicious. Let me explain‚Ä¶

Unit tests and private methods

To test our module, we instantiate it, then take every single method and check the output for a given input (variable + context). We unitly test the exposed method, taking care to make the input vary to test every use case and get a good test coverage.

We can remind the Test Driven Development (TDD) process:

  • first write the test with required use cases for our functionality
  • then code the method, pass tests
  • refactor code to clean the whole thing. As long as tests pass, you didn‚Äôt break anything.

The refactor step is the last one because we first want to produce something that works, then focus on optimizations.

Let‚Äôs get back to private methods: since they are not exposed, they are not technically unit tested. In fact, not directly.

Some considerations about private methods

The TDD point can leave you suspicious depending on the manner you consider and use the privacy notion. I think there is two ways of doing things:

  1. first code everything as private, then expose what needs to be
  2. private methods came from public methods refactor step

How to choose between private and public?

Considering you‚Äôre doing TDD‚Ä¶ you develop the public interface first ‚Äî that‚Äôs what you‚Äôre testing after all.

Personally, I code my (failing) tests, then my public interface: public methods or event handlers ‚Äî we‚Äôll talk about that few lines below. Nothing private with my code at this point.

Private methods appears during refactor step, at last. And if I don‚Äôt have time for that the code is working, at least.

Finally, unit tests test the public interface.

Private methods are tested through public ones. You may think that testing the detail of technical implementation would be a great idea to ease the debug part, but this would be also a cost to implement and maintain. On the contrary, I can update / refactor private methods as long as my module is still working as expected.

If I have to choose, I‚Äôd prefer to invest in testing more use case. The coverage will tell me if I actually test private methods, passing by.

About events handlers

Public interface matters.

What about events that make our module react? Should event handlers (e.g. onClick() & cie.) be public to be tested?

Well, no.

We‚Äôre talking about events. Our module is listening and reacting upon events. Tests should triggers these events and observe the expected behavior. The binded method could either be public or private, it doesn‚Äôt really matter here as we‚Äôre testing the event.

Prefix with ‚Äù_‚Äù

That‚Äôs a largely adopted convention: prefix private methods / variables names with _.

This is also what I do for 2 reasons:

  1. this is a convention which makes things clear. There is no such a thing than private in JS, but most of developers will understand the prefixed method is ‚Äúsupposed‚Äù private‚Ä¶
  2. this can ease automated documentation plugins work. If you‚Äôre lucky, the doc autocompletion will understand the method is private and won‚Äôt forget about the @private.

Finally, it‚Äôs about readability. The private nature of the _joke() method is explicit.

However, it‚Äôs a common practice that this convention is used to try to define the private nature of a method, instead of just make it explicit. That means the public interface is composed with methods prefixed with _ to tell those should be considered as private.

This is a hot point, with a lot of debates. On my own experience, this is generally something which appears when you don‚Äôt really know how to really set up privacy. Everything is public then, but you tell some methods are private by intention.

It‚Äôs relatively easy to introduce privacy with the module pattern in fact. Then, my advice would be to consider everything that is exposed as public. If you actually want a method to be private, let‚Äôs make it actually private and use the _ prefix for code readability.

That said, projects should define and follow convention that fit their need.

It‚Äôs not part of the prototype‚Ä¶ what about inheritance and performance?

That‚Äôs true. As long as it is not reachable, a private method can‚Äôt be inherited. This is basically why I consider private method as a way to simplify the exposed interface of my module. If I need the implementation detail, if I need to access it by inheritance, then I need this detail to be public.

Here again, scepticism is not really caused because of the nature of private methods, but because of a clumsy interpretation / implementation of these.

A note on performance: there will be as much private methods as instances of the module, which is technically less performant. But, having look the actual impact, I think this remark belongs to premature optimization for my current use of privacy.

How do I access public methods from private ones?

That could be blocking.

In fact, if my private method came from a public method refactor, this is not blocking at all. Just because my private method is meant to simplify the public interface, to make the public method more readable.

From my point of view, the private method is kind of a own helper for the module, which helps him to perform its job. Every variable the method needs should be passed as parameters.

Doing so, you can even pass the public interface context to the private method:

var MyModule = (function() {
  var _addSomeCats = function(context) {
    context.cats++
    context.logNumberOfCats()
  }

  return {
    cats: 1,
    addSomeCats: function() {
      // This is not really useful to wrap the whole thing in
      // a private method, but that's a way to illustrate how
      // you can pass it the context.
      _addSomeCats(this)
    },
    logNumberOfCats: function() {
      console.log(this.cats)
    },
  }
})()

Will give you:

MyModule.addSomeCats() // returns "2"

In this example, I‚Äôm passing the context as a parameter.

Actually, it‚Äôs possible to use this in the _addSomeCats method and then call it with the context bound, thanks to .call() this way: _addSomeCats.call( this );.

Previous example is not a such a big deal, but here‚Äôs what it could looks like in an actual project:

var MyModule = (function() {
  // alt. syntax for `var _createViewInstance = function() { ‚Ä¶ }`.
  // we refactor here some repetitive tasks of the module.
  function _createViewInstance(View, $parent) {
    if (!View) throw new Error('No View constructor provided')
    if (!$parent) throw new Error('No $parent provided')

    var view = new View()
    view.$el.appendTo($parent)
    view.render()

    return view
  }
  // ‚Ä¶

  return {
    onRender: function() {
      try {
        this.ordersView = _createViewInstance(this.OrdersView, $('#orders'))
      } catch (err) {
        app.err(err) // -> our way to log errors that would occur
        this.ordersView = {}
      }

      // a bunch of other stuff‚Ä¶
    },

    // ‚Ä¶
  }
})()

Which leads you directly to Backbone.js.

Implementation with Backbone.js

This is the main reason for this post. After you understood the concept and mastered the way you set up actual privacy with a module, you could end up puzzled on how to implement that when you usually deal with this:

var MyModule = (function() {
  var Books = {}

  Books.Model = Backbone.Model.extend({
    // a bit of configuration‚Ä¶

    isPrivate: function() {
      console.log('certainly not‚Ä¶')
      return false
    },

    _intendedToBePrivate: function() {
      // kind of method that would pop with this implementation.
    },
  })

  // ‚Ä¶

  return Books
})()

Finally, it‚Äôs that simple: .extend() will accept an object. Alright, let‚Äôs give him an IIFE that will return this object ‚Äî its API.

var MyModule = (function() {
  var Books = {}

  var ModelConfiguration = (function() {
    var _actuallyPrivate = function() {
      console.log("look 'ma, I'm private!")
    }

    // expose the configuration.
    return {
      defaults: {
        isCompleted: false,
      },

      urlRoot: '/order',

      isCompleted: function() {
        _actuallyPrivate()
        return this.get('isCompleted')
      },
    }
  })()

  Books.Model = Backbone.Model.extend(ModelConfiguration)

  // ‚Ä¶

  return Books
})()

Last words

Private methods in JavaScript is a subject that can feeds a lot of debates and one can remain skeptical about that. Sometimes ‚Äî often? ‚Äî it makes the whole thing more complex. That‚Äôs why I think every project should adopt the position that correspond the best to their needs.

For my part, I create private methods during refactor step. If the method is public by nature, I‚Äôll treat it as such: no _ prefix, unit tests. The most important thing for me is not fooling myself with a convention.

However, I struggled for some time to imagine how it could work using Backbone.js. As it takes me some time to work the whole thing out, here is my contribution post to help those who may enter the same reflexion I‚Äôve had.

That said, this is a subject full of debates and interesting reflexions. Don‚Äôt hesitate to share suggestions and remarks if you‚Äôre passing by!

item.title: Fonctions priv√©es avec Backbone.js
item.description: Pourquoi et comment faire des fonctions priv√©es. Et concr√®tement, comment impl√©menter √ßa tout en utilisant Backbone.js.
item.content:encoded:
Fonctions priv√©es, c‚Äôest-√†-dire¬†?

Pour faire simple et concis¬†: une fonction / m√©thode priv√©e est une m√©thode qui n‚Äôest pas expos√©e et ne peut donc pas √™tre appel√©e ‚Äúde l‚Äôext√©rieur‚Äù.

Il s‚Äôagit donc d‚Äôune notion de port√©e, ni plus ni moins.

function yolo() {
  var privateMethod = function() {
    console.log("can't be accessed outside of `yolo()`")
  }
  var privateVar = true

  // ici, on peut appeler `privateMethod` si √ßa nous chante.
  // ici, `privateVar` vaut `true`.

  return "that's all you've got from me!"
}

// ici, `privateMethod` n'existe pas.
// ici, `privateVar` n'est pas d√©fini.

yolo() // affiche "that's all you've got from me!"

Cette notion prend tout son sens lorsqu‚Äôon utilise le module pattern.

Pour en savoir plus sur ce point, je vous recommande cet article parmi tous les autres¬†: Mastering the module pattern, simple et efficace.

Et donc concr√®tement, √ßa donne ce genre de code¬†:

var MyModule = (function() {
  // tout un tas de trucs encapsul√©s -> priv√©s si pas expos√©s.
  var _cantTouchThis = function() {
    console.log('I just met you!')
  }

  var _nbOfCats = 3

  // ce que l'on retourne lorsque la fonction est ex√©cut√©e
  // -> ce qu'on expose (= public).
  return {
    nbOfRainbows: 10,
    sayHi: function() {
      console.log('Hi!')
    },
    logNumberOfRainbows: function() {
      console.log(this.nbOfRainbows)
    },
    logNumberOfCats: function() {
      console.log(_nbOfCats)
    },
    touchThis: function() {
      console.log('Hey!')
      _cantTouchThis()
    },
  }
})()

Ceci nous permet donc de toucher √† la partie publique, l‚Äôinterface, sans pour autant avoir acc√®s √† la partie priv√©e¬†:

MyModule.nbOfRainbows = 42
MyModule.logNumberOfRainbows() // affiche "42"
MyModule.logNumberOfCats() // affiche "3"
MyModule.touchThis() // affiche "Hey!" "I just met you!"

Fonctions priv√©es‚Ä¶ Et pour quoi faire¬†?

Question l√©gitime. Personnellement, je vois l‚Äôint√©r√™t d‚Äôune fonction priv√©e ainsi¬†:

  • elle simplifie l‚Äôinterface publique en s‚Äôoccupant des d√©tails techniques d‚Äôimpl√©mentation
  • elle n‚Äôa pas √† √™tre test√©e unitairement

Le premier point coule g√©n√©ralement de source. Le second point d√©coule du premier, mais rend souvent perplexe. Je m‚Äôexplique‚Ä¶

Tests unitaires et fonctions priv√©es

Pour tester notre module, on l‚Äôinstancie, puis on va prendre chacune de ses m√©thodes et v√©rifier leur sortie √† partir d‚Äôune entr√©e (variables + contexte). On teste unitairement les m√©thodes expos√©es en prenant garde de faire varier l‚Äôentr√©e pour tester tous les cas de figure et obtenir une bonne couverture de tests.

On peut d‚Äôailleurs r√©sumer la pratique du Test Driven Development (TDD)¬†:

  • √©crire d‚Äôabord le test avec les cas de figures requis pour une fonctionnalit√©
  • coder la m√©thode afin de passer ces tests
  • retravailler le code √† la fin pour le nettoyer. Tant que les tests passent on sait qu‚Äôon n‚Äôa rien cass√©.

L‚Äô√©tape de refactor vient en dernier car l‚Äôobjectif est de produire un code qui fonctionne, puis de faire des optimisations.

Pour revenir √† la question des m√©thodes priv√©es¬†: elles ne sont pas expos√©es, donc techniquement elles ne sont pas test√©es unitairement. Pas directement en fait.

Quelques consid√©rations sur les fonctions priv√©es

Le point sur les tests unitaires peut laisser perplexe selon la mani√®re dont on consid√®re et utilise la notion de fonction priv√©e. Je dirais qu‚Äôil y a 2 fa√ßons de voir les choses¬†:

  1. je code tout en priv√© et j‚Äôexpose que ce qui doit l‚Äô√™tre in fine
  2. les fonctions priv√©es sont le fruit du refactor de mes fonctions publiques

Comment choisir entre priv√© et public¬†?

Si on consid√®re que l‚Äôon fait du TDD‚Ä¶ on d√©veloppe l‚Äôinterface publique avant (puisque c‚Äôest ce que testent les tests).

Personnellement, je code mes tests (qui ne passent pas), puis mon interface publique¬†: les m√©thodes publiques ou les event handlers (petit point l√†-dessus plus bas, pour ceux qui s‚Äôinterrogent). Rien de priv√© chez moi √† ce stade.

Les fonctions priv√©es proviennent de l‚Äô√©tape de refactor, finalement. Et puis si je n‚Äôai pas le temps de nettoyer, au moins √ßa marche.

Finalement, les tests unitaires testent l‚Äôinterface publique.

Les m√©thodes priv√©es sont test√©es √† travers les m√©thodes publiques. On peut se dire que tester le d√©tail de l‚Äôimpl√©mentation technique serait judicieux pour mieux debugguer, mais c‚Äôest un co√ªt d‚Äôimpl√©mentation et de maintenance cons√©quent. √Ä l‚Äôinverse, je peux ici modifier / refactor mes m√©thodes priv√©es autant que je veux tant que mon module fonctionne.

√Ä choisir¬†: autant tester plus de sc√©narios sur l‚Äôinterface publique. La coverage indiquera si oui ou non on teste les m√©thodes priv√©es en passant.

Le cas des events handlers

L‚Äôinterface publique, c‚Äôest donc ce qui compte.

Qu‚Äôen est-il des √©v√©nements qui font r√©agir notre module¬†? Les events handlers (= onClick() & co) doivent-elles √™tre publiques pour pouvoir √™tre test√©es¬†?

En fait, non.

On parle d‚Äô√©v√©nements. Notre module √©coute des √©v√©nements et r√©agit en fonction. Les tests doivent donc d√©clencher le comportement en √©mettant les √©v√©nements, puis en observant le r√©sultat attendu (impact sur le syst√®me, etc.). La m√©thode li√©e peut bien √™tre publique ou priv√©e, ce n‚Äôest pas ce qui compte au moment o√π l‚Äôon teste la mani√®re dont le module r√©pond √† l‚Äô√©v√©nement.

Pr√©fixer avec ‚Äù_‚Äù

Par convention (assez r√©pandue), on pr√©fixe les noms des m√©thodes / variables priv√©es avec un _.

C‚Äôest √©galement ce que je fais pour 2 raisons¬†:

  1. c‚Äôest une convention qui pr√©sente l‚Äôavantage de se d√©marquer. On n‚Äôa pas de private en JS, mais la plupart comprendront qu‚Äôon parle l√† d‚Äôune fonction ‚Äúsuppos√©e‚Äù priv√©e‚Ä¶
  2. cela facilite le travail de documentation automatique. Souvent, par convention, l‚Äôautocompletion consid√©rera cette fonction comme priv√©e et n‚Äôoubliera pas de mettre @private. √áa vaut ce que √ßa vaut, en tout cas √ßa ne co√ªte rien \o/

C‚Äôest donc personnellement une consid√©ration de clart√©. La nature priv√©e de la m√©thode _joke() saute plus facilement aux yeux.

En revanche, il est assez commun que cette convention soit utilis√©e pour tenter de d√©finir la nature priv√©e d‚Äôune m√©thode au lieu de la mettre en valeur. C‚Äôest-√†-dire que l‚Äôinterface publique expos√©e est compos√©e de m√©thodes dont certaines sont pr√©fix√©es avec _ pour indiquer que celles-ci doivent √™tre consid√©r√©es comme priv√©es.

C‚Äôest un point qui g√©n√®re de nombreux d√©bats. D‚Äôapr√®s mon exp√©rience personnelle, c‚Äôest g√©n√©ralement quelque chose qui est mis en place quand on ne sait pas trop comment on fait pour v√©ritablement mettre en place des m√©thodes priv√©es. Du coup tout est public, mais on indique que certaines sont priv√©es par intention.

En pratique, il est assez simple de mettre en place des m√©thodes priv√©es avec le module pattern. Tant qu‚Äô√† faire, je conseille donc de partir du principe que tout ce qui est expos√© est public. Si on souhaite qu‚Äôune fonction soit priv√©e, alors autant l‚Äô√©crire comme telle et utiliser le pr√©fixe _ simplement pour la lisibilit√© du code.

Cela √©tant, √† chaque projet de d√©finir et suivre ses conventions selon ses besoins.

C‚Äôest pas dans le prototype‚Ä¶ du coup pour l‚Äôh√©ritage et la performance¬†?

Effectivement, √©tant donn√© qu‚Äôelle n‚Äôest pas accessible, une m√©thode priv√©e ne peut pas √™tre surcharg√©e. C‚Äôest la raison pour laquelle je consid√®re les m√©thodes priv√©es comme un moyen de simplifier l‚Äôinterface expos√©e de mon module. Si j‚Äôai besoin du d√©tail de l‚Äôimpl√©mentation, que je dois pouvoir y acc√©der en h√©ritant ma classe, alors j‚Äôai besoin que ce d√©tail soit public.

L√† encore, le scepticisme n‚Äôest pas tellement caus√© la nature des m√©thodes priv√©es en soi, mais plut√¥t √† une interpr√©tation / impl√©mentation maladroite de celles-ci.

On notera √©galement le point sur la performance¬†: il y aura autant de fonctions priv√©es que d‚Äôinstances de mon module, ce qui est techniquement moins performant. Mais en analysant effectivement l‚Äôimpact, cette remarque rel√®ve de l‚Äôordre de l‚Äôoptimisation pr√©coce dans mon utilisation des m√©thodes priv√©es, pour le moment.

Et comment j‚Äôacc√®de √† mes m√©thodes publiques depuis mes m√©thodes priv√©es¬†?

Ceci peut √™tre un point de blocage.

En fait, si ma fonction priv√©e provient d‚Äôun refactor de ma m√©thode publique, ce n‚Äôen est plus un. Tout simplement parce-que ma m√©thode priv√©e a pour r√¥le de simplifier l‚Äôinterface publique, c‚Äôest-√†-dire de rendre plus lisible ma m√©thode publique.

J‚Äôenvisage donc la m√©thode priv√©e comme un ‚Äúhelper‚Äù personnel du module, dont il se sert pour faire son travail. Toutes les variables dont la m√©thode a besoin lui son donc pass√©es en param√®tre.

Ainsi, on peut simplement envisager de passer le contexte de l‚Äôinterface publique √† la m√©thode priv√©e¬†:

var MyModule = (function() {
  var _addSomeCats = function(context) {
    context.cats++
    context.logNumberOfCats()
  }

  return {
    cats: 1,
    addSomeCats: function() {
      // En soi cela n'a pas grand int√©r√™t ici de tout envoyer
      // dans une m√©thode priv√©e, mais c'est pour illustrer la
      // mani√®re dont on passe le contexte.
      _addSomeCats(this)
    },
    logNumberOfCats: function() {
      console.log(this.cats)
    },
  }
})()

Ce qui donnera¬†:

MyModule.addSomeCats() // affiche "2"

Dans cet exemple, le contexte est pass√© en param√®tre.

En pratique, il est possible d‚Äôutiliser this dans la m√©thode _addSomeCats et de l‚Äôappeller en lui passant le contexte avec .call() ainsi¬†: _addSomeCats.call(this).

L‚Äôexemple pr√©c√©dent ne pr√©sente pas un grand int√©r√™t, mais concr√®tement cela peut se pr√©senter de la mani√®re suivante dans un projet¬†:

var MyModule = (function() {
  // syntaxe alternative de `var _createViewInstance = function() { ‚Ä¶ }`.
  // on a refactor ici quelques t√¢ches r√©p√©titives du module.
  function _createViewInstance(View, $parent) {
    if (!View) throw new Error('No View constructor provided')
    if (!$parent) throw new Error('No $parent provided')

    var view = new View()
    view.$el.appendTo($parent)
    view.render()

    return view
  }

  // ‚Ä¶

  return {
    onRender: function() {
      try {
        this.ordersView = _createViewInstance(this.OrdersView, $('#orders'))
      } catch (err) {
        app.err(err) // -> notre fa√ßon de log les erreurs qui peuvent subvenir
        this.ordersView = {}
      }

      // un tas d'autres trucs‚Ä¶
    },

    // ‚Ä¶
  }
})()

Ce qui nous am√®ne effectivement √† Backbone.js.

Impl√©mentation avec Backbone.js

C‚Äôest le point qui fut pour moi la cause de cet article. En effet, apr√®s avoir assimil√© le concept et bien visualis√© sa mise en place avec un module, on peut rester perplexe sur la mani√®re de l‚Äôimpl√©menter quand on √† l‚Äôhabitude de ceci¬†:

var MyModule = (function() {
  var Books = {}

  Books.Model = Backbone.Model.extend({
    // un peu de configuration‚Ä¶

    isPrivate: function() {
      console.log('certainly not‚Ä¶')
      return false
    },

    _intendedToBePrivate: function() {
      // le genre de m√©thode qui appara√Æt dans ce genre de situation.
    },
  })

  // ‚Ä¶

  return Books
})()

Finalement, le principe est simple¬†: .extend() prend un objet en param√®tre. Qu‚Äô√† cela ne tienne, on peut lui envoyer une IIFE qui lui retourne un objet (son API).

var MyModule = (function() {
  var Books = {}

  var ModelConfiguration = (function() {
    var _actuallyPrivate = function() {
      console.log("look 'ma, I'm private!")
    }

    // on expose la configuration.
    return {
      defaults: {
        isCompleted: false,
      },

      urlRoot: '/order',

      isCompleted: function() {
        _actuallyPrivate()
        return this.get('isCompleted')
      },
    }
  })()

  Books.Model = Backbone.Model.extend(ModelConfiguration)

  // ‚Ä¶

  return Books
})()

Pour conclure

La question des fonctions priv√©es et de leur int√©r√™t fait toujours d√©bat et peut laisser sceptique. Parfois (souvent¬†?), √ßa complique plus le schmilblick qu‚Äôautre chose. Aussi, chaque projet doit trouver midi √† sa porte et adopter la position qui lui convient.

En ce qui me concerne, je cr√©e des m√©thodes priv√©es lors de mes op√©rations de refactor. Si la m√©thode est publique par nature, je la traite comme telle¬†: pas de pr√©fixe _, des tests unitaires. Le plus important pour moi, c‚Äôest de ne pas me leurrer avec une convention.

Quoiqu‚Äôil en soit, je me suis questionn√© un bon moment pour comprendre comment cela pouvait se traduire en utilisant Backbone.js. Et comme j‚Äôai eu du mal √† faire le d√©clic, je me suis fendu de cet article pour aider les prochains qui entreront dans les m√™mes r√©flexions que j‚Äôai pu avoir.

Cela √©tant, c‚Äôest un point √† d√©bats et √† r√©flexions. N‚Äôh√©sitez donc pas, je suis preneur de suggestions et remarques √† ce sujet¬†!

item.title: Clean your git repo, like a boss
item.description: How to properly rebase your repo, removing what should never have been in there without broking your history.
item.content:encoded:
The context

The life of a git repo could last and change a lot. Conventions often move with our knowledge and mastering of that stuff.

And there comes the day where you look at your project and realize that it wasn‚Äôt such a good idea to commit those external libraries / compiled outputs / videos and other media / <your error here>.

I personally did a bunch of mistakes with git:

  • one day I realized a bit late that if you commit a lot of audio files in your project, then you‚Äôll make it grow insanely. 5 minutes to perform a simple git clone is waaaaaay toooo looooooong.
  • few time ago, I even managed to commit the whole vendor/ folder of a project by mistake. It didn‚Äôt play well with the nice GitHub stats of the project. That‚Äôs a tough job to follow the activity of the team when there is a 20.000 updates peak on the very first week.

And then you realize that:

  • it‚Äôs pointless to revert the faulty commit(s), it won‚Äôt remove the indexed modifications from the history
  • the project may not be young, it‚Äôd be sad to rebase and re-write every commits from the last 3 months and loose information such as the author / the date
  • and even sometimes you‚Äôll have your faulty files committed with other fixes and killer-features

Need another use case? Just think about Bernard who committed confidential information in a environment config file which should never have been versioned -have you heard about a guy called Murphy?.

Now you can figure out that situation when you open the Internet, searching for the magic git command. Here you go, this is precisely what‚Äôs this post about -at least, the magic command I know.

Magic happens here

Let‚Äôs say I would like to remove every MP3 files committed by mistake from a whole project. Plus, I don‚Äôt want to change the author of each commit, neither the date - but still I want to remove all trace from those files in the history to reduce the size of my repo.

To do so, I mystically wave my hand in the air and write the following incantation with the other:

git filter-branch -f --tree-filter "rm -rf \*.mp3" --prune-empty -- --all

Which would transform this history:

Into this clean and shiny one:

Dates and authors are still there, which wouldn‚Äôt have been true with a classic rebase. Still, the history has been rewritten: SHA1 of commits which have been rewritten are different.

It‚Äôs a kind of magic

Let‚Äôs see what is this looooong mystical command about.

git filter-branch

The filter-branch command will rewrite a large number of commit in a scriptable way. In other words, it will rewrite the history regarding the options you give.

-f

The -f option forces git filter-branch to start even if there is an existing temporary refs/original/ directory already. Git will use this directory to perform some backup before going further.

It‚Äôs not mandatory then, but if the backup can‚Äôt be created, git will tell you to use it anyway.

--tree-filter "<shell command>"

This option will check every commit of your tree and execute the given shell command.

I previously used rm -rf *.mp3 to ensure there will not be any MP3 file surviving this operation. In this case, I needed to ensure the command is forced -this is for the -rf part- so the cleaning won‚Äôt stop if there is an error because of no-mp3-file-in-this-commit reason.

Note - In case you don‚Äôt want to actually delete these files but just remove them from the git history, prefer to perform a ‚Äîindex-filter ‚Äúgit rm -rf ‚Äîcached ‚Äîignore-unmatch *.mp3‚Äù instead.

--prune-empty

We prune any commit that would eventually be empty after we cleaned the history.

-- --all

The first -- will ensure we don‚Äôt consider --all as a parameter for --prune-empty, but as another option. And so git will consider every branches of the history to perform the cleaning here.

Final words

If you‚Äôre many to work on the project, please remember that rewrite the history is not a genuine action, whatever the method you use. Then, if you really need to do that kind of manipulation, it will be easier for you colleagues to simply clone the new shiny repo.

If you fear that your manipulation won‚Äôt work as expected, just clone the repo somewhere else before doing your stuff. So you‚Äôd be able to get it back in case something is going wrong.

Note - A good idea is to perform that kind of operations in another branch. If you‚Äôre satisfied with the result, just reset hard the master branch onto this one and you‚Äôre all set.

Here you go. I hope that could help you‚Ä¶ but that you won‚Äôt need to use it too often!

item.title: Nettoyer son d√©p√¥t git, like a boss
item.description: Ou comment rebase proprement son d√©p√¥t pour retirer ce qui n'aurait jamais du y √™tre commit, tout en conservant l'historique (si si, c'est possible).
item.content:encoded:
Le contexte

Un d√©p√¥t git, √† l‚Äôimage du projet qu‚Äôil contient, peut avoir une vie longue et tumultueuse au cours de laquelle les conventions √©voluent avec nos connaissances et notre ma√Ætrise du schmilblick.

Aussi, il se peut que ce jour arrive o√π vous contempliez votre projet et r√©alisiez qu‚Äôen fait non, ce n‚Äô√©tait pas une si bonne id√©e que de versionner ces librairies externes / fichiers compil√©s / vid√©os et autres assets / <votre boulette ici>.

Pour ma part, j‚Äôai pas mal encha√Æn√© les boulettes avec le temps¬†:

  • une fois, j‚Äôai r√©alis√© un peu tard que versionner un paquet de fichiers audio dans un projet l‚Äôalourdissait de mani√®re ind√©cente. 5 minutes pour faire un git clone, c‚Äôest un peu ouate-ze-foque.
  • il n‚Äôy a pas si longtemps encore, j‚Äôai m√™me r√©ussit √† versionner l‚Äôensemble du dossier vendor/ d‚Äôun projet s‚Äôen m‚Äôen rendre compte. Et vlan les jolies stats GitHub du projet ; difficile de suivre son activit√© quand on a un pic de 20.000 modifications la premi√®re semaine.

Or c‚Äôest dans ce genre de cas qu‚Äôon r√©alise que¬†:

  • il est inutile de revert le(s) commit(s) fautif(s), √ßa ne supprimera pas les modifications index√©es dans l‚Äôhistorique
  • le projet n‚Äôest plus tout jeune, √ßa nous ferait mal de rebase les commits des 3 derniers mois et perdre l‚Äôauteur / la date de ceux-ci en les r√©-√©crivant
  • et m√™me que parfois on a commit ses fichiers fautifs par-ci par-l√† au milieu d‚Äôautres modifications d‚Äôun beau commit

Un dernier cas de figure¬†? Suffit d‚Äôimaginer Bernard qui, s‚Äôen trop le vouloir, a commit par erreur des informations un peu confidentielles dans un fichier de conf d‚Äôenvironnement qui n‚Äôaurait jamais du √™tre versionn√© (sisi, √ßa arrive).

Bref, c‚Äôest dans ce genre de situation qu‚Äôon se r√©signe ou que l‚Äôon retourne l‚ÄôInternet en qu√™te de la commande git magique. Et √ßa tombe plut√¥t bien, parce-que c‚Äôest celle-l√† m√™me que je vais vous proposer (enfin celle que je connais).

Magic happens here

Admettons par exemple que je souhaite supprimer tous les MP3s versionn√©s par erreur dans l‚Äôensemble de mon projet. Et ce, sans changer les auteurs des commits, ni m√™me les dates, mais en supprimant tout de m√™me toute trace de ces fichiers (histoire de r√©duire consid√©rablement la taille de mon d√©p√¥t, par exemple).

Et donc pour cela, j‚Äôouvre mon terminal et je lance l‚Äôincantation suivante¬†:

git filter-branch -f --tree-filter "rm -rf \*.mp3" --prune-empty -- --all

Ce qui me permet donc, en partant de ce genre d‚Äôhistorique¬†:

De me retrouver avec un d√©p√¥t propre comme un sous neuf¬†:

Les dates de commit sont conserv√©es, les auteurs aussi, ce qui ne serait pas le cas avec un rebase classique. Toutefois, l‚Äôhistorique est bel et bien r√©-√©crit¬†: les SHA1 des commits qui ont √©t√© modifi√©s sont diff√©rents.

C‚Äôest sorcellerie¬†!?

Voyons un peu ce que ce que cache cette loooongue commande magico-magique.

git filter-branch

La commande filter-branch de git permet de r√©-√©crire un grand nombre de commits de mani√®re scriptable. Autrement dit, c‚Äôest ce qui va permettre de r√©-√©crire compl√®tement l‚Äôhistorique en fonction des param√®tres que nous allons passer ensuite.

-f

L‚Äôoption -f permet de forcer le d√©marrage de git filter-branch si jamais il y a d√©j√† un dossier temporaire refs/original/ pr√©-existant. Git s‚Äôen sert pour faire une sauvegarde de l‚Äôhistorique avant de partir √† l‚Äôaventure.

Le -f n‚Äôest donc pas obligatoire mais si le backup ne peut pas √™tre cr√©√©, git vous dira de relancer la commande avec cette option.

--tree-filter "<shell command>"

Cette option va vous permettre de passer en revue chacun de vos commits et d‚Äôy ex√©cuter la commande que vous aurez pass√© en param√®tre.

Pour ma part, j‚Äôai utilis√© rm -rf *.mp3 pour m‚Äôassurer de bien supprimer l‚Äôensemble des fichiers MP3s qui pouvaient √™tre versionn√©s. Dans un tel cas, il faut s‚Äôassurer de forcer la commande (d‚Äôo√π le -rf) car le nettoyage s‚Äôarr√™te s‚Äôil y a une erreur √† base de fichier-mp3-non-trouv√©-dans-ce-commit.

Note - Au cas o√π vous ne voudriez pas vraiment supprimer les fichiers mais juste les retirer de l‚Äôhistorique git, pr√©f√©rez l‚Äôutilisation de la commande ‚Äîindex-filter ‚Äúgit rm -rf ‚Äîcached ‚Äîignore-unmatch *.mp3‚Äù √† la place.

--prune-empty

On s‚Äôassure de bien supprimer les commits qui seraient √©ventuellement vides, une fois l‚Äôhistorique nettoy√©.

-- --all

Le premier -- permet de distinguer --all comme une options suppl√©mentaire, et non pas un param√®tre de --prune-empty. Et donc cela permet de dire √† git de r√©aliser son op√©ration sur toutes les branches de l‚Äôhistorique.

Le mot de la fin

Si vous travaillez √† plusieurs sur le projet, n‚Äôoubliez pas que r√©-√©crire l‚Äôhistorique, c‚Äôest pas anodin (et ce, peu importe la m√©thode). Du coup, si vous √™tes amen√© √† faire ce genre de manipulation pour le bien du d√©p√¥t, le plus simple reste pour les autres de re-cloner le nouveau d√©p√¥t tout propre, tout simplement.

Et si vous craigniez que votre manipulation ne fonctionne pas comme pr√©vu, clonez simplement le d√©p√¥t quelque part avant de faire votre tambouille et vous pourrez toujours le r√©cup√©rer si jamais √ßa ne se passe pas bien.

Note - Une bonne id√©e serait de faire ce genre d‚Äôop√©rations dans un branche √† part. Si le r√©sultat est convaincant, alors il n‚Äôy aura plus qu‚Äô√† faire un reset hard de master sur cette branche.

Voil√†, en esp√©rant que √ßa puisse vous d√©panner‚Ä¶ mais que vous n‚Äôayez pas √† vous en servir trop souvent¬†!

item.title: Multilingual blog with Jekyll 1.5
item.description: What changed with Jekyll v1.5.1 if you want to build a multilingual blog.
item.content:encoded:
Note on compatibility

This post considers you‚Äôre using Jekyll v1.5.1.

It‚Äôs an extension to my previous post from April 2013 in which I explained how I managed to build this English-French blog. There have been a bunch of new versions of Jekyll since. I‚Äôll explain here how to change the previous implementation accordingly.

Few reminders about Jekyll

After almost one year using it - even though I didn‚Äôt write that much post these months - here is what I could take from Jekyll:

  • this is the simplest solution to build a front-end website with the ease of compilation (templates, plugins, etc.). The fact that GitHub takes in charge the compilation helps that point of view, for sure
  • it takes advantages and inconveniences from Ruby on Rails - the beauty of the language, the nightmare of the version upgrade
  • writing posts in Markdown is a no-brainer
  • if standard behavior doesn‚Äôt fit our needs, we could also override it with our own plugins

Keep in mind that if you‚Äôre using plugins, you should compile the website by yourself before sending the static version to GitHub.

Speaking Fran√ßais, ze retour

As a reminder, here is my blog architecture:

.
|-- _data/ # Variables and configuration
|-- _includes/ # Partials included in other files
|-- _layouts/ # Templates of the website
|-- _plugins/ # Plugins to override Jekyll workflow
|-- assets/ # LESS/CSS, JS, images, ‚Ä¶
|-- fr/ # French category
| |-- _posts/ # French posts
| |-- index.html # French html files
| |-- about.html
| |-- (‚Ä¶)
|
|-- en/ # English category
| |-- _posts/ # English posts
|
|-- index.html # Default html files (EN)
|-- about.html
|-- (‚Ä¶)
|-- _config.yml # Jekyll configuration file

Jekyll compile sources and will output them into _site/ folder. This version is sent to GitHub.

Note - I removed from _config.yml language-dependent variables that I can use in my templates‚Ä¶

They are now properly isolated into the _data/locales.yml file.

For sure, upgrading Jekyll from v0.12 to v1.5 leads to some modifications of the config.yml file in order to remove what was deprecated and add what was necessary.

Then come plugins‚Ä¶

Plugins, what has changed here

1. Per-category pagination

This is THE plugin that needed to be changed as Jekyll pagination workflow changed completely.

I didn‚Äôt find anything convincing enough, so I wrote my own category_pagination.rb plugin.

Just add it to your _plugins/ folder, then configure your config.yml regarding your needs:

  • paginate_per_category: true if you wish to activate the plugin
  • default_category: "en" (optional) if you wish the root pagination to be the one of a specific category

The plugin is pretty straightforward:

  1. if I want to paginate a category (aka folder),
  2. pagination will only consider posts from this category,
  3. I can define a default category for files that are at the root of the project (otherwise I‚Äôd paginate everything).

You can have a look to the fr/index.html page.

Note - This is a first draw that could be used as a simple - and opiniated - per-category pagination. Don‚Äôt hesitate to suggest improvements =)

2. I18n filter

i18n_filter.rb customize the treatment of page.date variable, regarding the language.

I‚Äôve had to add a _locales/fr.yml file in order to create the localize function. It works just like the date method, but output the french format for the date.

Et voil√†!

Nothing has really changed, just few corrections to set and it‚Äôs done. If you have any suggestion, remark or issue with that, just drop me a line.

Plop!

item.title: Un blog multilingue avec Jekyll 1.5
item.description: Retour sur la r√©alisation d'un blog multilingue avec Jekyll, apr√®s upgrade √† la v1.5.1.
item.content:encoded:
Note sur la compatibilit√©

Ce qui suit se base sur l‚Äôutilisation de Jekyll v1.5.1.

Ce post fait suite √† celui de Mai 2013 o√π je vous faisais mon retour d‚Äôexp√©rience sur la cr√©ation d‚Äôun blog en plusieurs langue. Depuis Jekyll a (s√©rieusement) mont√© en versions et voici les correctifs √† apporter en ce sens.

Petit rappels sur Jekyll

Apr√®s bient√¥t une ann√©e d‚Äôutilisation (quoiqu‚Äôayant √©crit peu d‚Äôarticles ces derniers mois), voil√† ce que je retiens de Jekyll¬†:

  • c‚Äôest la solution la plus simple pour r√©aliser un site web front-end avec le confort de la compilation (templates, plugins, etc.). Bien entendu, le fait que GitHub le prenne en charge nativement joue beaucoup en ce sens.
  • il b√©n√©ficie des avantages et inconv√©nients de Ruby on Rails (la beaut√© du langage, la prise de t√™te de la mont√©e en versions)
  • √©crire ses articles en Markdown, c‚Äôest vraiment pratique
  • si le fonctionnement standard ne nous convient pas, libre √† nous de le surcharger avec nos propres plugins

En revanche, si vous √©laborez vous-m√™me vos plugins, il vous faudra compiler tout d‚Äôabord votre site pour envoyer la version statique sur GitHub.

Speaking Fran√ßais, ze retour

Pour rappel, voici √† quoi ressemble l‚Äôarchitecture de mon blog¬†:

.
|-- _data/ # Stock de variables et configuration
|-- _includes/ # Bouts de codes inclus ailleurs
|-- _layouts/ # Templates du site
|-- _plugins/ # Plugins pour surcharger de Jekyll
|-- assets/ # LESS/CSS, JS, images, ‚Ä¶
|-- fr/ # Categorie FR
| |-- _posts/ # Articles en fran√ßais
| |-- index.html # Pages html en fran√ßais
| |-- about.html
| |-- (‚Ä¶)
|
|-- en/ # Cat√©gorie EN
| |-- _posts/ # Articles en anglais
|
|-- index.html # Pages html par d√©faut (EN)
|-- about.html
|-- (‚Ä¶)
|-- _config.yml # Fichier de configuration de Jekyll

Lorsqu‚Äôil est lanc√©, Jekyll g√©n√®re le site statique final dans le dossier _site/. C‚Äôest cette version qui est envoy√©e (et servie) sur GitHub.

Note - J‚Äôai retir√© de _config.yml les variables qui d√©pendent de la langue et que je r√©utilise dans les templates.

Elles sont d√©sormais isol√©es proprement dans le fichier _data/locales.yml.

Naturellement, mettre √† jour Jekyll de la v0.12 √† la v1.5 a n√©cessit√© quelques arrangements dans le fichier config.yml, histoire de retirer ce qui √©tait depreci√© et ajouter ce qui manquait.

Egalement, il a fallu toucher aux plugins‚Ä¶

Les plugins, ce qui a chang√©

1. Pagination par cat√©gorie

C‚Äôest LE plugin qu‚Äôil a fallu modifier, le fonctionnement de la pagination ayant radicalement chang√© avec Jekyll.

N‚Äôayant rien trouv√© de convaincant, j‚Äôai r√©-√©crit mon propre plugin category_pagination.rb.

Ajoutez-le simplement √† votre dossier _plugins/, puis configurez votre config.yml en fonction du comportement attendu¬†:

  • paginate_per_category: true si vous souhaitez activer le plugin
  • default_category: "en" (optionnel) si vous souhaitez que la pagination √† la racine du projet ne prenne pas en compte tous les posts, mais uniquement ceux d‚Äôune cat√©gorie

Le plugin fonctionne tr√®s simplement¬†:

  1. si je cherche √† paginer √† l‚Äôint√©rieur d‚Äôune cat√©gorie (aka dossier),
  2. la pagination ne consid√®rera que les posts de cette cat√©gorie,
  3. je peux d√©finir une cat√©gorie par d√©faut pour les fichiers qui se trouvent √† la racine si je le souhaite (sinon, √ßa pagine tout).

Je vous laisse jeter un oeil √† fr/index.html si besoin.

Note - C‚Äôest un premier jet qui peut aussi servir de pagination par cat√©gorie de mani√®re assez simpliste et orient√©e. N‚Äôh√©sitez pas √† proposer des am√©liorations =)

2. Filtre i18n

i18n_filter.rb customise le traitement de page.date en fonction de la langue.

J‚Äôai du ajouter un fichier _locales/fr.yml afin de cr√©er la fonction localize. Elle fonctionne de la m√™me mani√®re que date mais renvoie le format fran√ßais de la date.

Et voil√†¬†!

Rien d‚Äôautre n‚Äôa vraiment chang√©, juste ces correctifs √† apporter et le tour est jou√©. Si vous avez des suggestions, remarques ou soucis avec tout √ßa, fa√Ætes-le moi savoir.

Plop¬†!

item.title: Gitgraph.js
item.description: A JavaScript library, git trees, workflows modelisation‚Ä¶ and a bit of Georges Michael.
item.content:encoded:
The problem

Few time ago I was writing a post about git workflows. I wish I could use some illustration to explicit my thoughts at this time.

The git-flow already provided a nice illustration of the big picture for this workflow. But the GitHub flow didn‚Äôt.

Hopefully, @nvie gave its Keynote source and, hopefully, I‚Äôve got Keynote. Therefore I designed the second illustration myself, exported it and then get an image to insert in my post.

It was not a difficult operation, as long as you get the correct tools. But this is frustrating:

  • what if I want to do a little update?
  • what if I want to change the whole design?
  • what if I want to add some interaction?
  • what if I want to learn saxophone?

The solution

I wish I could find a nice little JavaScript library to design on-the-go graphs to illustrate my git worflows.

But, as we didn‚Äôt find anything convincing enough, @fabien0102 and I decided to develop our own solution : GitGraph.js !

Our guidelines are the following :

  • simple and intuitive API
  • flexibility and robustness of the result output
  • customisable design

The project reached a convincing state, stable enough to meet our first requirements. And so we released v1.0.0 and we‚Äôll scrupulously follow Semver, promise!.

Installation

Different solutions are available:

  • you can either download one of the latest releases sur GitHub
  • you can either use Bower with bower install gitgraph.js

Setting up

The set up process is dead easy.

Start adding the JavaScript (preferably before </body>) :

<script type="text/javascript" src="js/gitgraph.min.js"></script>

Then add the CSS (preferably before </head>) :

<link rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="css/gitgraph.css" />

Then, prepare some <canvas>, identified for GitGraph.js use :

<!-- some HTML here (‚Ä¶) -->
<canvas id="another-graph-here"></canvas>

Here we go!

Usage - Some examples

Using the library is straightforward : you just need to create a new GitGraph for each canvas, then to draw the desired graph.

Some parameters are customisable when you create your graph:

  • the desired template: "blackarrow" or "metro" (default)
  • the graph orientation: "vertical-reverse", "horizontal", "horizontal-reverse" or even "vertical" (default)
  • the display mode: "compact" to hide commit messages, or "extended" (default, only with a "vertical" display for now)
  • the targetted canvas ID ("gitGraph" is the default)
  • A default author for commits messages

And so we create our very first graph this way:

var myGitGraph = new GitGraph({
  elementId: 'my-canvas',
})

Then we add some branches:

var master = myGitGraph.branch('master')

A bunch of commits:

myGitGraph
  .commit()
  .commit()
  .commit() // 3 commits upon HEAD

Let‚Äôs create a new branch and add few commits:

var develop = myGitGraph.branch('develop')
develop.commit() // This commit will be on `develop`

Let‚Äôs do whatever we want:

// A new `feature` branch from `develop`
var myFeature = develop.branch('myFeature')

// A custom commit
myFeature.commit({
  dotColor: 'white',
  dotSize: 10,
  dotStrokeWidth: 10,
  sha1: '666',
  message: 'Pimp dat commit',
  author: 'Jacky <mailto:prince@dutunning.com>',
})

// Merge our feature branch back into `develop`
myFeature.merge(develop, 'Epic merge commit')

// Well we don't want to use it again, let's delete the old feature branch now
myFeature.delete()

The idea is to adapt the library to your needs so it could be intuitive.

There is still a lot of features to implement and bugs to correct. Please give us some feedbacks if you try it, that would be awesome =)

Usage - The result

Here are some basic use cases that could already be answered with the library.

This JavaScript:

var blackarrowSolution = new GitGraph({
  elementId: 'blackarrow-solution',
  orientation: 'vertical',
  template: 'blackarrow',
  author: 'Nicolas Carlo <mailto:nicolascarlo.espeon@gmail.com>',
})

var master = blackarrowSolution.branch('master')
blackarrowSolution
  .commit('This is a commit')
  .commit("And here's another one!")
  .commit()

var develop = master.branch('develop')
develop.commit('My first commit on develop.')

var feature = develop.branch('feature')
feature
  .commit('This is a mandatory feature')
  .commit()
  .commit()
develop.commit('Meawhile, we commit on develop‚Ä¶')
feature.merge(develop, 'Merged into develop')
feature.delete()

develop.commit('Add some commit here‚Ä¶').commit()
develop.merge(master, 'Here we merge!')
master.commit().commit()

Will produce the following output:

While this code:

var metroSolution = new GitGraph({
  elementId: 'metro-solution',
  orientation: 'horizontal',
})

var master = metroSolution.branch('master')
metroSolution
  .commit()
  .commit()
  .commit()

var develop = master.branch('develop')
develop.commit().commit()

develop.merge(master, 'Here we merge!')
master.commit().commit()

Will output this graph:

The project

Our project is open-source, available on GitHub : https://github.com/nicoespeon/gitgraph.js

Feel free to add an issue for any remark / suggestion / correction you‚Äôd have to do, or even to contribute more deeply. A technical documentation for the source code is available. A much more functional one is already considered, with concrete examples and use cases.

The project use the MIT license, which is simple and permissive.

Have a look to the website for more information about the library: gitgraphjs.com.

Hey, what about the sax?

I was afraid you wouldn‚Äôt ask. Thereupon I leave you with some Georges Michael tune \o/

Il y a quelques temps je r√©digeais un article sur les workflows git. Pour illustrer mes propos, je souhaitais m‚Äôappuyer sur une repr√©sentation visuelle de ces workflows.

Installation

Plusieurs solutions sont √† votre disposition¬†:

  • l‚ÄôID du canvas cibl√© ("gitGraph" par d√©faut)

On cr√©e donc un nouveau graphe tr√®s simplement ainsi¬†:

var monGitGraph = new GitGraph({

Puis on peut cr√©er des branches¬†:

Faire quelques commits¬†:

L‚Äôid√©e est que la biblioth√®que s‚Äôadapte aux usages afin de rester intuitive.

Il reste encore pas mal de fonctionnalit√©s √† impl√©menter et de petits bugs √† corriger. Mais si vous vous en servez, n‚Äôh√©sitez pas √† nous faire remonter soucis ou suggestions =)

Utilisation - Le r√©sultat

Voyons donc quelques exemples d‚Äôutilisation basiques que l‚Äôon peut mettre en place actuellement avec la biblioth√®que.

Produira le r√©sultat suivant¬†:

item.title: Which git workflow for my project?
item.description: A little look around git-flow, GitHub flow and which one to choose regarding your needs.
item.content:encoded:
TL;DR

One of the greatest strenght of git is the simplicity of its branching system.

If you‚Äôre in charge of a project, you may have wondered: which workflow could I set up to efficiently deal with my project and keep it simple thanks to this cool branching system?

As usual: some people already wondered the same and have found possible solutions to your problem.

The git-flow is the most popular with no doubt.

It‚Äôs a standard branching model that seems to adapt to any project, not that complex to deal with even though there are some specificities to understand.

If versioning has a meaning for you project, this workflow is for you.

There is a relevant alternative that is far easier: the Github flow.
This model has 6 simple rules and doesn‚Äôt have to consider every subtleties the previous one does.

If versioning doesn‚Äôt have a particular meaning for you project de sens and you would like to use an easy workflow, this workflow is for you.

The git-flow

This workflow has been published the 5th of January, 2010 by Vincent Driessen as a successful branching model for git. It covers most of the standard needs for a classical development project.

How it works

The git-flow has the following branching model:

We have first the primary branches, fixed and unchanging:

  • master is the main branch where everything is stable. Each commit is a stable version of the project - a release - which could be deployed in production and tagged accordingly (vX.Y.Z).

  • develop is the main branch where development is made. There will be prepared changes for the next release in master.

Then come the secondary branches which are flexible over time:

  • feature starts from develop and merge into develop.

    When you‚Äôre working on a specific feature, you create a feature/xxx branch. Then, when it‚Äôs over, you merge it back into develop to add the stable feature to the scope for the next release.

  • release starts from develop and merge into master or develop.

    When develop is reflecting the desired state of the future release - every features from the scope have been merged -, you create a release/xxx branch. Doing so, you can prepare the next release, correct eventual bugs and continue the development in parallel.

    Once the release is ready - stable - you merge the branch back into master, but also into develop to update it with modifications you made.

  • hotfix starts from master and merge into master or develop / release.

    When you want to quickly resolve a critical bug in production, you create a hotfix/xxx branch. It‚Äôs kind of a non-planned release.

    When the hotfix is developed, you merge it back into master with the according version number, and into develop as well - or the according release branch, if so - to update it with modifications you made.

Useful links

You might have a look at the original post to go deeper into details.

To make it simple when using the terminal, the author also created a git extension that easily implement the git-flow for you.

By the way, if you use SourceTree you may know that this workflow is natively implemented.

If you are a Windows or Mac user and you‚Äôre searching for a good graphic client for git/mercurial, I warmly recommend you to try SourceTree!

The GitHub flow

Scott Chacon shared this workflow in a blog post the 31th of August, 2011. It‚Äôs kind of a lightwight version of the previous one which, with a lot of common sense.

You‚Äôll notice that I kept the reference to GitHub because of the Scott‚Äôs blog post, but Atlassian - Bitbucket - presented it as the feature branch workflow for instance.

How it works

I have taken the liberty to illustrate the GitHub flow as follows:

You‚Äôll notice that there is only a single master branch - no develop - and a bunch of features. This model is extremely simple and this is precisely the goal. The learning curve est low, developers can quickly master this workflow which is perfectly relevant in some cases.

This workflow follows 6 basic rules:

1. Everything that is in master could be deployed in production

The absolute rule, same as the git-flow by the way. This is the only meaningful branch of the project and it should stay stable in any circumstance so you can base your work upon and deploy it in production at anytime.

2. Create descriptive features branchs from master

When you want to develop a feature or a hotfix, for instance, you just create your branch from master with an explicit name that describe your work: bug-grunt-tests, infrastructure-ssl or module-game-workers are examples from a project I currently work on, for example.

3. Regularly push to origin

In contrary of the git-flow where developer doesn‚Äôt have to push its local feature branch to the main repo, you have to regularly do that here.

Indeed, as far as you‚Äôre not on master, the stability of the branch doesn‚Äôt really matter. Doing so allows you to communicate and share your work with the whole team.

4. Open a pull-request at anytime

If your project is hosted on GitHub or Bitbucket, you should know that they both propose an incredibly interesting feature for code review: pull-requests.

It‚Äôs dead easy then, from any branch, to make a diff with master and open a pull-request at anytime: either you think you‚Äôre done or stuck on something, the pull-request allows you to ask someone else to have a look on what you did. Then, it‚Äôs possible to comment code, add modifications and visualize precisely what you‚Äôre about to merge into master.

5. Only merge after a pull-request review

This is much more and advice than an absolute rule. It‚Äôs a best practice that you can use to be sure that the first rule is less likely to be broken, still: a developer should not merge its own branch into master when he thinks he is done. Another one should review his pull-request and confirm that the branch is stable.

Doing so, if master becomes a mess because of this merge, you know who gave his agreement‚Ä¶ 0:-)

From here you can:

  • merge the branch back into master, directly from the pull-request
  • delete the merge branch, which became useless, on the server

If you are not synchronized anymore with master because you spend a long time working on your branch, you can‚Äôt merge directly the pull-request because there would be conflicts. You just need to merge master into your branch before, so you can fix conflicts and update your feature before merging it back into master.

6. Immediately deploy after you merge into master

Once pull-request is valid, your branch is merged into master so it means the whole thing is deployed to production, or will be soon.

Doing so, you‚Äôll stress on the necessity to keep master stable: developers don‚Äôt want to break everything because of its modifications were deployed, so they‚Äôre more likely to pay attention about his code stability before merge.

Few comments

This kind of workflow perfectly fits for projects that doesn‚Äôt have release nor versions.

You do continuous integration into master and you deploy the stable project to production, sometimes several times a day. You‚Äôll probably never rollback on master.

Thus, you‚Äôll very unlikely add series of big bugs. If problems appears, they‚Äôre quickly fixed on the go. There is no difference between a big feature and a small hotfix in terms of process. No matters what kind of change you have to do, the workflow still the same and keeps easy to use.

Useful links

Here again, you might have a look to the original post to go further into explanations.

Technically, GitHub is doing his best so you can deal with this entire workflow directly from your browser. Bitbucket is doing a great job also.

If you ever need, there is also a git extension which helps you to implement the workflow. But I guess you can handle it by yourself, in the browser.

Final words

To choose the best workflow depends on the nature and needs of your project. It‚Äôs up to you to consider which of these examples fit more or less with your reality, and adapt a workflow to your needs if so.

These are workflows I typically use so far. If you have other tracks, ideas or comments, please share.

item.title: Quel git workflow pour mon projet¬†?
item.description: Un petit tour d'horizon sur le git-flow, le GitHub flow et comment choisir le plus adapt√© √† son projet.
item.content:encoded:
TL;DR

L‚Äôune des grandes forces de git r√©side dans la simplicit√© de son syst√®me de branches.
Si vous √™tes en charge d‚Äôun projet, peut-√™tre vous √™tes-vous d√©j√† pos√© la question¬†: quel workflow mettre en place pour g√©rer efficacement mon projet, sans me compliquer la vie avec ce sympathique syst√®me de branches¬†?

Et forc√®ment¬†: √† ce probl√®me, certains s‚Äôy sont d√©j√† pench√©s et ont apport√© leurs solutions.

Le git-flow est probablement le plus connu, voire le seul d‚Äôailleurs.
Il s‚Äôagit d‚Äôun mod√®le de branches standard qui semble s‚Äôadapter √† n‚Äôimporte quel projet, pas trop complexe √† prendre en main, avec quelques subtilit√©s cependant.

Si la notion de versions a un sens pour votre projet, c‚Äôest ce workflow qui peut vous int√©resser.

Il existe une alternative pertinente qui a l‚Äôavantage d‚Äô√™tre bien plus simple¬†: le GitHub flow.

Le mod√®le tient en 6 r√®gles simples qui n‚Äôont pas besoin de prendre en compte les subtilit√©s du workflow pr√©c√©dent.

Si la notion de versions n‚Äôa pas sp√©cialement de sens pour votre projet et que vous souhaitez mettre en place un workflow simplifi√©, c‚Äôest ce workflow qui peut vous int√©resser.

Le git-flow

Ce workflow a √©t√© pr√©sent√© le 5 Janvier 2010 par Vincent Driessen comme un workflow de branchements git efficace. Il couvre l‚Äôensemble des besoins standards d‚Äôun projet de d√©veloppement classique.

Le principe

Le git-flow pr√©sente le syst√®me de branches suivant¬†:

On distingue les branches principales, fixes et immuables¬†:

  • master est la branche o√π tout est stable. Chaque commit correspond √† une version stable du projet (release) qui peut √™tre d√©ploy√©e en production et tagu√©e en cons√©quence (vX.Y.Z).

  • develop est la branche sur laquelle s‚Äôeffectue le d√©veloppement proprement dit. On y pr√©pare les changements en vue de la prochaine release dans master.

Puis les branches secondaires qui se font et se d√©font avec le temps¬†:

  • feature part de develop et se merge dans develop.

    On cr√©e une branche feature/xxx lorsque l‚Äôon travaille sur une fonctionnalit√© en particulier. Lorsqu‚Äôelle est termin√©e, on la merge dans develop pour ajouter la feature stable dans le scope de la prochaine release.

  • release part de develop et se merge dans master et develop.

    On cr√©e une branche release/xxx √† partir de develop lorsque celle-ci refl√®te l‚Äô√©tat d√©sir√© de la release (l‚Äôensemble des fonctionnalit√©s du scope ont √©t√© merg√©es). Ainsi, on peut pr√©parer la prochaine release tranquillement, corriger d‚Äô√©ventuels bugs et poursuivre le d√©veloppement en parall√®le.

    Une fois que la release est pr√™te (stable) on merge alors la branche dans master, mais aussi dans develop pour mettre √† jour les modifications apport√©es.

  • hotfix part de master et se merge dans master et develop / release.

    On cr√©e une branche hotfix/xxx lorsque l‚Äôon veut r√©soudre un bug critique en production rapidement. C‚Äôest un peu comme une release non planifi√©e.

    Lorsque le correctif est d√©velopp√©, on le merge dans master avec le num√©ro de version qui convient, ainsi que dans develop (ou la branche release en cours, le cas √©ch√©ant) pour mettre √† jour les modifications apport√©es.

Liens utiles

Je vous sugg√®re de jeter un oeil sur l‚Äôarticle original pour en apprendre plus sur la question.

Pour vous simplifier la vie dans le terminal, sachez que l‚Äôauteur a √©galement mis au point une extension git pour impl√©menter simplement le git-flow.

Enfin, pour les utilisateurs de SourceTree, sachez que ce workflow est nativement impl√©ment√©.

Si vous √™tes sous Windows ou Mac et que vous cherchez un bon client graphique pour git/mercurial, je vous recommande chaudement d‚Äôessayer SourceTree d‚Äôailleurs¬†!

Le GitHub flow

Scott Chacon l‚Äôa pr√©sent√© dans un post le 31 Ao√ªt 2011. Il s‚Äôagit d‚Äôune version all√©g√©e du pr√©c√©dent et d√©coule, en quelque sorte, du bon sens.

A noter que je garde ici la r√©f√©rence √† GitHub par rapport au superbe post de Scott mais Atlassian (Bitbucket) le pr√©sente, par exemple, comme le workflow feature branch.

Le principe

Je me suis permis d‚Äôillustrer le GitHub flow de la mani√®re suivante¬†:

Vous constaterez qu‚Äôil n‚Äôy a qu‚Äôune seule branche master (pas de develop ici) et des features √† gogo. Il est frappant de constater que le mod√®le est extr√™mement simple et c‚Äôest le but. La courbe d‚Äôapprentissage est faible, les d√©veloppeurs prennent rapidement en main ce workflow qui s‚Äôav√®re parfaitement adapt√© dans certains cas de figures.

Ce workflow se base donc sur 6 r√®gles essentielles¬†:

1. Tout ce qui est dans master peut √™tre d√©ploy√© en production

La r√®gle absolue, commune au git-flow d‚Äôailleurs. C‚Äôest la seule branche consistante du projet et elle doit rester stable pour pouvoir se baser dessus et √™tre d√©ploy√©e en production.

2. Cr√©er des branches explicites depuis master (features)

Lorsqu‚Äôon souhaite travailler sur quelque chose (une fonctionnalit√©, un hotfix, etc.), on cr√©e une branche depuis master avec un nom explicite, si possible¬†: bug-grunt-tests, infrastructure-ssl ou module-game-workers sont des exemples tir√©s d‚Äôun projet sur lequel je travaille actuellement par exemple.

3. Pousser sur origin r√©guli√®rement

Contrairement au git-flow, o√π le d√©veloppeur ne va pas forc√©ment pousser sa branche feature locale sur le d√©p√¥t central, il s‚Äôagit ici de pousser les branches r√©guli√®rement.

En effet, tant que nous ne sommes pas sur master il importe peu que la branche soit stable. En contrepartie, cela permet de communiquer avec l‚Äô√©quipe.

4. Ouvrir une pull-request √† tout moment

Si votre projet est h√©berg√© sur GitHub ou Bitbucket, sachez que les deux proposent une fonctionnalit√© extr√™mement int√©ressante pour la revue de code¬†: les pull-request.

Il est tr√®s facile, depuis une branche, de faire un diff avec master et d‚Äôouvrir une pull-request √† n‚Äôimporte quel moment¬†: que l‚Äôon pense avoir termin√© ou que l‚Äôon soit coinc√©, la pull-request permet de demander une revue du code. Il est alors possible de commenter le code, d‚Äôapporter des modifications et de visualiser ce que l‚Äôon s‚Äôappr√™te √† fusionner dans master.

5. Fusionner seulement apr√®s une pull-request review

Il s‚Äôagit plus d‚Äôun conseil que d‚Äôune r√®gle absolue. Mais c‚Äôest la bonne pratique √† mettre en place pour s‚Äôassurer que la premi√®re r√®gle est respect√©e¬†: un d√©veloppeur ne doit pas fusionner sa branche dans master lorsqu‚Äôil pense que c‚Äôest bon, un autre doit venir faire une revue du code et confirmer la stabilit√© de la branche.

Ainsi, si le merge vient mettre la pagaille sur master, on sait sur qui taper‚Ä¶ 0:-)

Vous pouvez alors¬†:

  • fusionner la branche dans master, directement depuis la pull-request
  • supprimer la branche, devenue inutile, sur le serveur

Si cela fait un moment que vous travaillez sur votre branche et que vous n‚Äô√™tes plus synchro avec master, vous ne pourrez pas fusionner directement depuis la pull-request car il y aura des conflits. Il vous suffit de faire un merge de master dans votre branche et r√®gler les potentiels conflits pour la mettre √† jour.

6. D√©ployer imm√©diatement apr√®s merge dans master

Une fois que la pull-request est valid√©e, la branche est merg√©e dans master ce qui signifie que le tout est d√©ploy√© en production (ou va √™tre d√©ploy√© sous peu).

C‚Äôest √©galement une fa√ßon d‚Äôaccentuer la pression sur la n√©cessaire stabilit√© de master¬†: le d√©veloppeur ne souhaite g√©n√©ralement pas que le d√©ploiement de ses modifications ne casse tout, il fera donc d‚Äôautant plus attention √† la stabilit√© de son code avant de fusionner.

Quelques remarques

Ce genre de workflow s‚Äôadapte parfaitement √† un projet pour lequel il n‚Äôy a pas vraiment de releases, ni de versions.

On int√®gre en continue dans master les fonctionnalit√©s et on d√©ploie, parfois plusieurs fois par jour, le projet stable. On revient assez rarement (jamais) en arri√®re sur master.

Ainsi, il est difficile d‚Äôajouter une s√©rie de gros bugs. Si des probl√®mes apparaissent, ils sont rapidement r√©solus dans la foul√©e. Il n‚Äôy a pas de diff√©rence entre une grosse feature et un petit hotfix avec ce process. Peu importe la nature du changement √† effectuer, le workflow est toujours le m√™me (et donc tr√®s simple √† prendre en main).

Liens utiles

Je vous sugg√®re l√† encore de jeter un oeil sur l‚Äôarticle original pour en apprendre plus sur la question.

Techniquement, GitHub a fait en sorte de vous permettre de g√©rer ce workflow enti√®rement, directement depuis le navigateur. Bitbucket se d√©brouille pas mal non plus.

Si vous en ressentez le besoin, il y a √©galement une extension git pour impl√©menter le workflow. Mais dans l‚Äôensemble, il se manie assez bien dans le navigateur.

Le mot de la fin

Choisir son workflow d√©pend de la nature et des besoins de son projet. A vous de voir si ces exemples s‚Äôadaptent plus ou moins √† votre r√©alit√©, quitte √† faire quelques adaptations si n√©cessaire.

Voici donc pour les workflows que j‚Äôutilise, n‚Äôh√©sitez pas √† partager d‚Äôautres pistes, d‚Äôautres id√©es.

item.title: Convert a SASS project into LESS
item.description: Similarities, differences et equivalents between those two CSS preprocessors.
item.content:encoded:
Matters of taste

LESS and SASS today are the two most popular CSS preprocessors so far.

They are quite similar and give functionalities to CSS that every front-end developer ever dreamt: variables, functions, mathematical operations, selectors nesting, etc.

However, there are some differences:

  • SASS is compiled with Ruby, it has two different syntaxes: .sass and .scss.
    The second one, closer to the CSS syntax, is the most used.
  • LESS is compiled with Javascript, it has one syntax which is quite close to the CSS.

As a general rule, we can say that SASS is more powerful than LESS because it notably has a bunch of additional functionalities. However, this is a matter of taste and LESS could suffice enough to please you and, in my opinion, is easier to use at first.

Personnally, I use LESS instead of SASS with my projects, mostfully because I get used to it.

In the same time, I tend to use the inuit.css framework (instead of Bootstrap) on these projects. But inuit.css uses SASS!

Hopefully, I‚Äôm not the only one who likes LESS and Peter Wilson has worked to create the LESS version of the framework. As I was keen on this idea, I joined the project we are maintaining today: the official LESS port of inuit.css.

It‚Äôs all about traducing the SASS framework into LESS, which leads us to 3 options:

  1. The SASS code is identical to the LESS one, so it‚Äôs the same principle
  2. The SASS code as an equivalent in LESS, so you need to find the alternative
  3. The SASS code doesn‚Äôt have any equivalent in LESS and you need to ruse - or ignore it -

Here is a broad overview of these options, as far as I know.

What is identical in LESS

In such a case, it‚Äôs dead easy: there is nothing to do.

Indeed, even though they are differents, SASS and LESS both share some basic concepts.

Nesting

One of the guiding principle of CSS preprocessors: selectors nesting.

Instead of creating huge selectors to specify inheritance, you just have to nest them like this:

.islet {
  margin-top: 24px;

  p {
    color: #bada55;
    font-weight: bold;
  }
}

That will produce the following code, in both languages:

.islet {
  margin-top: 24px;
}

.islet p {
  color: #bada55;
  font-weight: bold;
}

Beware - Developers, whether they are experimented or not, often abuse of nesting which bloats their CSS for no valuable reason.

Keep in mind the inception rule: never go farther than 4 nested levels.

Comments and compilation

In addition to features they bring, preprocessors help you to produce code clear and organized while having a single compiled - and compressed - CSS file as the output for production.

In that spirit, SASS and LESS both have alternate comments that are not compiled into CSS. So this code:

/**
 * The date/time
 */
.timeline__time {
  position: absolute;
  display: block;

  // The actual inner width is `25% - x`, `x` is the padding
  padding-right: 24px;
  width: 200px;
}

Will produce the following code:

/**
 * The date/time
 */
.timeline__time {
  position: absolute;
  display: block;

  padding-right: 24px;
  width: 200px;
}

Which could be very helpful in case you want to add some code comments which would not be relevant for production code.

Please note that a compiled file for production should be compressed so it doesn‚Äôt have CSS comments neither, excepted if you decide to preserve them. YUI compressor uses /*! */ to preserve CSS comments for instance.

Imports

Preprocessors help you to import other files very easily with @import, which allows you to build a clear and modular architecture of your source files. Dare I say: CSS preprocessors are OOCSS best friends.

A best practice may be to create a main.less / _main.scss file which role is to import the source file you need to produce your final main.css:

/**
 * Setup
 */
@import 'inuit.css/defaults';
@import 'vars';
@import 'inuit.css/inuit';

/**
 * It's all yours, cap‚Äôn‚Ä¶ Begin importing your stuff here.
 */
@import 'ui/base';
@import 'ui/layout';

@import 'ui/mod-block-list';
@import 'ui/mod-helper';

/* etc. */

You‚Äôll note here that it‚Äôs pointless to add the extension, whatever preprocessor you use.

Beware - All likeness taken after, the @import command of preprocessors has nothing to do with CSS one. Indeed, preprocessors will import your files when you compile them to output a unique CSS file that will be used in production. But CSS import will load many files by the browser.

Please note that the use of @import is not a very good CSS practice, try to avoid it.

What has an equivalent in LESS

In such a case, you mainly have to know the syntax and specificities of each language as fundamentals principles are the same. Let‚Äôs see what you‚Äôve got‚Ä¶

Variables

SASS and LESS both allow you to create variables, which is basically the Holy Grail in CSS!

The concept is very straight forward. The only difference here is that SASS uses $ while LESS uses @.

/* With SASS */
$color: #bada55;

.header {
  color: $color;
}
/* With LESS */
@color: #bada55;

.header {
  color: @color;
}

And so the CSS output is:

.header {
  color: #bada55;
}

Mixins

SASS and LESS both allow you to create what we call mixins. That means that you could simply create groups of properties that can be quickly included wherever you want to.

Here again, the main difference is the syntax, not the concept:

/* With SASS */
@mixin bordered {
  border-top: dotted 1px black;
  border-bottom: solid 2px black;
}

.header {
  @include bordered;
}
/* With LESS */
.bordered() {
  border-top: dotted 1px black;
  border-bottom: solid 2px black;
}

.header {
  .bordered();
}

This will output:

.header {
  border-top: dotted 1px black;
  border-bottom: solid 2px black;
}

You should know that mixins can do more and have parameters, default values, conditions, etc.

Without going further into details, you should know also that mixins can take a variable number of arguments into account.

However, while SASS deals perfectly with the different values you give to the parameters, you would have to escape those you pass to LESS if you don‚Äôt want him to interpret the whole thing as a single big variable.

Escaping in LESS would return the exactly given output thanks to ~‚Äúmy string‚Äù, which could be helpful for a bunch of tips.

Technically, code is the following:

/* With SASS */
@mixin box-shadow($shadows‚Ä¶) {
  -moz-box-shadow: $shadows;
  -webkit-box-shadow: $shadows;
  box-shadow: $shadows;
}

.shadows {
  @include box-shadow(0 4px 5px #666, 2px 6px 10px #999);
}
/* With LESS */
.box-shadow(@shadows‚Ä¶) {
  -moz-box-shadow: @shadows;
  -webkit-box-shadow: @shadows;
  box-shadow: @shadows;
}

.shadows {
  .box-shadow(~'0 4px 5px #666, 2px 6px 10px #999');
}

And that would produce this CSS:

.shadows {
  -moz-box-shadow: 0 4px 5px #666, 2px 6px 10px #999;
  -webkit-box-shadow: 0 4px 5px #666, 2px 6px 10px #999;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 5px #666, 2px 6px 10px #999;
}

Excepted some little specificities, mixins just work the same.

Operations

Every preprocessor has is bunch of mathematical operations which could be very useful to do some flexible styling with variables.

Syntaxes are very close and intuitive - just a matter of + and -, etc. A best practice is to isolate these operations into parenthesis so you avoid potential confusions and conflicts.

However, you should know that LESS is considering the first unit specified in the calculus, which could lead to some aberrations while SASS will properly output a warning instead of compiling something wrong:

.container {
  width: 300px + 2em; // == 302px o_O
}

So in LESS you should better not specify variables unit so you don‚Äôt have that kind of nasty surprises when you do operations. You just have to apply the unit at the very end and you‚Äôre all set:

@base-font-size: 16;
@base-spacing-unit: 24;

html {
  font-size: (@base-font-size/16)*1em;
  margin-bottom: @base-spacing-unit*1px;
}

Which will produce:

html {
  font-size: 1em;
  margin-bottom: 24px;
}

Functions

Each preprocessor brings their own functions that allow you to do a bunch of very nice things with colors, maths, strings, etc.

You may have a look to each respective list to get an idea:

  • SASS functions
  • LESS functions

Interpolation

Sometimes you‚Äôll need to include some variables into stings and interprate them however. That‚Äôs what we call interpolation and both SASS and LESS allow you to do that:

/* With SASS */
$base-url: '../images';

.container {
  background-image: url('#{$base-url}/bg.png');
}
/* With LESS */
@base-url: '../images';

.container {
  background-image: url('@{base-url}/bg.png');
}

Which will produce:

.container {
  background-image: url('../images/bg.png');
}

The only difference is the syntax: #{ $var } with SASS and @{ var } with LESS.

You also can interpolate variables within selectors as we could see with loops - yep, I‚Äôm working on my transitions.

Loops

Technically speaking, both preprocessors can implement loops which could be very useful.

However, SASS natively deals with the iteration logic, not LESS. In fact, you can use an alternative based on mixins to create the loop behavior with LESS.

With LESS, here is the deal:

  1. Create a mixin with an @index parameter
  2. The mixin will produce the content of the loop while @index > 0
  3. At the end of the mixin, you decrease @index
  4. You create an empty verion of the mixin to stop the loop when @index = 0

Which leads us to the following syntaxes for a loop:

/* With SASS */
$index: 5;

@while $index > 0 {
  // Interpolate the class name
  .container-#{$index} {
    z-index: $index;
  }

  // Decrease the index
  $index: $index - 1;
}
/* With LESS */
.loop (@index) when (@index > 0) {
  // Interpolate the class name
  .container-@{index} {
    z-index: @index;
  }

  // Decrease the index and start the loop again
  .loop (@index - 1);
}

// Stop the loop at 0
.loop (0) {
}

// Start the loop
.loop (5);

Which will output, once compiled:

.container-5 {
  z-index: 5;
}
.container-4 {
  z-index: 4;
}
.container-3 {
  z-index: 3;
}
.container-2 {
  z-index: 2;
}
.container-1 {
  z-index: 1;
}

This technique is used by Bootstrap to generate spans regarding the number of columns.

Extend and silent classes

With SASS you can extend a class properties very easily to share a common style, the second class inherits style of the first one.

For instance, this:

.error {
  border: 1px #f00;
  background-color: #fdd;
}

.serious-error {
  @extend .error;
  border-width: 3px;
}

Will give the following code:

.error,
.serious-error {
  border: 1px #f00;
  background-color: #fdd;
}

.serious-error {
  border-width: 3px;
}

SASS can create what we call silent classes: you just define classes that wouldn‚Äôt be compiled until they are included somewhere with @extend.

So this code:

a%error {
  color: red;
  font-weight: bold;
}

.notice {
  @extend %error;
}

Will output the following:

a.notice {
  color: red;
  font-weight: bold;
}

With LESS, you‚Äôll generally use mixins to realize that kind of extensions. Just like a silent class, the mixin won‚Äôt be compiled until it‚Äôs included somewhere. So it comes with the same spirit, only the syntax changes:

.error() {
  a& {
    color: red;
    font-weight: bold;
  }
}

.notice {
  .error();
}

That said, you‚Äôll note that SASS is extending smartly selectors - .error, serious-error in the previous example. With LESS, you‚Äôd need to do that by hand.

Note - LESS v1.4 - which is currently in beta - will introduce :extend() that could handle selectors extension. The syntax would be closer to the CSS one, just like a pseudo-selector, which should produce something like that:

.error {
  border: 1px #f00;
  background-color: #fdd;
}

.serious-error:extend(.error) {
  border-width: 3px;
}

!default variables

With SASS you can set a default value to variables at any time. The default value is used if the variable is not already defined somewhere.

$base-font-size: 14px;
$base-font-size: 16px !default;
$base-spacing-unit: 24px !default;
